Whilst section 44ZZA(6) confers powers on the commission to resolve disputes in accordance with an undertaking, there are no provisions for the commission to make determinations in the absence of a dispute. Conceptually, it would be possible to manufacture such a dispute, but this is an awkward way of regulating access issues.

The government's second amendment would provide for section 44ZZA to be amended to state that if an undertaking provides for the commission to make a determination in relation to any aspect of access, the commission shall make the determination in accordance with the undertaking. In this regard, the commission would exercise powers similar to those conferred on it by part IIIA of the act in relation to the declared services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just for clarification, I reiterate that the Greens (WA) will not be supporting the government's amendments in this regard because they actually reduce the amount of information that it is necessary for people to provide in relation to access codes. We do not think that is going in the right direction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, with your concurrence I would like to set a series of questions to you. Before I do so, I would like to acknowledge the courtesy of both you and your officials in giving us a briefing on this. It is much appreciated.

SPEECH.PARA: Minister, as you know, one of our principal concerns is that, in rationalising and making this whole process more efficient in your terms—I acknowledge the reservations of Senator Margetts—the ACCC may not, and probably does not, have the resources, the expertise or the funds to do this job. My first question relates to that. Does the ACCC have the resources, the expertise and the funds, or will it be given them, to be able to properly assess the public interest without calling for public submissions?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for those comments. I reiterate that we appreciate the frankness with which you have dealt with your concerns on this issue. I have to say, Senator Murray, that unlike the Labor Party in this area there have been some constructive discussions and a willingness to try to work through what are often complex issues without indulging in undue point scoring and political manoeuvring.

SPEECH.PARA: Just for clarification, it is perhaps worth mentioning how the public interest provisions of the Trade Practices Act operate. In the act, public interest must be considered when the ACCC is examining an application for authorisation and when the ACCC is examining an access undertaking. The act provides that when performing these functions the ACCC must publish the application and call for public submissions. Similarly, the amendments in the bill provide that the ACCC, before attempting an access code, must engage in public consultation. I think that perhaps goes a little way to addressing some of the issues Senator Margetts raised. It seems to me to perhaps clarify something which may have led to some confusion.

In relation to resources, when it was established in November 1995 the ACCC received an increase of 51 staff from 1995 to 1996 to undertake new functions arising out of the competition policy reforms. Recent reform of the scope of prices surveillance, as announced by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) in September 1996, allows for the freeing up of ACCC resources for use on the ACCC's competition policy reform work. Let me assure you: the government is committed to ensuring that the ACCC has sufficient resources to perform its responsibilities in areas such as electricity. We are anxious that the work is done and we believe that the resources are there. I have mentioned the increase in staff.

While I am on my feet, I will refer to public interest. That was a matter Senator Margetts raised. I wrote to the senator about how public interest is determined. I do not know from her comments whether it did address her concerns—

TALK.START.PARA: —It tried to, but no.

—Thank you, Senator. I think you suggested that public interest equals, in the government's view, naked competition, or words to that effect. It is just worth recording that the competition principles require governments to take into account a list of public interest matters when undertaking a review of regulation. The list is non-exclusive and specifically includes policies relating to ecologically sustainable development, social welfare and equity considerations, including community service obligations, and economic and regional development. I know that you attempt to define it in a narrow way. I think we are indicating that a wider range of interests are taken into account. That was the effort to explain that to you. I think that was worth putting on record.

—Thank you for that response, Minister. That is helpful. I think in particular the requirement that the ACCC has the power to and does call for public submissions and must consult goes quite some way to answering that question. The next question—it probably emerges on a close reading of the act, which I have not had—is: what powers does the ACCC have to enforce undertakings with regard to this code as to access from service providers?

—The advice I have from officials is that the act confers power on the ACCC to enforce breaches of undertakings. Section 44ZZJ provides that the Federal Court can, upon application by the ACCC, require the access provider to comply with its undertakings. I think that illustrates the powers which are available for enforcement.

—I would like to pursue this a little more, Minister, and perhaps you can be a little more specific. If your optimistic view is right, and if this does deliver immense benefits to the community, including $5.8 billion worth, there is a lot at stake. The power of enforcement is therefore an important one. Are there specific penalties, fines or specific and meaningful enforcement provisions available to the ACCC? If, in the scheme of things, there are thousands of dollars worth of fines versus billions of dollars worth of benefits, you can see that they might not have much effect. I would appreciate your indicating whether these enforcement provisions have weight and impact.

—I mentioned that section 44ZZJ provides that the Federal Court, upon application by the ACCC, can require the access provider to comply with its undertaking. This means that the Federal Court can make an order requiring compliance. A breach of an order of the court would be considered a contempt of the court. I think that provides the teeth that you are looking for.

—If, after accepting an undertaking, the ACCC subsequently becomes aware that a service provider could be disadvantaged by the undertaking, can the undertaking be withdrawn and reviewed, taking into account the new information?

—If a service provider is disadvantaged by an undertaking, he or she can apply to the ACCC for a variation of the undertaking. If the ACCC consents to the variation, the undertaking is so varied. I think that addresses that particular concern.

—I understand that service providers have the ability to make a challenge. But, if it becomes obvious that the provision is detrimental to community interests, do the community have the same rights of appeal?
—No, Senator. The undertakings are basically private undertakings between the provider and the commission.
—So it is a one‐way thing. The provision gives extra appeal power or a veto to industry but leaves that appeal power out for the community.

—That is an important point, and I look forward to Senator Margetts pursuing it further after I deal with this last question. I understand that the provisions for review and withdrawal, if necessary, relate to a material change of facts. What does `material change' mean in these instances? Is it restricted unduly in any way?

—There is no requirement for the ACCC to be satisfied that there has been a material change of circumstances. The material change of circumstances is a concept relevant to the authorisation, not the undertaking.

—I note that the minister at the table, the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), when addressing the first question asked by Senator Murray, said that Senator Murray had conferred with his office in the proper way, unlike the manoeuvring and point scoring of the ALP. I am not quite sure what all that means, because we are supporting these amendments. I thought the minister might have been a bit more generous than that, given we are voting for his proposal. However, I rise to signify where our vote will go.

—Senator Cook, it has never been my intention to cause offence to people but to put facts on the table only. We of course welcome your support for the amendments that we have moved. If you felt we were not appreciative enough, let me affirm that we appreciate your support for our amendments. But we are very concerned about the amendments that you are proposing to move.
—I wish to indicate that we will support the government's amendments.

BREAK.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Schedule 1.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, page 3 (after line 6), after item 1, insert:
1A Section 44B (after paragraph (c) of the definition of service )
Insert:
(ca) a service provided by a petroleum terminal, including the storage, handling, distribution and supply of petroleum products;
(2) Schedule 1, page 3 (after line 6), after item 1, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 1B Before Subdivision A of Division 2 of Part IIIA

SPEECH.PARA: Insert:

EMPHASIS.TAB: 44EA Petroleum terminals to be declared service

SPEECH.PARA: Petroleum terminals are a declared service for the purposes of this Part.

When I addressed the Senate in the debate on the second reading, I gave, for want of a better description, a second reading to these amendments by spending some time spelling out the purpose of them. Since then I note, with appreciation, that the Australian Democrats have indicated their support for these amendments. I am not entirely sure whether I caught the position of the Greens, but I am sure they will make that clear. I was overwhelmed by the opposition of the government to these amendments because that constituted most of the second reading reply by the minister.

In short, these points perhaps need to be made. The purpose of these amendments is to bring greater competition to the oil industry in Australia. All of us in this chamber know that there is competition in the oil industry at retail level but there is no competition at wholesale level. Retailers purchase from an oligopoly, which seems to control prices, between themselves. It is not at all surprising, as I said in my second reading remarks, that you would buy BP petrol from a service station that has been supplied by a Shell terminal or, in my own state of Western Australia, you might buy Ampol petrol from the BP refinery at Kwinana because BP supplies all the petrol stations in Western Australia. As you move around Australia, this is the case.

The purpose of my amendments is to enable competition between wholesalers and to require that as part of the national competition and consumer policy in the competition policy regime in Australia. What do we have from the government when we talk about introducing competition, which will have the direct impact of reducing prices at the bowser for Australian consumers and, importantly, reducing prices at the bowser for consumers of petroleum products who live in regional Australia? We have two points. Both these points were made by the minister in his second reading reply.

The first point was that the government is committed to bringing down petrol prices and it has its own program to do so. Congratulations to the government for that, if it succeeds. We have a view about the likelihood of that success, but one hopes that it does work. That is not an argument to say that if prices could be reduced further, we should not go further and reduce those prices.

The fundamental point here is that the cost of petrol or diesel fuel is an input cost to Australian business. If those prices can be reduced, obviously, the retail prices those businesses charge for their services or their goods can also be reduced, making the cost to the Australian consumer of those products less, meaning that where Australian companies are in competition with foreign companies, we will be able to reduce our prices in that market, and where we are trying to export, we will be able to reduce our prices and win greater market share. It is a question of economic efficiency.

To the first point—that the government says we are doing something about it—if the imputation is that, therefore, nothing else should be done, I think that imputation should be rejected by the Senate. If something can be done or if a lot of things can be done, all of which will have the effect of reducing costs and introducing competition, they all should be done. The principle we are talking about here is a principle of economic efficiency under the competition guidelines which we are simply applying to the petrol market.

The second argument raised by the government in the second reading speech was that we did not give them sufficient notice of our amendment—that they tried to obtain a copy of it last night and could not, and that this is point scoring by the Australian Labor Party, springing a surprise on them in the chamber without proper debate. If all those things are true, I regret that the government has not received proper notice if, indeed, it has not. I am surprised that it could not obtain a copy of our amendments last night. I do not recall any contact with my office in an effort to do so. If the government says it could not, I accept its word for it.

The question here is: should a procedure of formality block an issue of principle? If the formality and procedure and the lack of due courtesy—if I accept the full weight of the government's criticism, which may be arguable, but for the sake of the occasion, let me accept it—are to block the application of an overriding principle, which will have an important effect on this industry, in weighing which way one should go, one should always opt for the principle and accept that the principle here is valid.
With those remarks, and having moved my amendments, I hope that the National Party has paid attention to the impact these changes will have on the retail price of petrol in country areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of issues involved in the opposition's amendments. Honourable senators may recall that on more than one occasion I have indicated that the price of petroleum internationally is actually artificially low, the price that we pay for petroleum is artificially low, and the reason is because the world petroleum sources are moving towards their halfway point. There is usually good reason why much of the rest of the world's petroleum resources have not been obtained and the reason is related to the cost of production.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not just the cost of production but it is the cost of energy that is important. If you end up expending more energy to get out your energy, it never becomes economical. No matter how many dollars are involved and no matter how short petroleum becomes at some stage, if it costs more energy to get the petroleum out of the ground or the sea or wherever than you gain from petroleum, it never becomes economical.

Whilst technology changes, that cost of energy must be taken into consideration. I think it is not taken into consideration enough in government policy. So in that sense we are living in a bit of a paradise as far as petroleum is concerned. The price is artificially low, and it has been for some time. It is not helping us properly to adjust to what could be in a relatively short time quite substantial increases in petroleum costs.

I am not the only one to have come up with these figures. Even Senator Parer has admitted in this chamber that the government accepts this model, and international petroleum consultants have come to the same conclusion. I am not talking about environmental consultants but basically petro‐consultants who have done a lot of work on this issue. So in reality we are living in a paradise. I say to those people who want cheap fuel that it will not be around for long.

I wanted to put that generally on the table first: that we ought to be realistic about the price of fuel and get used to the fact that trying to get the lowest price now may not allow us to be realistic about our petroleum use in the future. Perhaps we have to look more at alternatives to the use of petroleum, alternatives in types of transport and alternatives to the use of petroleum resources in other industries as well.

Having said that, we are dealing with a situation where the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission still has elements of the old Industry Commission, which I think had a fairly well recognised big business orientation. That often meant that the ability for small businesses to survive and compete fairly was perhaps not given the priority that the concerns of large industry were given, and often the ability for large industry to be profitable was equated to competition. Of course, this is not necessarily the case.

BREAK.PARA: We know that people who have to get from A to B cannot, in the short term at least, make different decisions if the price of petroleum goes up or down. So in the short term at least those decisions may be inelastic; that is, people might go from petrol station to petrol station depending on the price but when there is a change in price they will not necessarily be able to use much more or much less petrol in the short term. That is especially the case for people in a country town which has only one source of petrol. They still have to get from A to B. Until there are changes in transport modes, types of cars, types of engines and so on, in the short term it is very hard to change those decisions.

Given that, we must consider, as Senator Murray has indicated—and I fully agree with him—the level of vertical integration in the petroleum industry. It is a well established fact that companies drill for oil, they produce it, they market it and they are then involved with the retail trade as well. They go right from go to whoa and have a lot of control over very large players and a very large industry right down to the selling of groceries at 24‐hour petrol stations.

There is a lot of vertical integration. Therefore, we need to be concerned about whether or not we should be assisting that ongoing vertical integration, which often pushes out a lot of small businesses, or looking at what the total outcomes are. I think we ought to be looking at the total outcomes. Because of that, I am prepared to support the opposition's amendment that we do provide the means by which operators of petrol stations can make a choice about their sources of petroleum. Therefore, I indicate that I will be supporting this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —This concept of competition in the fuel industry, particularly the petrol industry, has been around for a long time. There has been, I suppose, well‐meaning attempts to do something about it. For example, ACTU Solo was formed when I was on the ACTU executive. I was not terribly convinced that that would work. I do not think it ultimately did work. For a short time it brought down prices in particular suburbs of Melbourne, but what good did it do elsewhere?

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose I support in principle every attempt to tackle this problem, and I am inclined to support the proposal put by Senator Cook. The question is: will it work? As Senator Margetts has said, there is virtually a stranglehold on the industry. This is not going to touch the producers; it will touch the wholesalers. The people who are really hurting at the moment in some areas are the retailers—the people who are working in the retail trade.

Just as an aside I would like to comment on the ACCC. What worries me a little—and I do not want to foreshadow my view on the next amendment—is the term `in the public interest' being tied in. What do they take `in the public interest' to mean? Do they say that the public interest is that a shop should be open 24 hours seven days a week. Is that in the community interest, in the public interest?

We are facing that very issue, which has been coming from the ACCC—and that is a problem. It is certainly a problem for the workers concerned. It is a problem for a lot of retailers. If that is the sort of philosophy that is being advanced by people in that area, then I would be very wary about what is meant by amendments which include terms like `public interest', `community interest' and all the rest of it. Obviously we have to have that there, but we really do have to tie down what the people administering that mean. The only way to ultimately do that, I suppose, is by legislation.

Having said all that, I am just wondering what the government's practical arguments are against the amendment that has been put forward by Senator Cook. For example, if this is successful, what effect is it going to have on fuel for the bush? ACTU Solo might have a bit of an effect on fuel in some cities. But what effect is it going to have on fuel for the bush? What sort of mechanism can we look at to ensure that there is some sort of equal treatment, if you like, for people who are in the bush.

These are bigger questions, I know, than the ones that are dealt with in this particular bill. I support the measure and I support the amendment that was moved by Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. But I just raise those points. I am inclined to support Senator Cook's amendment in the absence of any very detailed opposition by the government. I am certainly prepared to support it through this chamber and see what happens when it gets to the other chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —My reasons for supporting Senator Cook's amendment have been spelt out in some detail in the second reading debate, but I think I should amplify in this respect: I am far less concerned about pricing than I am about the predatory control of the many by the few which exists at the moment in that industry. It is that predatory control which this amendment starts to affect and attack. It may indeed in some respects raise prices and not lower prices. I say that not universally but for the reasons that follow.

SPEECH.PARA: Oil companies make their profits upstream. They often make sure through transfer pricing that their profits are held and made elsewhere than Australia. In relation to those who are pressured in the secondary and tertiary sectors of this industry—in the wholesale and retail sectors—their profitability is often excessively squeezed. The effect of Senator Cook's amendment is likely to be felt most at the buying end and not at the selling end, in that those who buy for onward sale and for retail will be able to buy at better prices and will be able to shop around. But they will not always want to pass that on if their profitability—and this is the point Senator Margetts made, and made correctly—is such that it needs restoring.

The effects of predatory control are not always just on behaviour but on the state, the finances, the balance sheets and the cashflow of businesses. I think Senator Cook's amendment is very helpful in starting to reduce that predatory control and giving those businesses affected—and many of them are Australian businesses—more opportunity to operate freely in the market, and free markets are very much in your lexicon, Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp).

Having said that, I want to come back to some of the points that Senator Harradine made. You have said, Minister, that this issue has been sprung upon you. I do not know whether you used those exact words, but that was certainly your meaning. But all of us who are concerned with these issues are very well acquainted with the industry. There have been, as Senator Harradine has outlined, numerous reports, there has been much debate and each and every one of us has had visits and lobbying from all the various sectors in the primary, secondary and tertiary sectors of this industry. So, in that sense, you are not unaware of the issues—whilst you may not be aware of the detail of Senator Cook's amendment.

I am a little surprised by the vehemence and aggression, although couched in fairly courteous terms, with which the government wants to reject this. I am not sure how this change really undermines government reforms to the petroleum industry. It may in fact enhance and assist it by opening up the market. I think those are the points that Senator Cook and Senator Harradine have alluded to. So I think your reply needs to very clearly indicate to all of us exactly how this is going to make matters worse rather than better for the petroleum industry, because I think it is going to be a very critical answer that you are going to supply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it, Senator Murray, from your remarks that you are still wavering; is that right?
—No.
—You are not wavering. But you still want to hear what I have to say?
—Yes.

—That was not quite the impression you created. I doubt whether I have ever seen more confusion surrounding the outcome of an amendment as this debate has shown. Senator Cook, this bill has been around for some six months. The amendments were thrust on the chamber when the bill came forward, so there has been no proper consideration of the effect of these measures. I hope the independent senators will reflect on what an absurd process this is, and I will be outlining some of what we see as the flaws of the amendment, given the fact that we have had only a short time to look at them.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook supports competition policies. He believes that this will lead to cheaper prices. Senator Murray believes it could lead to higher prices, but he is still going to support the amendment. Senator Margetts is going to support the amendment, noting the argument from Senator Cook that it will lead to lower prices, but Senator Margetts wants higher prices. That was the point that Senator Margetts was making. Senator Harradine referred to some sort of historical perspective on this whole issue which, he correctly says, has been around for quite a long time.

The first thing I would put before the chamber, particularly to the Independent senators, is that the government was anxious to discuss all amendments. We were available to discuss all amendments. The amendments have been thrust on the chamber without any or proper consultation. There has been confusion surrounding the meaning of these amendments. Even those who are supporting the amendment moved by Senator Cook believe it will deliver separate outcomes or not deliver the outcomes that Senator Cook says that his amendment is designed to do.

The amendments are poorly drafted. Not only do people differ on the likely outcome of the objective, but also they are poorly drafted. For example, a declaration sets up only a right to negotiate. It does not give access to terminals with the transparent terminal gate process, which is what is needed for greater competition in the petroleum industry. It is arguable that the service provided by a petroleum terminal is the refining of crude oil. Hence, a service station owner would need to provide his own crude to be refined.

We have had these amendments. They have been thrust on us. They are designed purely for a short-term political purpose. We do not even think—on the advice that I have—that they will achieve the goal that Senator Cook sets out. Senator Margetts wants higher prices, not lower prices, but Senator Cook says that this will get lower prices. So I do not see, really, Senator Margetts—you may have a different amendment—how you could support an amendment which is strongly argued in favour of producing lower prices. Senator Harradine raised in this debate how this will deliver lower prices. I am intrigued to hear what the answer is because you have not, in your remarks, provided any figures at all. And no wonder, because it has all been done on the run.

I think that the amendments are poorly drafted. Our officials are still looking at them. They are poorly drafted for two of the reasons which I have put down there. The chamber does not accept—at least a significant proportion of the chamber does not seem to accept—that the amendments will achieve the very goal that they set out to achieve. To people who are wavering, Independent senators who may be interested in the arguments, let me say that the amendments are poorly drafted. They were brought into this chamber at the last moment and they were not available to be subjected to rigorous analysis before.

The bill has been out for a very long time. I think it would be very useful, in order to improve processes in this place, if the Labor Party could be encouraged to adopt a more constructive attitude to the way we debate bills so that there can be a proper debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a bit of a gap here between what I said and how it has been interpreted, so I will just put my points a little more clearly for the Assistant Treasurer. I gave a context in relation to why I was prepared to support the opposition's amendments. The context, quite clearly on the record, was that the prices of petroleum internationally and in Australia as well are artificially low. The reason I said that is that, apart from the ecological considerations, which are great, it will be in nobody's interest.

SPEECH.PARA: The ecological considerations about whether or not Australia in the end decides to pull its weight in the international arena to reduce greenhouse gas is one thing. The ecological considerations about the use of fossil fuels is another thing. It is in nobody's interest in the end if the price of such things as petroleum has been kept down artificially for so long that, by the time the price increases dramatically—this is the point that Senator Kemp seems to have missed—there will, according to the best brains internationally on petroleum, be substantial and massive increases in the next 10 years in petroleum.

It will do nobody any good, least of all industry, if we as a country and other countries around the world have not had the time to adjust to that change in the supply of petroleum. These figures include existing and prospective petroleum resources—Timor Gap, everything—and potential changes in technology.

I stepped back from the ecological argument a little and said that it will do nobody any good if international prices remain artificially low and then suddenly there is a big hike and we say, `Oh, we didn't know it was going to happen. We weren't prepared.' If we become very petroleum oriented and dependent, we as a country will suffer more than most. That was my point at the outset.

Now as to my comment, most people have personal knowledge of the impact of this very specific control over the petroleum industry that the big players have had for a long time. For some people, that has meant a lower price in terms of putting people out of business when they dared to try to become independent. For some people, it has meant higher prices when there were no choices and, unless government stepped in and tried to address that, often it has meant that the profitability of companies has held sway. As Senator Murray indicated as well, there is the ability of companies—in regard to whichever countries charge the most tax and whichever countries charge the least tax—to transfer pricing, which means that it may not be considered to be important in Australia to make as much as profit as it might be in another stage of their production. And it does not matter so much for a company whose production spans several countries. It is a global production, and they have control right down to the sale of milk and tea bags at the end of the process.

So the context was that people should understand clearly where I was coming from in general on petrol prices. It is my belief that probably the major effect of the opposition's amendment will be on the viability of small business. It is not just about price. It is about access, about people being able to access petroleum and about being able to access available sources. It is about communities being able to operate a little better than if they have only certain choices as to where they buy. I really do think it is about small business. It also obviously is about competition at that level and I think we will have to wait to see what the outcomes will be. As Senator Murray has indicated, it is some effort to address this situation. Nobody can pretend that this situation has not existed for a long time and I would like to see the government doing a little more about it than what it is doing at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I am not going to do you the discourtesy of reading you an economics lesson, but I would suggest that you are deliberately misinterpreting the statements made from the other side of the chamber for political purposes and, therefore, I must make sure that my point is clearly recorded. There is no confusion. The fact, as you will understand and as your advisers will understand, is that when you free up markets the participants in markets are then free to set their own pricing levels. The fact is that when they do so prices will go up as well as down and individual participants, if it is a genuinely free market, will not have common pricing. The fact is that you have to recognise that any change in freeing up a market can result in higher prices as well as lower prices. I do not know, and Senator Cook does not know, what the consequences will be when individuals are able to make their own decisions. Just in economic terms, straightforward practical empirical economics will tell you that a free market, or a freer market, will mean that prices can go up as well as down, especially if it is not a manipulated market. I do not think I can be clearer than that.

SPEECH.PARA: Minister, the second thing I want to say to you is that, for a horrible moment, I felt sorry for you because I could hear in your answer the inability to deliver a cogent and reasoned response to the question before you. That may be because you are not well enough briefed and it is not your field but what you have not addressed is whether the principle and the policy envisaged in this amendment are wrong. That is really what you have to tell us, and that was the question, as I understood it, that Senator Harradine was asking and that I was asking. Is the principle in the policy envisaged by Senator Cook's amendment wrong? Is it wrong on competition grounds? On community grounds? On what grounds? You have not answered that.

Your entire rebuttal focused on drafting. That could mean that you accept the principle or policy, but you just think it does not achieve its end through the amendment that has been put, that it is badly drafted. I put it to you that you have the opportunity, if this amendment is accepted by the Senate, of actually improving the amendment when it goes back to the House of Representatives. I am quite sure that, if the amendment comes through improved from the House of Representatives, the Senate will say, `That is terrific. You actually have met your own criticism.' So what I do say to you, Minister, is that you must address the principle and the policy as distinct from the drafting problems on which you may or may not have a good point—I do not know because I have not seen your alternative and you have not had time to produce one. Unless you can address the distinction between those two, you have a weak argument in rebuttal to the comments from this side of the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to take up the same point. The thing I have to say through you, Mr Chairman, to the Minister with the greatest of respect is that, in your reply, the arguments are the same as you put at the summing‐up of the second reading debate. The first argument—let me just deal with this again—is the question of whether the process has been as polite and as civil, and a recognition of the forms of procedure, as it should be. You have said that this has been dropped on you at the last minute, that you have not had time to consider it and that there is some defect in the drafting. I have been fairly generous in not replying to that, other than to say, `If it has inconvenienced you, I apologise for that.'

SPEECH.PARA: Let us just be a bit more realistic rather than employing the continuous politeness that sometimes masks some of the realities in this chamber. The government knows about this amendment, and it has known for some time. It had a private member's bill from Mark Latham, a member in the other place and the shadow minister for competition policy, put down on the 10th of this month. It has had notice of these amendments, if you like, that a bill was going to be proceeded with in the House on exactly the same criteria as you have before you. It is not as if the government did not know about this. Whether you knew about it directly, Minister, I do not know, and that is why I have been careful to be apologetic and reasonable from my side. But there is no argument that the government did not know about it, that the government would not have had a chance to consider it or that the government would not have had a chance to come to a view about it.

As far as the drafting argument is concerned, these amendments were lifted from a private member's bill that went through a drafting process. When you have got your back to the wall it is a reasonable argument to say that there are some problems with drafting, but you have to recognise that it has been through the drafting process. I do not accept that there are problems with the drafting.

Let me turn to the substance of it. I think the substance of it was fairly well summarised by the question just put to you by Senator Murray, so I should sit down, shut up and allow you to answer that question. I think these amendments will allow greater competition for petrol retailers with petrol terminals.

With the current situation we have, with what I might term the little `a' access plan that the government has—a plan where an oil company dictates to a particular distributor the terms and conditions by which it must draw from a particular terminal on a certain date—you could call these amendments the big `A' Access plan. The big `A' Access plan in these amendments provides a legal right for service stations and distributors to obtain petrol at commercially negotiated prices, terms and conditions that may be subject to ACCC assessment and determination.

It is the same principle of vertical separation and downstream access that the part IIIA regime has applied to electricity, gas, railway and telecommunications industries. Given the natural oligopoly features of petrol terminals and given the homogenous nature of petroleum products, the same principle should apply to the petroleum industry. That is my argument, but, Minister, I wait with bated breath to hear your reply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Not too bated, I trust, Senator Cook. I will bring some of these themes together. In relation to Senator Murray's contribution, the government's philosophy and policy to bring about reform in this sector were set out in the statement that was brought down some weeks ago. So I would not have thought that there was any question about our philosophy and our approach in this area. In fact, I think we have been exceedingly detailed. I do not want to go through that, but a major statement has been made.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say that, when people review this debate, they will find great ironies in it, Senator Murray. It is not our job to fix up the Labor Party's sloppy amendments. Your latest plea is that you cannot evaluate my argument because you have not had the time to look at it—that is essentially what you said. Well, join the club. No-one has time to deal with complex amendments in the way the Labor Party has handled this matter. Then Senator Murray said, `We will rely on your goodwill to get it fixed up.' That is an extraordinary way to run a debate.

Our philosophy and our approach are not in doubt. Major statements have been made. I have outlined two fundamental flaws with these amendments, which Senator Cook has not responded to. The reason he has not responded to them is because his advisers have not had a chance to consult with my advisers and to go through it in detail because the Labor Party did not give us the amendments last night. No government has been more accessible to discussion and negotiation with non-government parties in the Senate than this government.

The reality is that Senator Cook has been caught out and exposed attempting a political stunt with poorly drafted amendments. Senator Murray says, `Don't worry. Senator Kemp, you can go over and get it fixed up for him.' Thank you very much, Senator Murray, but we will not be picking up your invitation. It is not our job to fix up the sloppiness of the Labor Party.

Senator Murray, whenever you refer to me with such exquisite politeness, I always duck for cover. I think an examination of what you have said would show that the responses have been made. You asked me what initial problems we saw with the Labor Party proposals. I outlined two, but there may well be more as the advisers have a chance to go through them.

Senator Margetts, I think I was very fair in my comments to you. I have to say that I am in utter confusion about your approach to this whole matter. You are opposed to competition policy. You believe that this will induce greater competition. So you seem to be riding against your own approach. You want higher petrol prices, not lower petrol prices, and these amendments, according to Senator Cook, will produce lower petrol prices. I just do not understand, Senator. I do not want to have a debate with you about it. I have written you letters, but I have to tell you that I do not understand your approach. It seems to me that there is utter confusion about your philosophy and your policy.

I have outlined—and I will not go through them again unless people want me to—that these amendments will not even deliver what Senator Cook thinks they will deliver. Senator Murray says, `We can't evaluate your arguments, Senator Kemp, because we have not had time to see them.' That is not my fault; that is their fault.

If we are after proper processes in this chamber, those who are wavering should teach Senator Cook a lesson this time for coming into the chamber and proposing major policy initiatives and amendments to bills which have nothing to do with the substance of the bill—that is what he has done. He has got egg over his face over the petrol pricing issue over Christmas.
Senator Conroy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Conroy, don't provoke me. He is trying to recover some ground by coming in with very poorly drafted amendments. I urge the Senate to oppose these amendments moved by the Labor Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I do understand that the minister is confused about where the Greens (WA) stand in relation to competition policy. He has not understood for a long time. I would like to make it clear that monopolies and oligopolies are not necessarily in the public interest. I have always—consistently, right down the line—stood up on the basis of public interest. Have a look in the Hansard at the debates that we have had before to see that that is what I have stood for.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that governments have a very important role to play in assuring that the public interest is maintained. Giving over important industries to oligopolies is not in the public interest. Giving over important industries to monopolies is not in the public interest. That is where I stand. That is where I have stood all along. Have a look back over the last three years and more; that is where I stand.

As I say, I know that the government have trouble understanding that. How they can equate public interest or benefit to the community with the ability of one industry to have a stranglehold on outlets is beyond me. I have always stood up not in terms of the market but for what the community will or will not benefit from in relation to the outcomes of what governments do with their economic policy. As I say, if you do not understand that, I understand that you do not understand that, and I really hope that something will happen in the meantime to enable the penny to drop as to where we stand and why.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage, for the purpose of its passage through this chamber at this moment, I am supporting Senator Cook's amendments. But I put to the government for their con sideration that, in respect of essential supply, fuel is in competition with gas and electricity. So why one and not the other? Why have an access code for one and not the other? That is the question that needs to be asked and considered. After all, access codes are designed to require, by law, companies or individuals to make available their property to others on terms which the owners may not like.

SPEECH.PARA: The result of all this may well be that somebody might take it to the High Court in an action under section 51(31). Somebody might just do that. It may well be that the oil companies do that. They have been before the High Court before today. It may well be that they take a particular case to the High Court on the basis of unjust acquisition under 51(31). Then, of course, the whole issue will be under consideration and the whole philosophy will be up for grabs.

I know that we are treading in a minefield. Some in the parliament, I believe, do not feel that way, but I think we are treading in a bit of a minefield. Nevertheless, on the basis of what has been said, I am prepared, in short, to support the amendments here and now. If the government has further and better particulars at a later date, they can be dealt with—I do not think they need to be dealt with at great length before this chamber. I do not care what anybody else is doing, but I am supporting the amendments.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Cook's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Schacht did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza)

SPEECH.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice that on the running sheet it says, `Schedule 1—GWA—(1) to (6), by leave, together'. I might refrain from asking leave for the moment to move my amendments because there has been an indication from Senator Murray from the Australian Democrats that there are parts of my amendments which the Democrats would be able to support and other parts which they would not. I will speak to my amendments and then perhaps we can organise how we might progress to the vote.
—You can speak to amendments Nos 1 to 6 and we will see how we go.

—Our amendments deal with the matter of public interest considerations in this bill. We are concerned that public interest is not defined broadly enough. It has been interesting that Senator Kemp has talked about the narrowing of public interest definitions when in fact it is our consideration that under competition policy public interest has been narrowed very much indeed. The bill mistakenly equates increased competition with public interest. Senator Kemp, I know, has a different spin on that. I know he has written me a letter but the fact that he has written me a letter does not mean he has yet convinced me.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has got the cart before the horse when it comes to the relationship between competition and public interest with regard to network industries. For the government, increasing competition in markets such as electricity and gas seems to be the overriding policy objective with the public interest being only one factor to be considered while pursuing this. A statement in the National Competition Council's paper Considering the public interest under the national competition policy accurately sums up this attitude. It states:
The aim of this paper is to point to those processes by which public interest matters can be considered within the national competition policy agenda.
So the agenda is first. Public interest fits in there somewhere but I think it gets very much a lesser guernsey than anything else, certainly in terms of competition.

In contrast, we believe that the public interest or public benefit should be central to the formation of government policy. Otherwise, why would we be doing that? We assume we are moving towards public interest but, if it is not central, why the heck are we doing it? In the formation of public policy with regard to network industries, competition should be considered within that context. If increased competition or the opening of markets to competition is shown to be in the public interest, then so be it, but we should not be assuming that this will always be the case. I hope Senator Kemp is listening to this, because it will explain why we take particular positions on things like oligopoly and monopolies.

If the workings of markets are in the public interest, then we are in there batting. But, if they are not, then we are in there fighting that governments have a role to play—and we will always believe so. Of course, this opens a fundamental divide between us and the government. The government's policy on this and most others is premised on an ideological assumption that competition actually equals public benefit. This is explicitly stated in the section of this bill which deals with public interest considerations. Paragraph 44ZZAA(3) states that, when the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission decides if they will approve a network industry code, they must consider:
the public interest, including the public interest in having competition in markets (whether or not in Australia).
Yet the opposite can be true. Competition can be contrary to the public interest. Indeed, in a letter to me on this bill, the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) said:

The public interest tests contained in the Trade Practices Act 1974 and the Intergovernmental Competition Principles Agreement recognise that vigorous competition is not an end in itself and may not always be in the public interest.
See, we do read your letters, Senator Kemp.

Why then does the government's bill state so clearly that it is. Why is it that the only specific example of public interest mentioned in the bill is the public interest in having competition in markets? Accordingly, we believe that this bill must have a more detailed definition or a broader definition of the public interest than is currently the case. We should like to see other considerations, such as the environmental and social equity considerations, given greater weight. Yes, competition may sometimes be in the public interest, but it should not be taken as a given and should not subsume other important decisions.

We also are aware that the word `environmental' is in competition policy; we do know that. But, if you look further—which is what Senator Kemp seems to have failed to do—it says `in terms of whatever the government's policy is on environment in relation to this issue'. There is not one. Trade and competition override the environment so, if the government does not have a policy which says you must take ecological considerations as being important then, in reality, it is a circular argument. It is a circular argument when you finally get to the last point and you find that there is nothing that says ecological or equity considerations ought to be considered as important. Who does it? How do you do it? If it is not government policy, it does not actually get a guernsey.

Communities are asking that these other issues be taken into consideration. They need to have an assurance that they will be at least taken into consideration. Unfortunately, with the circular nature of competition policy and the way the ACCC is set up, there is very little they can take into consideration. I really do not see that there is a particular mechanism by which they can do so given the way things currently are. In our amendment we expand the concept of public interest. Paragraph 44ZZA(3)(b) will read:

the public interest, including the public interest in having access to the full range of relevant goods and services to be provided at least cost in ways which are efficient, ecologically sustainable, equitable and consistent with community wants and needs, irrespective of location;
I would wonder at any government or any major party which thinks that we should be promoting or saying that by law ecological sustainability should not be taken into consideration.

Are we saying that, no matter what happens, industry should be given free access to develop such things as electricity, water and so on, without taking into consideration ecological sustainability? If the problem is actually putting in the words `ecological sustainability', I want to know why. What is the problem with actually putting that in as part of what must be considered in the public interest without regard to geographical location?

Basically, we are not narrowing the definition; we are broadening it. Those people who would like that clarified should look at how narrow it is within the competition policy. We are certainly being consistent in saying the definition should be broadened. It should give some certainty—the word is very popular—to the community that these issues will be taken into consideration. If they are not, why the heck not?

In terms of moving the amendments, I am happy to be guided by the Senate as to how they should be moved. I believe that the Australian Democrats cannot agree with the new section (ba). I believe they are happy to support amendment 4, minus (ba) in that section—the relevant public interest standards relating to the industry. I respectfully suggest that we might be able to deal with those sections separately. The rest could be voted on together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest you move 1, 3, 5 and 6 together and then 2 and 4 together.
—If I can clarify that: there are parts of 2 and 4 which need to be separated as well.
—Those will have to be moved by the Australian Democrats as amendments to your amendments. So 1, 3, 5 and 6, and then 2 and 4.
—And 2 and 4 separately.
—Two and 4 individually, yes. It has been suggested that we have 1, 3, 5 and 6, then 2, then 4.
—I therefore seek leave to move amendments 1, 3, 5 and 6 together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, item 1, page 3 (after line 6), after the definition of access code , insert:
Public Interest Standards means the standards referred to in section 44ZZAB.
(3) Schedule 1, page 3 (after line 10), after item 2, insert:
Add "and public interest standards relating to the industry as a whole have been presented to the Commission by the relevant State or Territory Minister".
(5) Schedule 1, item 4, page 4 (line 12), at the end of subsection (4), add:

PARA.TAB: ; and (c) a public interest standard relating to the industry has been presented to the Commission by the relevant State or Territory Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Schedule 1, page 4 (after line 27), after item 4, insert:
Insert:

(1) A person who is, or who expects to be, the provider of a service must provide to the Commission a set of Public Interest Standards, setting out details of the principles, goals and conditions that represent appropriate standards to protect and promote the public interest.

(2) Public Interest Standards should apply in principle to the whole of a service to which application for access is being made, rather than in relation to the provision of that service by a specific provider.
(3) The Commission must not accept standards unless the Commission has first ensured that the process by which the standards were developed complied with subsection (4).
(4) The formulation of Public Interest Standards must include the following steps:

PARA.TAB: (a) the relevant State, Territory or Commonwealth Minister must appoint a Public Interest Committee comprising representatives from each of the following groups:

(ii) non‐government environment, consumer protection and social justice groups;

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

SPEECH.PARA: (b) the public interest, including the public interest in having access to the full range of relevant goods and services to be provided at least cost in ways which are efficient, ecologically sustainable . . .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

SPEECH.PARA: Under amendments (1), (3), (5) and (6) moved by the Greens, it would be necessary to establish a public interest committee to develop standards which would be taken into account by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission when assessing undertakings. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the opposition, I would like to indicate that we support the Sex Discrimination Amendment Bill. We would like to put on record a number of comments about this amending bill. The bill is designed to implement the recommendations of a review conducted by the Attorney-General pursuant to section 40A of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 of the operation of subsections 40(2) and 40(3) of the act. The review was completed by the Attorney-General on 31 May 1996.

SPEECH.PARA: The requirement to conduct a review pursuant to section 40A of the act was inserted by way of an amendment moved by the Australian Democrats to the Sex Discrimination Amendment Bill 1991, an amendment which I am pleased to say received bipartisan support.

Subsections 40(2) and 40(3) contain exemptions to the act. The bill narrows the scope of a number of those exemptions. Consistent with the Labor Party's support for the procedure requiring the conduct of a review pursuant to section 40A of the act and in terms of the substance of the recommendations made by that review, the Labor Party supports this bill.

I do not propose to discuss the amendments in detail as I note that they have been comprehensively covered in the second reading speech delivered by the Minister representing the Attorney-General, Senator Vanstone. However, the bill has been introduced at same time as the parliament has been considering the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996.

The Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Chris Sidoti, set out HREOC's concerns in relation to the bill as they relate to sex discrimination. He stated during the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Legislation Committee's consideration of the bill on 28 November 1996:

BREAK.PARA: The first part of schedule 3 would propose the insertion of a section 507(a) into the Migration Act. The insertion of this paragraph (a) would permit differentiation between applicants for immigration on the basis of de facto or de jure marital status. The commission is most concerned that the introduction of this kind of discrimination represents a significant retreat from the commitment made in the enactment of the Sex Discrimination Act and there should be no discrimination on the basis of marital status.

Australian law has dealt for some time with the criteria for the acceptance of the existence of a genuine de facto relationship. That criteria has been spelt out most particularly in social security law, but it has also been enacted in the past and developed in the past in relation to immigration law.

The introduction of a period of relationship test, as proposed in paragraph (a) of the proposed section 507, is a significant retreat from the banning of discrimination on the basis of marital status and introduces a much harsher test for those claiming on the basis of a de facto relationship than those claiming on the basis of a de jure relationship. The commission recommends strongly to the committee that the introduction of that new test and this form of discrimination be removed from the amending bill, and that the existing form of testing of the genuineness of a de facto relationship be continued.

The commission is also gravely concerned at the proposal to enact paragraph (b) of section 507. Paragraph (b) would have the effect of introducing a much wider exemption into the Migration Act than paragraph (a) would introduce. It represents, for the first time since the enactment of the Sex Discrimination Act in 1984, the provision of an exemption relating to the implementation and administration of Commonwealth laws and programs. The banning of that form of discrimination is found in section 26 of the Sex Discrimination Act. As I have indicated, there has not in the past been any exemption or exception whatsoever from the unlawful nature of conduct covered by section 26 of the Sex Discrimination Act.

Paragraph (b) of the proposed section 507 would allow any form of discrimination in the administration of programs, so long as the program itself is within the law. That would mean, for example, on our reading of the paragraph, that immigration officials, in seeking to apply regulations concerning marital status, could discriminate generally against people on the basis of their de facto relationship, whether or not that discrimination was required by section 507(a) or by the regulations. It has the potential to provide a very sweeping exemption for the immigration department's officials and one which we consider unacceptable. Even if 507(a) were enacted, which we have recommended against, 507(b) remains unnecessary and particular ly undesirable because of the greater breadth of exemption that it would provide.

On the basis of the matters advanced by Mr Sidoti, it is easy to see the government's hypocrisy on the issue of sex discrimination. The government cannot, through the introduction of this bill, claim to be fulfilling its obligations to eliminate sexual discrimination yet at the same time legislate in a way contrary to the principles underlying the legislation. The government should bear in mind that, even if it is successful in imposing this provision on the Australian people, it will rightly be subject to criticism from international fora for failing to live up to its fundamental human rights obligations.

The fate of proposed section 507 as contained in the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996 is a matter which obviously will be resolved when the bill is considered. I urge the government to reconsider that provision and, failing that, encourage all non-government senators to support the relevant amendments to be moved by the Labor Party at the committee stage of the bill's consideration. Otherwise I encourage all senators to support the Sex Discrimination Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sex Discrimination Amendment Bill is a direct result of an amendment in 1991 by former Leader of the Australian Democrats Senator Janet Powell. Section 40A was successfully inserted by the Australian Democrats in the context of the Sex Discrimination Amendment Bill 1991, which sought to halt the regime by which exemptions to the SDA for Commonwealth legislation were implemented by regulation. In place of this regulatory regime a range of Commonwealth legislation was to be given permanent exemption from the act, most significantly legislation relating to taxation and social security.

SPEECH.PARA: During consideration of the 1991 bill by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, Senator Spindler stated the Democrats would move an amendment to the effect of section 40A. This amendment had been foreshadowed by Senator Powell during the second reading debate and was accepted by the committee. Although the intention of the amendment seems to be as a general watchdog clause, Senator Powell specifically noted that `it seems to me that an indefinite exemption is inappropriate in the case of the tax and social security departments'. The bill implements the recommendations of the Attorney-General's review of the permanent exemptions in subsections 40(2) and 40(3) conducted pursuant to section 40A and tabled on 26 June 1996.

The framework for the bill is expressed to reflect the government's supposed `commitment to equal opportunity and the prevention of discrimination', as indicated by this bill's second reading speech. Both the second reading speech and the explanatory memorandum state that the bill is consistent with and an indication of the government's policy that exemptions to the SDA should be limited and that where possible all federal legislation should be consistent with the SDA's objectives.

The amendments in the bill are not controversial, primarily because of their limited nature. But the amendments in relation to taxation legislation, the Norfolk Island Social Services Act 1980 and the Papua New Guinea (Members of the Forces Benefits) Act 1957, merely reflect the status quo. Therefore, although the exemptions are either narrowed—that is, in taxation the exemption is narrowed from a general exemption to an exemption from the SDA in terms of marital discrimination—or repealed, these actions reflect the existing types of discrimination relevant to that legislation. Therefore, no positive steps have been taken to ameliorate discrimination in these areas.

In relation to the sunsetting of the exemption for certain definitions in the National Health Act 1953, again this is not a positive step in itself to rectify discrimination. Rather, it is a necessary amendment to ensure that the SDA reflects the phasing out of sex differentiated access to age pensions.

Some other limitations with this bill need to be pointed out. The bill does not amend the exemption currently provided in the SDA for anything done in direct compliance with the Social Security Act 1947. There are apparent ly a couple of reasons for this. The first is the unclear legal status of the exemption given that the Social Security Act 1947 no longer exists and was repealed by the Social Security Act 1991. Secondly, there are complex issues concerning `in principle' discrimination in the social security regime, particularly in relation to marital status discrimination, which are raised in the report of the steering committee assisting the Attorney-General in his review of this exemption. The review defers the legislative response to the social security exemption and states that the Attorney and the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman, will report back to the parliament before 26 June 1997 as to the status of the exemption and the issues raised in the steering committee's report.

Another matter which needs to be considered is the review of marital status discrimination in social security. As the exemption for social security was one of the issues which Senator Powell specifically mentioned as inappropriate for an indefinite exemption when proposing section 40A, it is interesting to note that the process by which consideration of this issue has proceeded.

The Senate committee's report states that most discrimination in the social security regime is based on `assumptions of dependency', which generally invoke discrimination on the grounds of marital status. While analysing these provisions, the steering committee's report recognises that discriminatory assumptions of dependency are not limited to the social security regime but are intertwined into areas such as superannuation, taxation and the payment of student assistance. Accordingly, the report recommends that, with the aim of ameliorating discrimination on the grounds of marital status, it would be productive if a general review of policy and laws based on assumptions of dependency were undertaken.

In light of this recommendation by the steering committee, the Institute of Public Administration of Australia and the Australian Institute of Administrative Law held a one-day seminar on 16 September 1996 to tease out the issues relating to assumptions of dependency which arose in all government portfolios. A wide range of Commonwealth departments attended the seminar and identified discriminatory aspects of government programs. It was indicated at this seminar that these issues would be raised with the Minister for Social Security.

I understand that the minister has decided that the review of in principle discrimination identified in the steering committee's report will only relate to issues arising in the social security regime and will not be linked to other laws and programs. If this is the case, it is rather a curious outcome, given that the identification of in principle discrimination was the subject of the steering committee's report. Such a review would appear to be a duplication of research in a climate of scarce or dwindling resources.

We should note that, as part of the government's legislative agendas, other exemptions to the SDA are currently being sought, for example temporary exemption for Austudy and Abstudy. Currently, Abstudy and Austudy discriminate on the grounds of marital status in that the schemes differentiate between legally married and de facto couples. If one is legally married and a student one can apply for independent Austudy—of course subject to a means test—whereas this is prohibited if one is in a de facto relationship.

The exemption for student assistance from the SDA has always existed in various forms, either within legislation such as subsection 40(4) which expired in 1994, or through administrative exemptions provided by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in accordance with section 44 of the SDA. Section 44 exemptions are specifically temporary exemptions designed to provide temporary protection for a situation whilst the discrimination is fixed.

HREOC has just provided a further exemption for Austudy and Abstudy for 1996 under the notice of the grant of exemption. The notice of the grant of exemption links the exemption for student assistance to the review on notions of dependency and states that the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) has given an undertaking that a report will be made to the commission prior to the expiry of the exemption on long‐term solutions to marital status discrimination in current and future student assistance schemes, which take into account the review outcomes.

Two things are interesting to note with this temporary exemption. Firstly, the fact that once again a temporary exemption has been sought and granted, given that the raison d'etre of a temporary exemption is to provide a space so that the discrimination exempted can be stopped. The notice of exemption does not detail any steps that DEETYA has taken to find a solution to discrimination in Austudy, except in so far as it is linked to the dependency review. Secondly, a central problem with temporary exemptions is that they are not noted in legislation and are not easily available on public record, in fact they are gazetted. They have the effect of permitting ongoing discrimination to remain hidden in a sense.

It should also be noted that at the same time as this bill is in the Senate, the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) is being debated. This bill proposes an exemption for the Migration Act from the SDA in relation to the making of regulations which specify the incidents of a relationship required to establish a de facto relationship. This therefore potentially permits regulations to be made discriminating on the grounds of marital status and is specifically aimed at ensuring that regulations can be made which impose a two-year cohabitation period on a de facto couple before they can apply as a couple under the Migration Act, and of course that was an election promise.

The second reading speech for that bill states that this measure will relieve the mischief of bogus and short‐term relationships, a statement which suggests that de jure married couples are less likely to have short‐term or bogus relationships. It is precisely these assumptions that prohibition of discrimination on the ground of marital status is aimed at stopping. Of course I will comment further on this when that particular bill comes to the chamber.

Professor Margaret Thornton, an Australian expert on anti-discrimination laws, has noted that although anti-discrimination law represents a halting step towards the formal recognition of inequality, it nevertheless `is riddled with weaknesses in respect of both substance and procedure'. She considers that a key weakness in relation to federal sex discrimination law is the numerous exemptions and exceptions to the act. In relation to 40(2) and (3) specifically, Professor Thornton notes that:

. . . the exception accorded acts done under statutory authority has been potentially one of the most devastating. . . the usual principle of statutory construction in which the most recent enactment overrules the former, has been waived in some legislation. The subordinate status of anti-discrimination legislation reveals quite unequivocally that certain legislatures did not intend that their anti-discrimination legislation should be taken as seriously as other legislation.

The government is presenting the bill as a sign of its commitment to anti-discrimination principles and to narrowing exemptions. The narrowed exemptions are not positive measures to actively narrow current discrimination, but reflect the status quo. At the same time other exemptions in other legislation to the SDA are being introduced.

The final word must surely come from Ms Sue Walpole, the federal Sex Discrimination Commissioner who recently criticised the federal government for creating a policy vacuum on women's issues. Since the election the commissioner has come under considerable criticism from this government with the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, describing her as a Labor stooge and the Attorney-General, Mr Williams, describing her as biased simply because the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission funded a report on flexible working hours. The report was jointly launched by the commissioner and ACTU President, Jennie George. I suggest that it is beneath both the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General of this country to seek to implement the politics of division over such an issue as discrimination. Australian women will not be used as political footballs by those particular men, or any men in this country, regardless of what office they hold.

I would like to take this opportunity to thank Commissioner Walpole for her tenacious pursuit of women's issues throughout her time as the commissioner. She has made a valuable contribution to the human rights landscape in this country and in my view has never shrunk from what is an inalienable truth, that is, that women's rights are human rights and when they are being breached, ignored or in this case neglected, then this entire nation is diminished by that fact.
Debate (on motion by Senator Campbell) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling on questions, I wish to make a statement about question time. I think all senators would be aware that the issue of the allocation of questions during question time has been under consideration for some time and has been discussed at length outside the chamber by the parties and the Independent senators. I am advised and can now confirm that the current arrangements will continue on a permanent basis.

SPEECH.PARA: These arrangements provide that in the first 12 questions of any day the opposition will be allocated six questions, the government three, the Australian Democrats two and the Greens and Independent senators one between them. The questions allocated to the Australian Democrats will be Nos 6 and 12 and the question allocated to the Greens or Independent senators will be No. 8. If, on any day, question 12 is not reached, then on the next sitting day the Australian Democrats will be allocated question No. 10 and the government question No. 12. Questions beyond 12 will be allocated on the basis of odd numbers to the opposition and even numbers to the government. I understand that information containing these details has been circulated.

It is of course the prerogative of the President to call senators to speak at any time, but it has become a convention of the Senate that speakers lists are used on a number of occasions and this and other conventions are appropriate for the more smooth running of the Senate and for the more efficient use of our time. On this agreement with question time, for the same reasons I am happy to acknowledge its existence.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I seek leave to make a statement relating to government business.

—I want to remind the Senate that Senator Woods resigned on 3 February as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services. —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs.
