Why, Minister, did you deliberately omit the one portion of this letter that was embarrassing to yourself and your colleague by taking the extraordinary step—and it was—of ending your quote in mid‐sentence and then jumping to the final paragraph?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, they showed that they were a second-rate government and they are showing that they are a third-rate opposition. If these are the issues that concern the opposition, I am pleased; because they are not the issues that the people out in the real world are worried about. There is a very simple explanation which the opposition would not recognise.
—You misled the Senate; that's what you did.
—I did not mislead the Senate. There is a very simple explanation.
—Have a look at the Hansard .
—It is called propriety.
—Ha, ha!

—They laugh, Madam President. They do not know what it means. I was reading out a personal letter to Ms Gabi Hollows which involved a colleague and, as I was halfway through and got to that sentence, I thought, `I haven't told Mr Sharp that I am doing this; I haven't told Ms Hollows.'

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections on my left.

—I would like to clarify it so that even those on the other side might understand what occurred. I will speak slowly and I will speak quietly, because they bring out the worst in me, I must say. The first point that needs to be made is that my letter did not involve a job offer to Gabi Hollows; it did not involve that. My letter was an invitation to, and I quote again from the letter, `discuss with you'—Ms Hollows—`the ways in which you would contribute through an appointment to one of the organisations under my ministerial responsibility'. That is in the letter. On that single point the entire attack by the opposition is exposed for the baseless and insulting sham that it is. It is a muckraking exercise of the worst possible kind because it drags Gabi Hollows and the Fred Hollows Foundation into what is a low and offensive political stunt.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You bring no honour to the profession of politics; you bring no honour.
—Ha, ha!
—They laugh.
—You sanctimonious twit!

—For the benefit of honourable senators, I will read my full involvement. John Sharp phoned me in late March or early April last year. I did not keep a record of the conversation, but in essence he indicated that he had been talking to Gabi Hollows and it was clear that she had a great deal of expertise in Aboriginal health. He also indicated that he thought she might resign from the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Bob Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins, you can follow this up with a supplementary question, if you wish.

—He indicated that he would have no objections to that resignation, which would hardly be news to anyone as he had publicly stated that he wanted to replace the board. I said that I would be very interested in having Ms Hollows involved in my portfolio because of her expertise.

ANSWER.PARA: On the afternoon of 6 May, my office received a phone call from the Deputy Prime Minister's office to say that Gabi Hollows was there if I wanted to see here. I would like you to listen to what I say next. I have subsequently learned from Mr Fischer's office that Ms Hollows asked Mr Fischer's staff if they could arrange that meeting with me. Ms Hollows asked if they could arrange that meeting with me. Where is the noise now?

I had a short meeting with her, at which I indicated that I would be interested in her being involved in my portfolio. I got the impression she might be interested. I told her that I would be in touch with her about it. I returned to my office and confirmed in writing my invitation to discuss the possibility of using her expertise in my portfolio. Someone from my office then took my letter to Mr Fischer's office from Ms Hollows. What happened after that, I have no idea.

I have not received a response from Ms Hollows. I have not discussed it with her since. You have raised the question of why I referred to Ms Hollows's possible resignation from the board, obviously because Minister Sharp had informed me that he believed Ms Hollows intended to resign. There is nothing more I can add because there is nothing more to add.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, that explanation was in fact effectively what you said this morning on the Pru Goward program. Is it a fact that you said on the Pru Goward program this morning:

QUESTION.PARA: I started reading the letter and then I thought gee, I haven't checked with Mrs Hollows, one, for her permission for me to read it out, and then I hadn't spoken to John Sharp. . . . And I thought gee, you shouldn't read private letters out unless you've got permission. So I thought gee, I better stop here . . .

Minister, doesn't the fact that you read the whole letter into the Hansard , including the last paragraph, and only omitted the one small section—three lines that embarrassed you and your colleague—make that explanation transparently false?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Gee, Madam President. Gee—that is a word that I use when I am talking to people; the real people out there in the community, not when I am talking to people like the rabble on the other side.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I do use that word in my conversation, and I do not resile from it. It is an expression of mine. Yes, I did. I was interrupted, if you remember. With the racket from the rabble that was going on, it is a wonder that I was able to read any part of the letter, that I was able to get any bits of it out. But with the yelling and the sledging that occurs on the other side, many in the gallery cannot even hear. You do no honour to politics with the way you are performing.

ANSWER.PARA: I have said all. I have been consistent in everything that I have said.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you bring the letter into the chamber?

—I have laid it on the table. In fact, last night I faxed Ms Hollows and disclosed to her that that letter would be revealed. Then I fulfilled my obligation. But you would not understand propriety on that side. You just would not have a clue. None of you have ever practised it. You want to talk about the appointments that you made throughout your 13 years of government! I would still welcome Ms Hollows and the Fred Hollows Foundation to be associated with my portfolio. (Time expired)

—My question without notice is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, last month when you announced that youth unemployment rose, the Labor Party almost rejoiced in its efforts to make cheap political capital out of the misfortune of young people. Today, when it was announced that it had fallen, their churlish response again showed how out of touch they are with the Australian community. Minister, can you please explain the government's approach to the obvious volatility of these figures and its policies to attack the structural causes of unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Tierney for his question. He is quite right in asserting that last month, when seasonally adjusted youth unemployment went up, some in this chamber on the other side in the Labor Party and even the Australian Democrats chose to try to make some cheap political capital out of the misfortune of young Australians.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that after 13 years of Labor we have been left by Labor with a seriously ingrained stain of unemployment on the economy. It is a fact they do not want to admit. They somehow think that this problem of unemployment arrived the day after they were kicked out of power. They accept no responsibility for the stain on the employment area that they created and the stain on the economy that they left. They had no ideas how to fix it. That is why they were rejected by the Australian people.

Of course anybody who comments regularly on unemployment figures knows full well that the seasonally adjusted figures are very volatile. They will go up in some months and down in others. I have consistently said when we do the unemployment statistics—the labour force statistics—each month that the seasonally adjusted figures are of some interest. Of course they are.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a trend line—are you going to admit that?
—But what is important to keep your eye on is the trend line.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senators opposite laugh. I do not know why they would laugh at that, because unemployment remained consistently high when you were in government. You people had 10 per cent for nearly three years. You had 32 consecutive months of unemployment at its highest level since World War II. So you are in no position to laugh or giggle at this disgusting problem that you left with the Australian community.

ANSWER.PARA: As Senator Tierney rightly says, it has fallen to 27.3 per cent this month. But that is seasonally adjusted, and we cannot take too much glee from seasonally adjusted figures. Nonetheless, I think it is important to recognise that with this ingrained stain of unemployment left on the economy, there is no Dynamo fix. There is no single policy that you can put a little on the stain and the rest in the wash, because it simply will not work like that.

We have now been left with structural ingrained unemployment, and it is going to take very consistent work by the government to get policies through this chamber—with reluctance from people opposite—to remedy and break down this problem. The coalition has produced lower interest rates through a balanced budget and low inflation. That makes a big difference. We are making workplace arrangements more flexible and revitalising apprenticeships and traineeships.

The apprenticeships we had last year were the same as we had 10 years ago—what a disgrace! That is what sort of contribution you people made to getting young people into jobs. You kept the apprenticeship levels the same as they were 10 years before. You are in no position to comment. We want to give school students the skills that employers want, and we want to provide individually tailored labour market assistance to the unemployed.

BREAK.PARA: We are now seeing a labour market that is gathering strength. Trend employment has increased every month since April 1996, just one month after we were elected. Since we were elected there have been 160,000 new jobs and, if you take into account the telephone polling changes undertaken by the ABS, that may be increased by a further 40,000 or 50,000 jobs. Employment this year is growing at around three per cent. The bottom line is that those opposite created the mess; they laugh about it, they try to make political capital out of the mess they left this country in. This government has the plans to fix the problem, but it is such a serious, ingrained stain on the economy that it is going to take some time to fix the mess that you people created. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Minister, when did you discuss with Mr Sharp the possibility of Ms Hollows being appointed to a position within your portfolio area? Did you discuss the proposal with any other ministers or their staff? When and why did you ask the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Fischer, to deliver your letter of 6 May, and why was the letter hand‐delivered to Ms Hollows at a meeting in the Prime Minister's office?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you should ask the Deputy Prime Minister, because, as I said, the letter was prepared in my office, I said, `Would you send that off to Ms Hollows—
—Did you sign it?

—I signed it, yes, and off it went. What happened to it after that I have not the faintest idea. I do not know what happened to it. That was 9 May, and it surfaced in February. I have not the faintest idea what happened to it between then and now. Does he seriously suggest that, after I have handed it to the staff to have it delivered, I should cart it around and hand it over, go and see the Deputy Prime Minister of the country and say, `Will you deliver this to Ms Hollows?' The real issues are the employment rate, the unemployment rate, the problems of the family, the problems of small business—they are the real issues, rather than this—

—I raise a point of order, Madam President. I asked Senator Herron a four‐part question: when he discussed with Mr Sharp the possibility of Ms Hollows being appointed to a position in his portfolio area; whether he discussed that proposal with other ministers or their staff; when and why he asked the Deputy Prime Minister to deliver the letter; and why the letter was hand‐delivered. He has had a stab at the third and fourth questions, a vague stab at them, but I do ask, Madam President, on a very serious matter going right to the issue of Senator Herron's ministerial accountability, that you demand that he answer these questions.

—On the point of order, I thought at least the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate had the wit to hear what I said in the answer to his question. There is no point of order, because I had already answered the first part of the question in my previous answer.

—Order! There were four parts to the question; you have undoubtedly dealt with some of them and you may have nothing further to say on the others. You had strayed a fraction beyond the question asked. You should apply yourself to the question. If there is anything further to add, you may do so.
—The surrogate leader of the opposition sitting up in the back seat has given instructions down here to the monkey at the front to ask a question—
—I ask you to withdraw that.

—I withdraw, Madam President. I had covered the answer to the first question in the sense that I said that John Sharp phoned me in late March or early April last year. I did not keep a record of the conversation—
—I wouldn't have either, if I was you.

—They were not listening because there was a rabble and so much calling out, particularly by the leader of the opposition in the back seat there. In essence Mr Sharp indicated that he had been talking to Gabi Hollows and it was clear she had a great deal of expertise. That is when the circumstance arose, and I said I would be delighted to have her aboard—in fact I had had it in mind for some time. I would be delighted to have her aboard because I had had dealings with her previously and her executive director of the Fred Hollows Foundation in relation to assisting them in a lens factory—in Pakistan, I think it was. I think she would be an adornment to my portfolio responsibilities—
—Adornment!
—Because of her high standing in the community—
—A bauble, in other words.

—You can use another word. But I think it would be great to have her, and I still would, as I say, so I do not resile from that at all. I would like to have the Fred Hollows Foundation associated with Aboriginal health. As I said yesterday, I knew Fred. He did all his work in the Aboriginal community, and it would be great to have my portfolio associated with the Fred Hollows Foundation. I see no difficulty about that at all. I probably intimated that to her in the conversation I had with her in that meeting in the Deputy Prime Minister's office, where I think from memory now she was talking to him about AusAID and aid for the lens factory and so on.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Sherry interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It came up in conversation, Senator Sherry, when I was talking with her. You can scoff, but that is the truth.

—I wanted her associated with my portfolio, Senator Collins, and I still do. I would still love to have her and the foundation associated with my portfolio. This grubby exercise of dragging the foundation and dragging Gabi Hollows through the mud I think is appalling. I just do not think it does any honour to the opposition or the Senate itself that a matter of this nature should be dragged up into the political arena, because you are dragging her and the foundation through the mud, and you really should have thought that through before you took on this crass political exercise.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Herron, did you discuss this proposal with any other ministers or their staff? Will you come back to the Senate and tell us precisely when you did discuss this issue with Mr Sharp? I also ask why you had a letter on your ministerial letterhead hand delivered in the Prime Minister's office by the Deputy Prime Minister? Was it because the Prime Minister was unable to attend the meeting? Finally, Minister, is it not true that Ms Hollows is appalled by the standover tactics of you and Mr Sharp?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition just showed his—I will not say `stupidity' because I might be made to withdraw it. He said now that it was the Prime Minister's office that the letter was delivered to—and it will be in the Hansard .
—Where was it?
—How would I know where it was delivered, Senator Ray? I do not know where the letter was delivered.
—Where did you meet her?
—I met her in the anteroom of Mr Fischer's office. Where the letter was delivered, I have not the faintest idea. As I said before, it is not my responsibility to deliver the letter.
—Why didn't you hand deliver your own letter?

—Did you hear that, Madam President? Why didn't I hand deliver my own letter? I would like to know how many ex-ministers on that other side ever hand delivered their own letters. You did not ask me whether I typed it myself. We are scraping the bottom of the barrel now. Will he ask which pen I used? I would be happy to tell him that. I have got a few I think. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Resources and Energy. My question follows your release this week of details of granting of a production licence to Woodside Offshore Petroleum to proceed with plans to build the world's largest offshore production facility in the Browse Basin—a facility which, when on stream, will contribute $1.8 billion a year towards Australia's economy. Can you further tell us the beneficial impacts that projects of this size have for the Australian economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator McGauran very much for that question. It is refreshing to get a question that is important to the whole Australian community instead of the rubbish we are hearing from the Labor Party on the other side. It seems to me that the disease of relevant deprivation that Mr Evans got has become contagious and has now spread throughout the whole Labor Party.

ANSWER.PARA: As I mentioned at the press conference earlier this week, the production licence to Woodside for Laminaria represents a major and significant boost to Australia's oil reserves. From a self-sufficiency point of view, it is great news for Australia with a 20 per cent increase in our reserves. In global terms, Australia has been very much underexplored for oil, even though the exploration undertaken has produced a great success rate.

The success of Laminaria—and this is the other positive point—will add impetus to exploration activity in Australia for oil. On 24 January this year, the Australian Petroleum Production and Exploration Association published its forecast for petroleum exploration and development activity in 1997. The forecast is very positive for the future of Australia.

Firstly, a significant increase is predicted in both exploration and development activity, especially in Australia's offshore areas. Between $750 million and $1 billion will be spent on exploration, while over $1.5 billion is expected to be spent on development projects. This means real jobs, direct and indirect.

BREAK.PARA: Most of the offshore exploration will again concentrate in the Carnarvon Basin on the north-west coast of Western Australia and in the Bonaparte Basin in the Timor Sea, which includes the Timor Gap.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which government did all the work to set it up? We did!
—Senator Collins, after 13 years of Labor, you are not used to good news and you do not like it. You are going to be even more unhappy because I have got more good news.

BREAK.PARA: Most of the onshore activity will concentrate on the proven petroleum province of the Cooper‐Eromanga Basin in the north-east of South Australia and in the south-west of Queensland. This means more jobs for regional Australia. Development drilling will increase offshore in the Carnarvon Basin and in the Gippsland Basin in Bass Strait, while onshore development drilling will continue in the Cooper‐Eromanga Basin.

I would like to congratulate the shadow minister for resources and energy on what I believe is his second press release on resources in 12 months. It can best be described as a blast from the past. It may be even reminiscent of the late Rex Connor. Let us see what Mr O'Keefe has to say. Among other things he called on the federal government to use its export licence control powers to demand stronger Australian returns. Someone should tell Mr O'Keefe that there are no export control powers on oil and nor were there under the previous Labor government. Great stuff from Mr O'Keefe!

The next thing he says is that he requires a substantial part of investment capital to be sourced in Australia. Here we have a joint venture made up of Woodside, an Australian company, 50 per cent; BHP, another Australian company—the big Australian—25 per cent; and Shell, a company which has very proudly worked in Australia for many years, 25 per cent. Yet he says he wants more investment capital sourced in Australia. He goes on to say that he is happy with the project. Australians want more projects. They want real job creation. They do not want the negative carping of the Labor Party. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Chief General Counsel
Attorney‐General's Department
12 February 1997
So he seems to say that he was asked advice, Senator Bolkus, on the basis of a specific—
