—I have just been told that it is already public. Why table it if it is public? Senator Bolkus, it would seem that he was asked a specific question in relation to the letter signed by the minister for Aboriginal affairs, and he has answered in terms of the request.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. There are a number of very serious questions arising from that answer. If, Minister, you say that the advice was based on all the evidence on the record, why were not relevant minutes of meetings and relevant letters seeking resignations tendered to Mr Burmester? Why does Mr Burmester specifically limit his advice to the material set out in the one letter? Minister, why was Mr Burmester not given an opportunity to interview both ministers and Ms Hollows? Even Chief Inspector Clouseau would have examined the witnesses. What is more, why was this matter not referred to the DPP instead of the government's Chief General Counsel, given that the DPP is the most senior and independent expert on Commonwealth criminal matters?

—What Senator Bolkus is seeking to do is to beat this up into terms of an investigation which, of course, it was not. Henry Burmester was asked to advise in relation to a particular letter, and he so advised. I presume that other matters were regarded as irrelevant.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, are you aware of allegations that Port Hinchinbrook developer Keith Williams has breached the Environmental Protection Act of Queensland by dredging a basin for the resort's marina without a licence? This violation was confirmed by legal advice provided to the North Queensland Conservation Council which says the developer must have a licence to dredge Queensland waters, and that dredging without a licence violates the act. Minister, are you aware that this also violates the deed of agreement, negotiated with the federal government, which requires that all parties adhere to all rules and regulations affecting the Hinchinbrook region? Minister, now that Mr Williams has thumbed his nose at you, will you do your duty and rescind the deed of agreement, which has been shown to be a sham?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am doing my duty, as Senator Woodley would suggest, and I am doing my best to ensure that Mr Williams in the works complies with the deed that he has entered into with the Commonwealth. GBRMPA, who administers that task on my behalf, has my instructions in clear and unambiguous terms. There is, as I think I may have said on a previous occasion, Senator Woodley, some dispute as to the correct interpretation of the deed—differences of view between Commonwealth advisers, advisers to the Queensland government, advisers to Mr Williams and probably advisers to various conservation groups as well.

ANSWER.PARA: But having said that and having tried to progress the matter consistent with the terms of the deed, let me say that the works, as I understand it, are not taking place at the moment at all; secondly, the advice I have had from time to time from GBRMPA has been that there has been no action taken that would significantly in any way detrimentally affect the environment—in other words, whether or not all the provisions of the deed have been technically complied with or not. I am pleased to note that an independent monitor has been appointed in relation to the acid soil management and that other approvals that are necessary for the next stage are still being progressed and I hope will be progressed to finalisation before works recommence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you for that, Minister. Given that the state government has the responsibility to monitor the management plans as well as GBRMPA and through GBRMPA, would you agree with me that, if the developer has violated the Environmental Protection Act and the deed of agreement under the supposedly watchful eye of the Queensland government, this evidence calls into question the state government's ability to protect the world heritage area adjacent to the Port Hinchinbrook development?

—We will take action as is necessary from time to time to protect the world heritage area, Senator Woodley. Certainly, the Queensland government in terms of this deed has certain obligations which it claims to be meeting in full. We have some differences with the Queensland government on that from time to time. But, as I said, we are seeking to work through those differences in a way that protects the environment, ensures that the deed is complied with and, therefore, ensures that the benefits to the environment that are secured by the deed are, in fact, gained.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Hill in his capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister. It follows on from the answer given to a question asked of him by Senator Bolkus a moment ago. Was the Prime Minister made aware of legal advice from Blake, Dawson and Waldron, which was in the possession of Mr Sharp, stating quite clearly that his manoeuvres to remove the CASA board members were unlawful? Given that the Blake, Dawson and Waldron advice goes to the core of what Mr Sharp and his ministerial co-conspirators were trying to achieve, why wasn't it made available to Mr Burmester?
—Senator, I believe your question should be rephrased to leave out the slur on ministers in another place.
—I will make that adjustment to the question. The question is: why wasn't it made available to Mr Burmester?

QUESTION.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senators should not be shouting across the chamber.

—It is no secret that Minister Sharp wanted to replace the board members with those who may have expertise in the area of air safety. The minister who is responsible, through this board, for air safety wanted a board in which he would have greater confidence.
—The legislation is in the Senate. Bring it on!

—For all of us who fly regularly, I would have thought, Senator Ray, that was something we ought to applaud. He was therefore seeking to meet his ministerial responsibility. That is one issue. That is still his wish. We know there has been a much publicised dispute between those members of the board who apparently seek to stay in office and Mr Sharp, who wishes to have them replaced with those better qualified. That is on the public record and that debate can be had.
—What about the legal advice?

—Well, those who seek to remain on the board get their legal advice and so the processes continue. But that is totally irrelevant to the matter raised by Senator Herron yesterday upon which the Prime Minister sought advice. The matter that was raised yesterday arose out of a letter from Senator Herron. The letter from Senator Herron was forwarded by the Prime Minister who sought legal advice upon it. Anything beyond that is irrelevant and that would therefore be the reason why other extraneous materials were not also forwarded to Mr Burmester.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Hill has not answered either of the questions I put to him and he has actually talked about something entirely different. I wonder whether he would actually answer: was the Prime Minister made aware of the advice from Blake, Dawson and Waldron that the manoeuvres to remove CASA board members were unlawful? Why wasn't that advice made available to Mr Burmester? Will you now raise with the Prime Minister this matter and ask him to ensure that the advice is made available to the appropriate authorities as part of a proper and thorough investigation? Will you answer those questions, Minister, and would you please answer them not on your own personal reflections but as the Minister representing the Prime Minister?

—I will pass the request of Senator Cook on to the Prime Minister. Whilst I am on my feet I will make a few comments. What Senator Cook fails to appreciate or conveniently avoids is the fact that a dispute between Minister Sharp and the board and legal advice upon that is totally irrelevant. It is a different matter. It seems therefore to me obvious that it would not have been forwarded to Mr Burmester who was asked whether anything in a letter from Senator Herron could be said to be in breach of certain pieces of legislation. So if it is irrelevant, why would it be forwarded? I presume that that is the answer I will get back from the Prime Minister, but I will pass on the request.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment and Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Following today's Senate resolution, will the Minister for Foreign Affairs protest to France, Britain and Japan against the nuclear waste ship Pacific Teal which is about to enter the Southern Ocean and pass south of Tasmania in the coming week? Did you mislead the Senate on Monday when you said that this dangerous waste ship will go east of New Zealand on its way to Japan? Minister, in accord with today's vote, will you now give the Senate precise information on the route through our region which this ship will take or is the best you can do still the stock reply of your office: `We don't know. Phone Greenpeace. We do have their number.'?
—What an obscure question!
—So you don't have their number.
—Greenpeace? They ring me often, I know that. I have great respect for Greenpeace.

BREAK.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senators on my left please cease interjecting.

—The Senate passed a resolution today asking that I give further information to that which I provided the other day. Of course I will comply with that. In fact I was planning to do so immediately after question time. But basically the information remains the same. We do not know the exact routeing. We have been told that it will not be travelling within Australian territorial waters. I said that I believed that it was going to travel to the west of New Zealand.
—East, not west.
—He's no geographer!

—Notwithstanding the help, the answer I intended to give after question time I will still give after question time. My best information is that the ship will pass to the east of New Zealand. I partly base that on the fact that our advice was that it would be travelling through the south-west Pacific. I do not see the sea between Australia and New Zealand normally expressed in those terms. We are satisfied with all the safeguards and all the assurances we have been given in relation to the safety of this transport. The effect of the information that I will table after question time is just to add a little more detail to that.

—I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister to what degree his and the government's nonchalance on this issue has been determined by the government's intention to try to expand its uranium sales to Japan and to France? I ask the minister whether he will categorically state that he will join protests from New Zealand, the Cook Islands, Fiji and Malaysia about this dangerous cargo that is about to pass through the Australian region?

—You are the one who climbs trees and chains yourself, I don't. I am not going to join in any protests. I remind the honourable senator that in the 35 years existence of the IAEA's transport regulations, no accident has occurred during the transportation of radioactive material which has had any significant radiological consequence.
—I hope not!

—It is the basis upon which we have some confidence, Senator. Thirty‐five years, no problems. When you talk about shipments from Japan to Europe, 150 shipments already—no problems. That is the basis upon which we have some confidence. So rather than go out and scare the Australian community, why don't you set a realistic base which will give them confidence that they need not be unduly concerned by this shipment?

—My question is to Senator Vanstone representing the Attorney‐General. At what time yesterday afternoon was the Attorney‐General's Department requested to provide advice on the Hollows affair, and at what time did Mr Burmester provide his response? Has the government sought advice from Mr Burmester on the basis for his opinion that no Commonwealth criminal offence has been committed? If so, will the government make the advice publicly available? If not, will the government seek that advice as a matter of urgency?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I think you are stretching a long bow to regard this as `an affair'. You want it to be an investigation, clearly, but as you have had indicated to you, advice was sought on a letter. That is not an investigation. That is the only information that I have. I will pass all your questions on to the Attorney‐General. If he has anything to say to you, I am sure he will pass it on.

—I ask a supplementary question. While you are doing that, you might try answering this question. Was Mr Burmester only provided with a copy of the letter from Senator Herron to Ms Hollows as indicated by the limitations expressly stated by Mr Burmester in his advice or was he provided with the Hansard of yesterday's question time, as indicated by Mr Williams in his interview on ABC Radio this morning? If the latter, why was Mr Burmester not asked to provide advice in relation to the matters contained in the Hansard , and why did he fail to refer to the Hansard in his letter of advice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I will take those questions on notice as well, but I cannot help but refer to Senator Herron's answer to you. With all the problems that you left this nation, the best you can do is ask at what time the Attorney asked this person for advice, at what time someone else did something else and whether Mr Burmester had the Hansard at hand. I am sure Mr Burmester is capable of getting Hansard should he need it. Really, if you do not understand the mess that you left this nation in and the job we have been given to fix it up, if all you can do is nitpick, you are just a disgrace. You should not be here. You gave the nation that kind of problem, especially with unemployment, you have no plans to fix it, and all you want to do is waste a whole question time nitpicking. You are a disgrace. No wonder they voted you out of government. No wonder they voted you out. It will be a long time before they ever vote you back.

—My question is to the Minister for Social Security. Last year you reported to the parliament on the measures this government had implemented to ensure that only those genuinely entitled to receive social security benefits would receive them. Could you inform the Senate on any further progress that has been made in this area as a result of our commitment to a fairer and more equitable system for social security recipients and taxpayers alike?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —It interesting, isn't it, that the focus on good administration and running government effectively is of interest to people like Senator Ferris but it does not seem to be of much interest to the Labor opposition who would play games in the Senate when there are important matters of employment, for example, before us.

ANSWER.PARA: We heard a great deal during the previous Labor administration about how clever they were about administering the Department of Social Security. The former minister, Mr Baldwin, said in 1995, `What we do now by way of compliance is now recognised as being world leading standard in many respects.' Because of that, what did they do? They sat on their hands. They did not really make any further effort in terms of compliance. They did not put the additional resources in.

The former Labor government's administration of the social security portfolio has been exposed as fraud. They were defrauding their fellow taxpayers and the community by telling them that the system was as tight as it could get. We now know from Labor's findings on the reasons for its recent election failure that the people were not conned. The Labor post‐mortem report, co‐authored by Senator Mackay sitting opposite me, was a clear statement that almost everyone knew a social security cheat—that is, everyone except the former Labor government. They were supposed to have their finger on the pulse.

I think it really shows that Laurie Oakes did not list enough things in pointing out how out of touch they were with mainstream Australia when he wrote his Bulletin article this week. This was yet another area where they were quite out of touch. I made a promise when I became Minister for Social Security, and today I am delighted to be able to provide to the parliament the second social security compliance report. When we compare the social security compliance results for the last six months of last year with the opposition's results for the same period in government in 1995, we can see how misguided their understanding of the system was.

My report today demonstrates that my department has increased compliance reviews by nearly 29 per cent. From these increased reviews, there was an increase of over 27 per cent in cancellations or reductions of payments. Overpayments raised from reviews totalled over $105 million, and that is an increase of almost 40 per cent. This is a particularly interesting item, Senator Ferris: we are saving the Australian taxpayer over $10 million every week as a result of the review activities over the last six months of this last year.

In addition, recoveries of debts for the six‐month period were $175 million, which was a massive 49 per cent increase over the same period in 1995. Most importantly of all, the public have also demonstrated their support for our efforts in this area by assisting us with information that has allowed us to undertake a further 26,500 reviews—and that was an increase of 27 per cent of public reports. There is a resultant increase in savings from these reports. So reviews are up; identified overpayments are up; debts recovered are up; and support from the public is up because they know this government means business. I am very happy to table this report for the benefit of the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to Senator Hill, representing the Prime Minister. Is Senator Hill aware that the Prime Minister in his press conference today revealed for the first time that Senator Colston had written to him directly regarding the staff upgrade for a position in his office? When was this letter received in the Prime Minister's office? Given that all other correspondence has been made available, will you table that letter here in the Senate. Could you also ascertain whether that letter arrived before or after PM&C proffered its advice to the Prime Minister, as revealed by the Prime Minister, and will you table that particular piece of advice?

—I do not think I know of the letter to which you are referring, Senator Ray. I have copies of the letters as I know them, which I presume you have also. The letters I have include a letter from Senator Reid to the Prime Minister on the matter, and the following letters seem to flow from that. I will go back and ask specifically for details of that letter and see what I can advise further.

—I have a supplementary question: is it also a fact that, when questioned on whether Senator Colston's vote on the Telstra bill was discussed with his chief of staff at the time of approving the staff upgrade, the Prime Minister said, `I don't remember that being discussed'? Is this just a case of the Prime Minister becoming the Anastasia of Australian politics?

—That is a bit feeble, Madam President. I know what the opposition is seeking to do, and that is in the nature of politics. There is quite a long history, when you look back through this file, of the Deputy President seeking to have his staff brought into a position similar to the staff of the Deputy Speaker on the other side of this building. There is correspondence between him and Senator Reid, and some views expressed by Senator Reid on the matter.
—She wasn't happy about it.

—Well, she reminded the Prime Minister how she had been somewhat frugal, therefore producing savings for the government. She has greater flexibility in her staff than the Deputy President, of course. As I understand it, this staff member is the only staff member that the Deputy President gets. In fact, it turns out that it was not his staff member but an officer of the Senate. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill. At the launch of your wetlands policy, you said, `Wetlands are among the most important life support systems on earth.' You were proud of Australia's involvement in the Ramsar convention and said, `Australia continues to be a world leader in this field.' Minister, your decision on the future of the Ramsar listed wetlands at Point Lillias relies upon, amongst other things, the demonstration of urgent national interest.

QUESTION.PARA: You will be aware that the departments of Industry, Science and Technology, Health and Family Services, Defence, Foreign Affairs and Trade, Finance and your own department are on the record as questioning whether a case of urgent national interest has been adequately demonstrated such as to warrant excising part of Point Lillias for a chemical storage complex. Minister, in the light of your government's commitments and the advice you have been given, will you now protect Point Lillias?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I am heartened to learn that the Australian Democrats are reading our materials and I applaud your study of wetlands and the importance of wetlands within ecological systems. I am pleased that Australia takes the Ramsar convention seriously. In fact, we were the first signatory to that convention and this government will uphold the obligations Australia assumed by signing that document. As you are aware, it is possible to delete part of a Ramsar site by a contracting party if the contracting party is satisfied that there is an urgent national interest and if adequate compensation has been made.

ANSWER.PARA: The Victorian government—it is no secret—have written to us seeking to make out a case of urgent national interest that relates to their wish to relocate the chemical storage facility at Coode Island. They have also offered compensation—in fact, some 240 hectares of compensation—in lieu of the 20 hectares they are seeking to have deleted. That is out of a total Ramsar site of about 4,500 hectares. They want to take out 20 hectares and they have offered an additional 240 hectares and further enhancement of about half of that 240 hectares.

Be that as it may, we have to be satisfied on both points and I have sought advice from my department on that. I now have that advice and I am considering that advice. When I have made a decision on that, it will obviously be made public.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask supplementary question. Minister, are you aware that of that 240 hectares offered by the Victorian government as compensation, at least 61 hectares would be degraded by the Point Lillias chemical complex? I believe that was admitted by the Victorian government and your own department. If the complex goes ahead, do you intend to pursue the Montreux listing for that habitat?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the honourable senator again. She is obviously studying the papers. That is true. If you take into account the buffer zone, you get back to a net of about 180 hectares additional clear compensation. As she has read the papers so carefully, she will know that most of that compensation area is regarded by the scientists as of much higher conservation value than Point Lillias itself. She will no doubt nod, because she has read the materials.

ANSWER.PARA: Be that as it may, that is all part of this debate as to whether compensation is adequate. Obviously, no, I am not going to seek a Montreux listing for this because Australia's obligations under the Ramsar convention are properly met and are not threatened by activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Is it true that at the televised launch of the green corps in Adelaide on 12 January, a significant number of young people in the small crowd were members of the Young Liberals, including Michelle Lensink, president of the Young Liberals in South Australia and a staff member for Christopher Pyne, dressed down and in dark glasses, and Kaija Balodis from the Young Liberal executive? Is this in the same league as Senator Woods' meet the people stunt where his staffers posed as ordinary voters praising John Hewson during the 1993 election? Or are these Young Liberals genuinely interested in signing up for the green corps to escape their jobs with people like you, Christopher Pyne and Trish Worth because they feel, like the rest of Australia, that the coalition government has lost all credibility?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I am tempted. Here is a former minister of a former government suggesting, despite the fact that the former government was soundly kicked out of office after 13 years, thrown on the scrapheap of opposition for some considerable time, that somehow the electorate have decided that the government they elected to fix the mess you created has lost credibility. Why do you say this, Senator Crowley? Because some genius on your side who has nothing better to do than look at the television has spotted three Young Liberals at a green corps launch? Heavens above!

ANSWER.PARA: I should have put up a sign saying, `P.S. If you are a Young Liberal you are not welcome to be interested in the environment.' I should have told them, `You're not allowed to come along to this. You're a Liberal. You should be kept out of such events. And don't wear your sunglasses on a day that is about 35 degrees in the heat because some Labor person might think you are disguising yourself.' Oh dear— Senator Crowley, if you cannot do better than this, don't bother.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The Prime Minister says that the green corps is part of your government's armoury of policies to combat youth unemployment, yet you yourself said in the chamber, this week I think, that the green corps is not a labour market program. Can you explain who is speaking the truth, the Prime Minister or you? Is it true that the 240 places will not go far to help 100,000 unemployed people get jobs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no point in you faking rage at the unemployment you created—stamping your foot, saying, `What are you going to do about it?' We are going to do a lot more than you did in 13 years in government—absolutely creating it. The green corps is a most innovative idea of this government—so I thank you for raising it—to give young people the opportunity to combine accredited training with their interest to protect and enhance the environment. They can go on from that into further training. We are going to give those who want to a cash amount to encourage them into further training.

ANSWER.PARA: As you should well know, Senator Crowley, further training is the key to a job. We believe giving young people experience with accredited training will lead to them having a greater opportunity of deciding if they want a career in the environment or of simply getting a job because of the work experience they have had. If you do not like the idea, why don't you move a motion saying we should scrap it—(Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Given yesterday's decision by some banks to cut interest rates, is it a fact that repayments on an average $100,000 mortgage have resulted in savings to Australian families of $246 a month, a massive reduction since the Howard government was elected? How will the environment of low interest rates, low inflation and—

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senators on my left should cease interjecting.
—How will the environment of low interest rates, low inflation and strong business investment assist Australian families and small business?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a good note on which to end—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senators on my left should cease shouting out in that manner.

—This is a good note on which to end question time for the fortnight actually, because we are back onto the big picture—the advantages of a Howard coalition government: low interest rates, low inflation, strong business growth, the chance for increased employment. These are the things the people elected the new government for after the dismal failure of 13 years of Labor.

ANSWER.PARA: It is good news to see this week headlines reading `$46 loan cut' and articles stating, `The Commonwealth Bank yesterday cut its standard variable home loan rate to 7.55 per cent; the lowest in 23 years.' That is good news for Australian voters. It is good news for all Australians. In fact, on an average $100,000 home loan over 25 years, repayments have been cut by $246 a month. Small businesses—never forgotten by the Howard government—with a loan of $500,000 have been given interest savings of $7,500 a year. That is good news for small businesses. It gives them the chance to grow, to make a profit and to start employing more Australians.

When we came to government only 10 months ago, the interest rate for small business was 11.25 per cent. It is now down to 9.75 per cent. That is good news. Add to that the fact that non-bank lenders are entering the housing market and are providing a more competitive environment, we now have home loans interest rates at around 7.4 per cent. That is good news for small business and for families. That will result in a saving of over $11,000 on a $500,000 loan. One million Australians are now better off with $1 billion worth of tax savings.

BREAK.PARA: Contrast that with Labor's record: the second highest prime interest rate among all developed nations and average monthly home repayments rising by nearly 50 per cent. Labor pushed up interest rates on homes by 50 per cent. Do you remember the home loan variable interest rate of 17 per cent in 1990? Do you remember that under Labor home loan variable rates never went under 8.75 per cent?

Senator Schacht, as the then minister for small business, do you remember small business loan rates of 20 per cent in 1989‐90? Under your government small business had to pay 20 per cent to borrow? What did your government do? It pushed rates up further and further until businesses went to the wall. Do you remember the credit card rates, or have you got a short memory? There was a 25 per cent interest rate on credit cards. That is the record of Labor.

In only 10 months, in such a short period, the coalition government enacts sensible economic policies and gets hold of expenditure and we see three official reductions in interest rates. This is now flowing through to businesses and houses. When you add to that low inflation rates, a government determined to keep taxes down and a government that is encouraging business investment, which is now up to around 17 per cent, then there is real hope in this country at last.

Thirteen years of dismal Labor has been replaced by the opportunity of hope, the opportunity of growth, the opportunity of jobs and the opportunity of benefit to those who suffer so much under Labor: small business and families. This government is responding in the way that the public elected it to do, and that should be applauded.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 February Senator McKiernan asked me a question in my capacity as Minister representing the Attorney-General. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an answer to that question.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

BREAK.PARA: The document read as follows—
Senator Amanda Vanstone—On 6 February 1997 (Hansard Page 197) Senator McKiernan asked me as the Minister representing the Attorney-General the following questions without notice:
1. Do you agree with the Attorney-General's statement in the House yesterday that this is entirely a matter for the New South Wales government?

2. Are you aware that this particular case only proceeded under State law because the Commonwealth authorities decided that they did not have sufficient information to charge the defendant with importation, a Commonwealth offence?
3. Is it true that your government's draconian cuts were based on faulty figures?

4. Is it also true that your government has undertaken no preparation towards the setting up of a separate federal legal aid system despite having prior notice of the New South Wales government decision?
5. Will the government accept a moratorium that Senator Bolkus has called for against the cuts to the legal aid system?
The Attorney-General has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:
1. The matter is a matter for the New South Wales Government as the person charged with the possession of heroin has been charged with a criminal offence under New South Wales law.
2. No, not in this particular case. I am not privy to information regarding matters prosecuted by the State authorities. Decisions to prosecute are matters for the prosecuting authorities.

3. The figures used to calculate the reduction in legal aid funding from 1 July 1997 are not faulty. The figures for 1994-95 were the only full year figures available at the time of the calculations. Even now we do not have complete figures available for 1995-96 because we are still waiting on some State figures.

4. The Commonwealth is considering a number of options for setting up a separate Commonwealth legal aid system if the need arises, but this is not the preferred option. This Government remains committed to a joint Commonwealth-State arrangement for the delivery of legal aid services.
5. No.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said that I would table the further materials required pursuant to a motion of the Senate moved by Senator Brown regarding the radioactive waste ship ment. I table that information. On 11 February the Senate agreed to an order for the production of documents relating to the defence exercise Operation Tandem Thrust. I table that information in response to the order of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Tuesday Senator Harradine asked me a question regarding the government's decision to abolish the general independent Austudy rate. He also asked whether the family tax initiative deems those students as not being dependent upon their parents. I seek leave to incorporate my answer into Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
RESPONSE TO SENATOR HARRADINE

On Tuesday Senator Harradine asked me a question regarding the Government's decision to abolish the general independent AUSTUDY rate and whether the family tax initiative actually deems those students as being not dependent upon the parents.
Eligibility for AUSTUDY relates to the Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs portfolio, for which Senator Vanstone is responsible.

However I am advised that the Government did not abolish the general independent AUSTUDY rate but did announce that it would increase the age of independence under AUSTUDY from 22 to 25 and that regulations to give effect to this decision have been tabled in the Parliament.
As Senator Harradine is aware, under the family tax initiative a child qualifies as a dependent if the child:
was under the age of 16; or
was aged 16 or 17 and receiving full-time secondary education
and the taxpayer contributed to the maintenance of the child and the child's income does not exceed the child income ceiling.
The age of dependent children for the purposes of the Family Tax Initiative is basically aligned with the ages of children for Family Payment eligibility.
The Family Tax Initiative age cut offs are also generally consistent with the age cutoffs in our election policy documents.
As a result of the age criteria of the definition of dependent under the Family Tax Initiative legislation, any child over the age of 17 will not qualify as a dependent irrespective of:
whether or not they are studying full-time; and
whether parents contribute to the maintenance of the child.
This will include full-time students aged 22 to 25 which do not qualify for AUSTUDY as a result of the increased age of independence.
Senator Harradine also asked about what the Government is going to do in the next budget. I will not speculate on what the Government will be doing in the budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) to questions without notice asked today, relating to alleged inducements offered to Ms Gabi Hollows to resign from her position on the Civil Aviation Safety Authority board of directors.

What we had from Senator Herron today was the most extraordinary admission of guilt. Yesterday in this chamber he misled the Senate and the Australian people. He is now showing his weakness: he cannot stand the heat in the kitchen. He is getting up and walking out now that key issues are being raised about his own ministerial competence and ministerial accountability.

Yesterday, when asked a question in the Senate chamber, Senator Herron read into the Hansard a letter that he had written to Ms Gabi Hollows. He read the first paragraph, the second paragraph and the third paragraph. Then, remarkably, he read only part of the fourth paragraph. He read this in the Senate:
I have discussed this matter with my ministerial colleague Mr Sharp.
He then interpolated:
I did. I can keep going.
He then read the last sentence of that paragraph:
I hope that we can work together to achieve improved health outcomes for Aboriginal people and look forward to discussing this issue with you.

What he did not read out was the full fourth paragraph of that letter. He deliberately engaged in one of the most transparent cover-ups that we have ever seen in this Senate chamber because the whole paragraph said this:
I have discussed this matter with my ministerial colleague Mr Sharp,—
That is what Senator Herron owned up to. Then there is a comma, not a full stop, and it continues:

who has assured me that he will be amenable to you retiring from your responsibilities on the Board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority in order to be available for an appointment in the area of Aboriginal health delivery.

That was a deliberate and bare‐faced attempt to mislead the Senate. He did not front up. It was an admission of guilt. He knew he was not telling the whole truth to the Senate. He knew he was misleading and he knew its significance. You have to ask yourself why Senator Herron did not tell the whole truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gutless.
—It is not only that he is gutless because he knew—
—Order! That is an unparliamentary remark.

—I withdraw it. Not only did he not have the courage but he knew that it was an inducement to Ms Hollows. He realised that if he read that into the Hansard he would be in diabolical trouble in terms of the continuation of his ministerial career.

SPEECH.PARA: But what happened was that he was found out. The heat on Senator Herron and the heat on Mr Sharp all got too much. At the end of the day, after a four-hour crisis meeting in the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), the letter was made public, along with a very flimsy piece of advice from the Chief General Counsel in the Attorney-General's Department who apparently had been given very limited access to material and provided an advice. So Mr Howard made the weak and quivering announcement that neither Mr Sharp nor Senator Herron would be required to resign. I was not surprised that Mr Howard said that. That is the sort of thing we expect from this Prime Minister, who came to office with such high and mighty ideas and ideals about ministerial competence and accountability but has not delivered on any of it.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Herron said on Pru Goward's show this morning:
Oh, yes, sure, but gee—
again, gee—
really it was a private letter to Ms Hollows. I didn't have her permission to read it out and, I mean, I am happy to table it or do whatever.

Remember what happened in this Senate chamber yesterday during question time? Time and again Senator Herron refused to table that letter. He refused to table it because he knew it was an admission of guilt and he knew it was an inducement to Ms Hollows to resign and he understood so well the significance of that part of the letter. He stands condemned for misleading this chamber and for abrogating his ministerial responsibilities and he ought to stand down while it is properly investigated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Sandy

TALK.START.PARA: —The most unfortunate thing about this storm in a teacup is the use of Ms Hollows to try to embarrass Ministers Sharp and Herron. The work of the Hollows Foundation in Aboriginal health is highly regarded. Her continued role in this area should and must be encouraged. It is very unfortunate that Labor has tried to bring that very important work into disrepute by involving her in this way.
—Rubbish! The two things are completely separate. What nonsense!

—They are not completely separate at all. The Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) has the responsibility to get the organisation for air safety in this country, CASA, in proper shape. The failure of the previous government to appoint suitable people to the board of the CAA to properly oversee Australia's air safety operations contributed in some small way or perhaps some large way to the fatal Monarch and Seaview crashes. The fatal crashes have been a continuing worry to the minister, and the public record shows the inappropriateness of the existing board.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook came in and mentioned the legal advice from Blake Dawson Waldron. He said that it was unlawful, as if it was some illegal proposal that the minister had proposed to remove the existing board of CASA. I think that was probably a misconception to say that it was unlawful. I have not seen the advice from Blake Dawson Waldron but I would suggest that it was probably compensatable—

TALK.START.PARA: —If you haven't seen it, you shouldn't talk about it.

—Neither should he. He did not even know the proper name of the law firm. He probably had not seen the advice of the law firm either. All I am saying is that it was recognised that compensation would have had to have been paid to the board. All that Minister Sharp was trying to do was get a board that was accountable to the government and accountable for air safety.
—Why does he want to sack Dr Pollock? She's an expert.
—Order! Honourable senators on my left!

—The only proper conclusion that can be drawn from Ms Hollows's discussions with the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer), Minister Sharp and Minister Herron is that there was no inducement for her to resign on the basis that she was going to be appointed to a new board.
—Give my office a ring before question time, Sandy, and I'll write a speech for you if you like.
—Order! Senator Collins, you will remain silent.

—On 6 May Ms Hollows asked to see Minister Herron from the Deputy Prime Minister's office. After discussions, her expertise in Aboriginal affairs was confirmed in the letter from Senator Herron to Ms Hollows. Ms Hollows has not replied to Minister Herron. She never took up the offer that Minister Herron had provided to her. But there are no grounds on which it could be seen that she was induced to resign from the board of CASA by the offer from Senator Herron.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this motion because I think it is a matter that is becoming increasingly urgent and one that is of national importance. We do have a cover‐up here. That is an indisputable fact. Especially after question time today we can see that the whole mountain of evidence in relation to this matter has not been examined. I say that because in question time today we had Senator Hill and Senator Vanstone either not being able to answer questions or not wanting to. I make the allegation of them not wanting to because some of the most basic information that was sought here was available to members of the House of Representatives but Senator Hill was not able to provide it to us here.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most fundamental things that Senator Hill said in question time today was that there had not been an investigation. We on this side believe there should be a full investigation that takes into account the whole context of this matter. It is not good enough that Senator Hill, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, has come in here and said, `Look, this incident has a long history. It is a saga. It has gone on for some time, and the minister has wanted to sack the board members,' and then said that all of this is irrelevant to the correspondence between Minister Herron and Gabi Hollows. It is not irrelevant—it is not irrelevant at law and it is not irrelevant at politics. For as long as this matter goes on, politically there will be a stench. It will undermine the credibility of this government, particularly our Prime Minister (Mr Howard). `Honest John' has a very empty sound these days.

Legally—I ask Senator Hill to listen to this—the context is critical, the context is important. This is not just the view of the opposition; it is the view of the full bench of the High Court of Australia. It is worth placing on record the view of the High Court of Australia in terms of these matters. Just a few years ago the bench, chaired by Justice Mason with Justices Brennan, Toohey, Gaudron and Davies, had this united voice on what is relevant in matters like this:
A representation may be made by acts and conduct as well as words or by a combination of words, acts and conduct.
I am not talking here about judicial activism of the High Court, because they go on to quote Lord Campbell in the 1841 case of Waters and Morgan in the British judicial system. They say:

"A nod or a wink, or a shake of the head, or a smile" may constitute a representation. Likewise, the content of a representation (which is ordinarily a question of fact) is to be ascertained, where appropriate, by reference to the circumstances in which it was made and the matters to which it related.

That is the telling part: the context, the import, the impact of a representation is to be assessed `by reference to the circumstances in which it was made and the matters to which it related'. In this case, this government sat the whole weight of the Prime Minister's office and the office of the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) on a poor public servant in the Attorney-General's Department, the most inappropriate person to make an assessment of the evidence in this case. They sent to him only a small bit of the mountain of evidence.

For anyone to make a comprehensive, full and honest assessment of what these ministers were up to, they would have had to look at, for instance, the circumstances of the delivery of the letter that was examined; the discussions between ministers; the general background; minutes of meetings, especially of the initial one that Minister Sharp had with the board where he sought their resignation, and of particular discussions he had with individual members—there would have been minutes for those; letters from ministers to members, seeking resignation; minutes of conversations between ministers and their officers; and of course minutes of the meeting that Minister Sharp had with Gabi Hollows and the one Minister Herron had with Gabi Hollows.

All these bits of evidence are quite critical and fundamental to any honest examination of this matter, and they have been neglected. The Prime Minister was not game enough to put all this evidence to independent scrutiny. As I say, for independent scrutiny it should have gone to the DPP or the Australian Federal Police, because we have here a case involving quite a number of characters.

The bottom line in a sense is that the Australian public is being asked by `not so honest John' to believe that there has been a full examination here and everything is okay. But how can there have been an examination when not even the prime witnesses have been questioned? Even Chief Inspector Clouseau would have examined the prime witnesses. He would have asked them questions.

But this Attorney-General has been derelict in his responsibility to the law and the legal system of this country. As the person responsible he should have said, `Hey, this is a bit of a sham here. There's more involved in this than one letter.' All the evidence should have been sent to the appropriate law enforcement agency—not just one or maybe two letters in the Hansard being sent to an officer under the direction of the Attorney-General. There has not been a full and independent investigation. This is a sham. It is a cover-up. And there are not just two ministers involved now; there is a conspiracy here to pervert the course of justice. Go straight to the Prime Minister's office. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset can I dispel this myth that Senator Herron is withholding evidence or that he attempted to do so. The opposition was given yesterday a copy of the very letter that Senator Herron wrote to Mrs Hollows, and that speaks for itself. There is no inducement in that letter whatsoever, and this attack by the opposition falls flat on its face.

SPEECH.PARA: When one looks at the letter one can see that it was an invitation `to discuss with you'—that is, Mrs Hollows—`the ways in which you could contribute through an appointment to one of the organisations under my ministerial responsibility'. The letter did not involve a job offer. The letter did not involve any inducement. Senator Herron has explained fully what took place.

Senator Herron has stated that Minister Sharp phoned him in late March or early April last year and indicated that during a discussion with Gabi Hollows it became clear that she had a great deal of expertise in Aboriginal health, which falls squarely within Senator Herron's responsibility. He also indicated that he thought she might be resigning from the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. He also indicated that he would have no objections to her resigning.

Senator Herron, of course, took up the opportunity to approach this woman, who has a great deal to offer his portfolio. There is absolutely nothing wrong with that. Anyone listening to this would understand that to be what any competent minister would do. In fact, bringing in experienced people from the community to assist the government only leads to good government. Mrs Hollows had precisely that experience: she had involvement with Aboriginal people and, more importantly, with Aboriginal health. Of course Senator Herron would approach her to see how she could contribute to the portfolio.

Senator Herron has stated repeatedly that he would be interested in having Mrs Hollows involved in his portfolio. There was no inducement, threat or anything of that sort in this letter. The letter speaks for itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —It sure does!
—It is in the public domain. There is nothing further to add—
—Herron isn't the problem. He's the patsy. It's John Sharp organising this.
—For the opposition to imply that Senator Herron is involved in some sort of perversion of the course of justice—
—No! I disagree with Herron being made—
—You say `no', Senator Collins? At least we can clear that up.
—No, I agree with you.
—You withdraw that allegation, do you?
—No, I disagree.
—I take it you withdraw the allegation that Senator Herron made any inducement to Mrs Hollows.
—I didn't make the allegation. I will speak next.
—You can hear the opposition's case crumbling, because they know that they cannot make out this outra geous allegation that Senator Herron was involved in any inducement.
—He attempted to mislead the Senate yesterday.

—Senator Herron did not attempt to mislead the Senate. In fact it was yesterday afternoon that the very letter he was referring to was made public. There is nothing misleading about that. Senator Herron said yesterday:

SPEECH.PARA: I will check that out for you and see if I have anything further I can give you to assist you. I will see what I can do and see if I can produce anything further that would be of assistance.

Later that afternoon the letter was made public. The letter says it all. There is nothing in that letter at all which is incriminatory and there is nothing at all which would imply interference with the exercising of the duties of an officer of the Commonwealth, as Senator Faulkner feebly tried to imply yesterday.

So what we have here is a very common situation that we find in government: someone who has a great deal to offer has been discovered, as it were, by someone—in this case, Minister Sharp. He contacts his colleague, quite rightly so, and says, `I have a woman here who has a great deal of expertise and can assist you.' That is what happened. In fact, Senator Herron has said that. It is reflected in his letter. He even states in the letter that he has spoken to Minister Sharp and he has said in that letter what he wants to do, and that is to make use of this lady's services in relation to her expertise. It is nothing more and nothing less than that. There is absolutely nothing wrong with that. In fact, any minister who did not make that sort of approach to some worthwhile member of the community would not be doing his job.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I just say immediately—
—You can.

—In fact if I say it first I cannot avoid saying it immediately, can I. I agree that the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron, is in fact the patsy in this matter, and I said that to him by way of interjection yesterday. He is not the prime agent in this dreadful piece of chicanery at all. He was the cat's paw; he got set up.

SPEECH.PARA: But, having been given that job to do by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr Sharp, there is no question about what he did in the Senate yesterday. I ask all honourable senators to simply do one thing: get the page of the Hansard from Senate question time yesterday, sit it alongside this letter that Senator Herron was quoting from and just have a look at what he tried to do. Senator Herron in question time yesterday read out the complete text of this letter from the top to all the way down the page—every single word. Have a look in the Hansard; you will see the letter there.

The impression Senator Herron was deliberately trying to create was that he was reading out the whole letter. Without leaving out anything, he got all the way down to the words, `I have discussed this matter with my ministerial colleague Mr Sharp.' He then stopped, put the letter down, looked up and said to the chamber—and you see the Hansard page; you then come out of the letter; Hansard have correctly placed a full stop after the word `Sharp'; and it scans, it makes a complete sentence—`The letter continues'. It is in the Hansard. He then goes on to quote the last paragraph.

It is not just us, Mr Deputy President, who stand to be deceived on this; it is the many people—and there are many in fact, sometimes to my surprise—who follow the proceedings of this parliament, read the Hansard and watch question time in the Senate. When you read the Hansard you are deliberately given the impression by the minister that he has quoted the whole letter. His words: `The letter continues'. What he did not tell us yesterday was that he only part‐quoted a single sentence; he stopped in the middle of the sentence. There is not a full stop after `Sharp'; there is a comma. The words he did not read out were:
. . . who has assured me that he will be amenable to you retiring from your responsibilities—

et cetera. I know what happened. He got to that bit, when he was reading, and thought, `Oh; better not read that out.' That is when he stopped, looked up and said, `The letter continues'. He deliberately left it out so he could run off and check whether he should table the letter or not, because he knew that bit was potentially, at least, embarrassing to both him and his colleague.

So the impression he set out to create, as the Hansard record demonstrates, that he quoted the entire letter, was an entirely false impression and he stands condemned for attempting to get away with it. When they knew the game was up later on that day, somebody else of course tabled the letter. They knew we had it in any case and they gave it out publicly. But that does not excuse what the minister did yesterday in question time.

I want to pose a question to the minister. It is a genuine question. I am not attacking him by asking this question; I am genuinely interested. Gabi Hollows is a talented person. I know Gabi Hollows well. The first time I ever met her was in an Aboriginal community with Fred Hollows a lot of years ago when she was out there as a nurse helping Fred treat people. Of course she is qualified in that area. But, after sending the letter, the minister made not the slightest further attempt in relation to this.

I ask the minister: what are the bodies in his gift that he could appoint her to? Primary responsibility for health, of course, was transferred to the health department—with my full and continuing support—from the portfolio of Aboriginal affairs in 1994. I would actually like to know from the minister what are the appropriate bodies on which appointments in his gift are made in respect of Aboriginal health.

I conclude by saying this: why does the minister for transport, if he wants qualified people on the board of CASA, want to sack Dr Clare Pollock? Why do he and the media keep referring to her as simply an academic? She is not; she is an expert in human factors. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —On a day when unemployment figures come out, on a day when there is a lot happening in the economy, a lot of things that this parliament could be discussing to attack the real issues, the issues that confront Australia, the issues that Australians are worried about, what do we get from the ALP? A series of questions about when the Attorney-General had a cup of tea, when he saw this person, when he saw that person—all the sort of nitpicking rubbish that we have come to expect from the Labor Party!

SPEECH.PARA: They are not interested in the real issues. They are interested in nitpicking, and that is all they are about. There was not a serious question from the ALP in question time today. I have to say that even the Democrats asked a couple of what they thought were serious questions. But from the Labor Party there was nothing but nitpicking and attempts to do a little bit of point scoring.

The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate got up and said what a great issue this was, how important it was and that it was a great matter of national moment. If you looked behind him at the time, most of his colleagues had walked out. Those that remained were either asleep or deep in conversation with each other. None of them was interested in it whatsoever, and that is the case in the wider electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order. Senator Macdonald has cast some aspersions about people on this side being asleep during question time.
—What is your point of order? What standing order are you referring to?
—I think he should retract that, particularly since the only person who has been sprung sleeping in this place has been Senator Macdonald himself.
—Order! I could not hear the point of order because there was an interjection from my right.

—The point of order is that the reflection has been made that members of this side of the chamber were sleeping during question time when, in fact, no-one was asleep. I think Senator Macdonald should withdraw that reflection, particularly since the only person who has ever been disturbed sleeping in this place is him.
—I indicate that it is probably a debating point.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. It is not even worth responding to. Having come from `Honest Nick', it is probably just another one of the bits of misinformation that he is pretty good at. Nobody would take any notice of what `Honest Nick' might say about this.

SPEECH.PARA: The point of this attack on Senator Herron is that the Labor Party appreciate that Senator Herron is the first minister for many, many years—for more than a decade—who is seriously concerned about the plight of Australia's indigenous people. They realise that Senator Herron has compassion. He has an understanding of and a determination to do something serious about indigenous people in Australia. He is concerned about their health, he is concerned about their education, he is concerned about their housing standards, and he is doing something about it. The Labor Party does not like that. They are trying to discredit Senator Herron because they know he is doing such a wonderful job. They can go on as much as they like. Comments from `Honest Nick' and the crew will not wash with the indigenous people nor with the people of Australia.

Senator Herron knows what is needed and that is why he approached Ms Hollows. That is why he, recognising her interest in the matter, approached her to see if she could help. She has a great deal of expertise in Aboriginal health. Mr Sharp indicated to Senator Herron—I think it is important to get the facts on the record—that he thought that Ms Hollows might be resigning from the CASA board. So Senator Herron thought about Ms Hollows, but only after—and it is interesting to emphasise this—Ms Hollows had actually called around to speak to Senator Herron.

They had a short conversation and following that conversation, Senator Herron thought that he would confirm the contents of that short meeting: that Ms Hollows would be interested in exploring the possibility of working in the Aboriginal affairs area. Sena tor Herron confirmed this in writing and invited Ms Hollows to discuss the possibility of using her expertise in the portfolio. Ms Hollows never responded to the letter, and that was the end of the matter as far as Senator Herron was concerned. Senator Herron has related all of those facts, step by step, on at least two occasions.

Senator Bob Collins made a big point about this letter. Senator Herron in question time indicated why he stopped there. If you look at the letter, you can understand why. He read the first paragraph, which said that Ms Hollows would be aware that the federal government was interested in improving health conditions—quite a matter for public dissemination. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.

This bill proposes an amendment to the Public Service Act 1922 (the act) to deal with a procedural flaw in the discipline provisions of the act. Currently, because of a procedural flaw, the act does not enable the bringing of valid discipline charges against officers of the Australian Public Service who have resumed duties in a Department of the Service after a period of unattachment, where the misconduct alleged took place when the officer was an "unattached officer" as defined in the act.

The discipline provisions are set out in Division 6 of Part III of the Public Service Act 1922 and seek to ensure that officers or employees of the Service who have committed misconduct can be dealt with, in order to ensure efficiency in the workplace and to maintain the integrity of the Service.
Because of differences in the nature of the employment relationship, the procedure for disciplining unattached officers differs from that for disciplining officers occupying substantive positions.

This bill proposes an amendment to the act to ensure that disciplinary action can be taken against an officer whether or not a change in his or her status has occurred since the time of the alleged misconduct.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Carr) adjourned.
