SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The Community Affairs References Committee has considered the terms of reference relating to the inquiry into housing assistance, which was referred on 9 December 1996. To provide greater clarity in the scope and purpose of the inquiry, the committee has agreed to seek the Senate's approval to make some minor amendments to the terms of reference. These amendments, which do not alter the general nature of the inquiry, have the support of all parties on the committee. Therefore, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the terms of reference for the Community Affairs References Committee's inquiry into housing assistance, as referred on 9 December 1996, be varied to read as follows—

Current arrangements for the provision of housing assistance in Australia, including the public provision of housing, cash subsidies and taxation measures, and options for reform of those arrangements, with particular reference to:

(a) the effectiveness of existing forms of housing assistance in alleviating housing-related poverty and ensuring Australians have access to affordable, adequate and appropriately located secure housing;
(b) the equitable distribution of housing assistance in regard to:

PARA.TAB: (i) levels of assistance provided, and
(ii) relative housing outcomes from such assistance;

SPEECH.PARA: (c) the responsibilities of Commonwealth and State governments in the delivery of housing assistance, with specific reference to:

PARA.TAB: (i) the efficiency, effectiveness and delivery of housing assistance,
(ii) appropriate processes for ensuring the accountability, transparency and evaluation of housing assistance, and
(iii) an effective framework for determining housing need, setting national goals and developing national strategies for housing assistance;

SPEECH.PARA: (d) the value, condition and management of current public housing assets;
(e) consumer rights and responsibilities, including legislative protection and the level of advocacy and support services required to meet the needs of low income households;
(f) the value and impact of housing assistance given to the private rental market, with specific reference to:

PARA.TAB: (i) the capacity of the private rental market to meet the needs of low income and disadvantaged households,
(ii) the price and supply impact of changes to rent assistance,
(iii) the impact on market rents of a reduction in public housing stock, and
(iv) options for, and related costs of, attracting private investment to the low cost end of the private rental market;

SPEECH.PARA: (g) the appropriate mix of income support and supply assistance measures to ensure ad equate affordability and supply of housing in the medium and long term for low income households;
(h) the appropriate level and mix of investment necessary to ensure:

PARA.TAB: (i) an adequate supply of private rental housing, and

SPEECH.PARA: (ii) an adequate supply of public housing which meets the needs of low income households;
(i) the appropriate level of, and arrangements for, provision of income support to ensure affordability of appropriate housing for low income households.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I am raising this matter now as a matter of urgency because I think there are some pretty important and critical issues that need to be addressed and they need to be addressed very quickly. We have here a matter which is of national interest. It is one, however, that requires immediate investigation.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of that investigation, it also requires the immediate seizure of documents and examination of witnesses. There are minutes, letters and all sort of documentation involved that are quite critical in the full examination of this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —What minutes?

—I will get to that in a second. The opposition is concerned to ensure that this matter is fully, very quickly and exhaustively canvassed, unlike that cursory review that we had conducted at the insistence of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard).

SPEECH.PARA: I have seen some advice today from a senior counsel in New South Wales, Mr G.R. James QC. I think it is important to place some of that advice on the record because we believe that immediate action is needed to ensure that a full and proper investigation can continue in the future. He said in respect of this—and it gives the lie to what Senator Hill said in question time today:

There are many ways to seek to influence or affect a Commonwealth officer in the exercise of his duty or authority by promising or offering any property or benefit other than by an outright ex pressed bribe. The suggestion made by the letter on its face is oblique. When it is considered in the context of the provable circumstances the suggestion becomes quite blatant: "If you resign from the Board we'll find you a job in Aboriginal health." What matters as far as criminality or impropriety is concerned is the nature of all the conduct, the intention behind it and its effect. See Hawkins v The Queen (1994) 181 CLR 440 particularly per Sir Anthony Mason CJ at 447-448 citing Lord Campbell L.C. in Walters v Morgan (1861)—
as I say, a UK case—
referring to "a nod or a wink or a shake of the head or a smile" as comprising or giving content to a representation.
So what Mr James says is that the whole context of this matter is critical if one is to get an adequate examination of it. He goes on to say:

Such an offer as is implied from the letter and the surrounding conduct if made with the requisite intention is quite capable of being revealed as illegal or improper on full investigation. The conduct of the two Ministers considered in combination is hardly subtle.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: Senator Bolkus is quoting from what I think he said is a legal document. Would it be appropriate—and I do seek your ruling on this—if you asked Senator Bolkus what that opinion is. Is it related to this matter that he is talking about, is it a general treatise on accountability or is it a document that belongs to the government? I raise that only because, if it is not particularly relevant to the issue before the chamber, then it should be ruled out on the grounds of irrelevancy.
—I ask Senator Bolkus to speak to the point of order.

—On the point of order, Mr Deputy President, but I do not think it is a legitimate one: I am prepared to say that this is a legal advice on the question of inducements in the current affair. I am quite happy to table the document so that Senator Macdonald is not misled as to any aspect of it.
—But is it related?
—It is related specifically to the current affair involving both Minister Herron and Minister Sharp. I seek leave to table the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Queen's Counsel is quite explicit. The third paragraph on the final page refers to Mr Burmester's advice. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Burmester's advice, confined to the terms of the letter and omitting reference to Mr Sharp and Senator Herron's other actions, an advice given with no reasons but as a simple assertion of the author constitutes no substantial basis in my opinion, why investigation into such an important matter should not proceed.

We on this side believe that it should proceed as a matter of urgency. As I say, there is a lot of documentation that needs to be grabbed here and a lot of people who need to be examined. In terms of that documentation, the Queen's Council says:
I am instructed—
and I do not think anyone disputes this—
there is evidence available to prove that:

PARA.TAB: (1) at the initial meeting of the Board the Minister sought the members resign and indicated to the members that if there were any other appointments more congenial or convenient he was prepared to look at it.

SPEECH.PARA: Those minutes are critical. There is the fact that the minister wrote to each member seeking their resignation. He met with the board and asked for their resignations. All those documents and minutes are critical in terms of any full and honest investigation.

In a conversation with one member the minister indicated it might be that the member would be able to earn remuneration from the department if the member resigned from the board. That person also needs to be examined and questioned. The advice goes on, but I think the important thing here is we need to take into account the fact that, whereas this QC says quite clearly that there is a mountain of evidence—and I am using my words—to be assessed by an appropriate officer, this government has not taken that course. As he says, the advice of Mr Burmester does not examine the actions of the ministers, either separately or in combination, and specifically does not deal with the conduct of Mr Sharp. That is a very valid point. The QC says:

BREAK.PARA: The advice does not advert to any question of a matter arising of impropriety in public office.
No doubt this was because the Attorney-General did not seek advice on those matters although in my view it is those matters which raise considerable concern warranting inquiry.

One of the leading silks in the bar in New South Wales makes it very clear in this advice that there are matters which raise considerable concern warranting inquiry. He cites the only relevant precedent in this case in terms of the relevance of all the context of this matter. Yet the government, through the Leader of the Government in Senate (Senator Hill), came in here today and put on the public record quite clearly the government's view that there is a context, there is a saga here and there is a longstanding issue.

But having said that, contrary to the law of this country—and in fact the law of the United Kingdom, to the extent that that might be relevant—he then makes the assertion that all these matters are irrelevant. You cannot do that, Senator Hill. You cannot claim legally that all this background information, all this to-ing and fro-ing, is irrelevant.

For instance, how did it come about that Mr Fischer, the Deputy Prime Minister, handed the letter over to Gabi Hollows? The whole context of all these matters—the running public debate, the inducements to Ms Pollock as well as Gabi Hollows—has not been put to an appropriate legal officer. That then raises the point of who is an appropriate legal officer?

I must admit that I feel sorry for Mr Burmester. He is in the Attorney‐General's Department, he is there to provide legal advice. He could see the train coming yesterday—the Prime Minister's office, the Attorney‐General's office—with all of them wanting quick advice. You cannot get to the root cause of a matter like this unless you have a full assessment. That is the judgment of the Full Bench of the High Court of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr James has.

—In fact, what Mr James says is, `There are matters that warrant investigation.' He also reflects quite clearly that the law of this country demands that those matters be investigated. That is what Mr James says.

BREAK.PARA: The appropriate person to investigate these sorts of matters is not Mr Burmester—a person who has been given a couple of documents and asked to pass judgment on them, knowing that the full impact of the government's wrath is not just about to descend on him; it has been descending on his department for some time. We saw the last manifestation of it in the Australian on Monday when Glen Milne had been `fed the line' from the government that they were not happy with the government's advice from the Attorney-General's Department.

Mr Burmester is the same person who gave this government advice on the Wik case. He told them in that advice—a document which was put to cabinet by Ministers Herron and Williams, together with Parliamentary Secretary Minchin, last year—that you cannot extinguish native title and you should not. The advice from this person and the A‐G's department was that you should not extinguish native title. They rejected his advice there and set the bushfires going with Mr Fischer and Premier Borbidge. But, as I say, whereas they rejected his advice there, they were clutching at straws to get this advice here.

The right people to investigate this are the law enforcement agencies. If the Prime Minister is not going to do that, then there needs to be a judicial investigation. What you have here is evidence which is quite pertinent and evidence which, I fear, may not be present later down the track unless this investigation is done urgently. As I say, there are a whole raft of matters to be examined.

But what really makes a mockery of the Prime Minister's assertion that there is nothing to worry about is the fact that Mr Burmester came to his conclusion without examining one person. How can you claim that you have had a full investigation and assessment of these matters and not have one person examined? It would have been appropriate for Ms Hollows to have been asked about what inducements were offered, the meetings, including the one with Mr Sharp, and so on. It would have been appropriate for others on the board to have been asked. The victims of the inducement should have been examined—and, in fact, the perpetrators also. It makes a mockery of the whole judicial system if you can argue that one can come to a conclusion on guilt, without questioning the witnesses and without examining the suspects.

That is what we have been asked to do here. We have been asked basically to turn our heads to a case not just of a potential breach of section 73A but also one involving a whole raft of ministers, including the Deputy Prime Minister. And you have to ask how and to what extent the Prime Minister's office was involved here. We know that there was a meeting in the Prime Minister's office, so you have to ask to what extent the Prime Minister was involved in this.

This is nothing short of a potential case of conspiring to pervert the course of justice. This government's cover‐up, as indicated yesterday, its inability and unwillingness to examine these matters fully, is something that should not go unrecognised. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I would indicate to the Senate that I am not going to take 10 minutes, as there is really very little that needs responding to. When Senator Bolkus, with some drama, rose to speak in this debate, we thought he may have some new information, some information that may well bring the government down.

SPEECH.PARA: What that information has turned out to be is an advice, apparently from Mr James to we are not quite sure who, based on instructions of which we are not quite sure, about another barrister's opinion. It is a barrister giving an opinion on another barrister's opinion. I daresay that, if you gave this couple of pages over to another barrister to give an opinion on this barrister's opinion, you could get a different set of conclusions. Perhaps you could get any set of conclusions you wanted to. You could go around to whichever barrister you wanted to pick and ask him to give an opinion on another barrister's opinion. It is quite remarkable.

We do not know who this advice is to. It is rather remarkable in the way it is set out. It is some six years since I practised law, but I have never seen an advice like this. Neither have I ever seen an advice where there does not seem to be any basis for the instructions. Somewhere in this it says, `I am instructed that there is evidence available to prove that . . . ' That is apparently his instructions.

I wonder who gave him those instructions, what the evidence was, and what he was told the evidence was. Could I be right in thinking that he was given those instructions by some political people, perhaps the Australian Labor Party? Perhaps some senators or staffers have made up some facts; perhaps they have given him a set of facts which they seem to have got from somewhere and said, `Right, these are your instructions, now give us some advice on them; and here is another barrister's opinion, give us some advice on that.'

I do not know of Mr James, but that is my failure and not his, I might say. He is of senior counsel, so he obviously has some considerable ability at the law. But a counsel's advice can only be as good as the instructions that are given. If these instructions are given by the Australian Labor Party—a political group seeking a political opinion or a matter on a political issue—then one has to have some doubt as to just what this particular opinion says.

Regrettably, although Senator Bolkus spoke at some length on this—the advice has only just been handed to me, so I have not had a chance to have a look at it—but on the brief look that I have had it does not really seem to take the matter any further at all. There is nothing in what Senator Bolkus has raised that warrants any sort of response from the government at this particular stage. Perhaps if we knew a little more about the facts that were given to Mr James, perhaps if we were to get another eminent counsel to give an opinion on Mr James's opinion, then the matter could go further. But I do not think I need take the time of the Senate any longer to address this. There is really nothing in what was said that requires any sort of response.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for discussion has concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make some comments in respect of a clerk's document dated 13 February 1997 referring to Christmas Island.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The document I refer to is a letter by the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government, the Hon. Warwick Smith, to the chairman of the Casino Surveillance Authority concerning a dispute between Christmas Island Resort Pty Ltd and Casinos Austria International (Christmas Island) Pty Ltd. Because the casino has such a significant effect on the economy of Christmas Island, this matter was drawn to the attention of the Australian public by Mr Dave McLean, who is the representative of the employees through their union in that area. The dispute has arisen in such a way as to have an effect on the operation of the casino and therefore the operation of the hotel.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr McLean reported to the public, as I understand it, that, because the casino operator was now no longer prepared to allow the so-called high rollers from South‐East Asia to wager to the extent they would like to, the casino's operations were prejudiced, the hotel's operations were prejudiced and that was affecting the employment of the community on Christmas Island.

I do not profess to be an expert about Christmas Island, but I do know in relation to that particular part of the world there is not a lot of employment available and they do depend heavily on the operation of the casino for their economy. That casino, for its success, depends on drawing the gamblers and other visitors from the South‐East Asian region.

It is pretty well known, I think, that people who frequent the Christmas Island casino often go there not only because it is close to where they live but also because they have been able to wager large amounts. They do not travel to bet $2 or $5 on a turn of a roulette wheel. They go there because they are able to gamble to the extent that they would like to.

BREAK.PARA: Because of the dispute, as I understand it, as reported by Mr McLean, between the hotel operator and the casino operator, the casino is now not taking wagers of any significant amount. That means that the so-called high rollers are not travelling to Christmas Island to use the hotel or the casino and that means the employment of the locals is drastically affected. Whilst that circumstance continues, the economy of Christmas Island will suffer.

It is urgent. I do support the reference to the Casino Surveillance Authority of this matter by the minister. I would urge that the matter be attended to expeditiously and that, if need be, the casino operators and indeed the hotel operators be replaced by operators who are prepared to have regard to the needs of that economy rather than whatever is provoking the dispute which exists between them.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will now return to the orders of the day relating to government documents. There are 110 government documents listed for consideration on today's Notice Paper and there is a limit of one hour for their consideration. To expedite the consideration of the documents, I propose, with the concurrence of honourable senators, to call the documents in groups of 10. Documents called in each group to which no senator rises will be taken to be discharged from the Notice Paper . Documents not called on today will remain on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for not being in my seat when Senator O'Brien finished. I seek leave to comment for no more than two minutes on the matter that Senator O'Brien raised.

—Does that include dialogue with this side of the chamber in regard to that request? I understand the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Kemp) got very uptight earlier this afternoon when a similar request was made from this side of the chamber. If courtesies are expected from one side of the chamber they are indeed expected from the other side.

—Senator McGauran, there was some confusion earlier in the day in so far as the matter that Senator O'Brien spoke on. He probably did not have to seek leave, given that it was a matter of business on the Notice Paper . So for that purpose, unless—
—I will get to the whip in a moment, Senator McKiernan. With regard to any exchange of time, I think Senator Ian Macdonald probably has a right. Senator McGauran, would you like to add something?
—Yes, I would invite Senator Ian Macdonald to speak on this, but I cannot allow Senator McKiernan's comments to go unchallenged.
—Senator McGauran, I think it might be better if we do not challenge. Indeed, I think it might be more appropriate to call Senator Ian Macdonald.
—If he had any graciousness, he would withdraw his comments. He has jumped the gun, as is Senator McKiernan's wont.
—Senator McGauran, would you resume your seat. Senator Ian Macdonald, you have some words to say with regard to the Christmas Island report.
—I will take Senator McKiernan's kindly smile not as an apology but as an acknowledgment that his point of order and the aggression with which he delivered it was perhaps inappropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to more or less concur with what Senator O'Brien has indicated, and to say that the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government (Mr Warwick Smith) has perhaps established this inquiry for the reasons and because of the concerns that Senator O'Brien has raised. I am pleased that Senator O'Brien supports the government's proposal to try to get some resolution of what is obviously a matter of some great concern on Christmas Island. It is certainly the case, As Senator O'Brien said, that there are not great opportunities for employment on Christmas Island, apart from tourism. The casino was a major attempt to attract tourism, and tourism of a particular class, to the island. If there are problems with tourism on that basis, then I think it is appropriate that as a government and as a parliament we do what we can to resolve that. It is pleasing to have Senator O'Brien's support for the government's initiative in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I have some comments to make ever so briefly on the matter. I speak as Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories. I endorse Senator O'Brien's comments. Some six months ago, the minister and I visited Christmas Island when this matter was just starting to brew. Now it has broken wide open.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember that when the issue of the casino first came to the Senate it was controversial: should one be set up or should it not? It really did split the Senate. But it has proven to be very beneficial for the island because of employment. There are not many opportunities there and, of course, it drags in the tourist dollar. The other opportunity is phosphate. To its credit, the union took over the phosphate mine, after it was shut down by the company, and is running it very successfully. Other than that, there is only the casino on the island. The union on Christmas Island is taking great interest not only in the phosphate mine but also in the troubles of their workers at the casino. They have been faxing the minister and me and keeping us updated on the matter.

More particularly, in relation to the portfolio of the minister, the minister and I met with the licence holder of the casino, Mr Sumampow, and the managers of the casino, Casinos Austria International Ltd. They are at loggerheads, and the situation has reached a very serious point. This casino once turned over billions of dollars a year; now it has come to a grinding halt. The high rollers are not coming into Christmas Island any more. The maximum bet allowed at the casino is $50. That is the absurd situation that has come about because of the dispute between the licence holder and the management. There are many opinions about who exactly is at fault. That is why Senator O'Brien is quite right in saying that we should get to the crux of this matter.

Australia's reputation is very much on the line. The present government—as with the previous government—takes great interest in the happenings on Christmas Island because of its position so close to Indonesia. We cannot have one of our outposts, one of our territories, in such a mess financially and its reputation held up to ridicule. Quite frankly, at the moment the dispute between the casino operators and management has reached the absurd stage. It is greatly affecting the people of the island, and they deserve better.

The report is of importance. These outposts cannot be forgotten. We so often focus only on the mainland of Australia, but we have territories like the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, Christmas Island and Norfolk Island and others. We have to have an equal involvement in them as a government. Senator O'Brien, you have brought important matters to the Senate. We on this side of the chamber are acting upon them with great diligence. We do not underestimate the importance of the matter to the people of Christmas Island.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I also want to join with Senator McGauran in commending Senator O'Brien for bringing this matter to the attention of the Senate this afternoon. It is an extremely important issue for the people of Christmas Island and for those who have an interest in the continuing development of that island, that beautiful area off the Western Australian coast. It is not part of my electorate; it comes into the electorate of the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: I also commend Senator McGauran for paying tribute to the very good work, over a large number of years, of the Union of Christmas Island Workers and the contribution that they have been able to make to the continued development of the island. There are grave fears on the island about the island's future and what is going to happen. There are hopes that this inquiry that has been initiated by the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government (Mr Warwick Smith) can be concluded quickly and successfully for all parties, without making comment on who is at fault and who is not at fault.

The reason I want to bring this to the attention of the Senate and urge expediency in the resolution of the matter is that it is having much wider ramifications than on just the island itself or on those high rollers, those gamblers, who visit the island to chance their luck on the tables.

I think it is this weekend that the only international airline link between mainland Australia and Christmas Island is going to cease. National Jet Systems operate between Broome and Christmas Island and they have given notice that the service is going to cease from Monday of next week. That is another reason that I suggest that, while it may not be directly impacted by the matter that is under investigation by the casino control ordinances, nonetheless it is a further example of why the matter ought to be resolved as speedily and as justly as possible.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 December 1996, on motion by Senator Hogg:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —Although this matter has been on the Notice Paper for quite some time, it is appropriate that some words are mentioned about Foreign Affairs and Trade in the Senate in February. The Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Alexander Downer, has just returned from an extensive trip to Europe where he talked with our trading partners in that part of the world.
—With some help from the British government.

—With the mention of the British government we are reminded, indeed, Senator Carr, of the wonderful joke about bath towels that our minister told when he was over there. He implied that the British people would not know what bath towels were—but I think he retracted it quickly.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter that I did want to address and, hopefully, it will be a great subject matter in next year's Foreign Affairs and Trade report, is Australia's decision not to sign a human rights clause that is contained within the trade agreement with the European Community. In some parts of Europe, this is causing grave concern as to why a country like Australia, a country of the First World, a developed nation, is so backward about signing a human rights clause, which is something which is a matter of course.

The reason that I am motivated to bring further attention to this matter today—although it does not stand Australia in good stead and I am very loath to in any way knock Australia—is that yesterday I had the privilege of meeting members of a delegation from the French parliament, from their foreign affairs committee, who were in this country. During a working lunch with that delegation, mention was made of the fact that, in recent times, what French people have heard about Australia most has been related to one member of the other place, the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). It is in that context that they had an understanding of Australia.

Previous to that, their understanding of Australia and their knowledge of Australia was related to our opposition to France's testing its nuclear weapons in our backyard. Of course, that has put some strains on the relationship with this country.

When you compound those three events—Australia's pretty vigorous opposition to the French testing, which I acknowledge crossed party lines; their knowledge of the publicity surrounding some of the comments by the member for Oxley; and now Australia's reluctance to sign a human rights clause in a trade agreement—one must wonder what French people think of Australia.

I would hope that our Minister for Foreign Affairs, who has just returned from visiting a number of countries in Europe as well as some other parts of the world, will be putting increased and enhanced efforts into building Australia's reputation in that area. It is not the only area of the world that the foreign minister and other ministers of this government have to put effort into. Certainly, they cannot neglect the area in which we are located, that is the South‐East Asian region where you have to build many bridges—and I do not mean only in the physical sense of building a bridge across the Mekong. We have to build many more bridges because many of our relationships have been damaged in this region since this government came to office, not the least of which by the reportage of certain comments by the member for Oxley.

It is something that the members of the parliamentary friendship group with France sought to address yesterday when they met with the French foreign affairs committee. They did tell the committee about the motion condemning anti-racist comment that was moved successfully by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) last year at the behest of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley). They were not aware of that. It is only the negatives that get reported to that degree. The onus is on the Minister for Foreign Affairs—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McKiernan has raised a very important matter. As others before me have said, you really have to divide the issues. I do not think anyone anywhere in the world can critically accuse Australia of having a poor human rights record. I think our human rights record over the years—I might say, Senator McKiernan, in the time of even your government—has been second to none. I do not think anyone seriously challenges that proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia will continue to push for the rights of all human beings, no matter where and when they are. But we will do this in the appropriate forums with the appropriate devices. Annexing these sorts of clauses to trade agreements, which are really agreements related to trade, is just, in my mind, quite silly. They are completely separate issues. You make agreements for trade by talking about trade issues, talking about advancing the welfare of all countries in the world by having the freest and easiest form of exchange of goods and services. That is what trade agreements are about. That is what trade discussions and forums are held for. But that should not be confused by human rights addendums.

BREAK.PARA: We have a proud record of human rights. We will continue to pursue that and continue to make all Australians proud of the way their governments, regardless of political colour, pursue the question of human rights. Certainly, this government will be as much to the fore as, if not more to the fore than, the previous government in that regard.

It is tremendous to see the French delegation here. We look forward to very close relationships with the French parliament and, in fact, all parliamentarians right throughout the world. I could not quite follow your logic, Senator McKiernan, when you said that the French worry about us because of three issues, one of which was our objection to their testing nuclear weapons in our backyard. I do not point the finger at anyone or at any nation. I do not think it is appropriate for me, or perhaps any Australian, to lecture other countries on how they should run things although I, like others, was very concerned about the French testing in our backyard, or anywhere in the world.

But I wonder what the French explanation was for the human rights of those people who would have been affected by that nuclear testing. Perhaps some of the things that were said to us by some of our European friends could have been looked at a bit more closely when we were determining the rights of those living in the Pacific islands, the rights of those living in Australasia and the rights of those of us living in east Asia when the French were testing nuclear weapons. Again, I do not make any accusation or comment, but I raise the matter of Senator McKiernan's joining a blaming of Australia for not saying something about human rights with a comment about the French being concerned about us and our attitude to their testing of nuclear weapons.

As is quite often the case on some of these occasions—I certainly make it clear that I am not talking about the French particularly here—people who are saying to us that we should include in trade agreements comments about human rights have records on human rights that are nowhere near as good as Australia's record. I as a private citizen sometimes wonder if perhaps a little bit of action might speak louder than words on those occasions.

In conclusion, the matter Senator McKiernan raised is a very important one. On no occasion will Australia resile from its commitment to human rights, but we think it should be done in the appropriate place at the appropriate time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia really does have a proud record on human rights. That goes for not just this government but also governments past throughout the decades. I do not think any nation would challenge our human rights record. If they did, they would be ungracious and would certainly have an improper motive for doing so.

SPEECH.PARA: Our human rights record is proud, and it is proven through two examples. The first is our voting pattern through the United Nations. That is where we stamp our credentials in regard to human rights. We have not failed to uphold in the strongest terms the highest ideals in regard to human rights.

The other example of how a country respects human rights is through its political system. Australia, with its mix of predominantly the Westminster system and the American system, has the freest and most tolerant of political systems, with all the democratic checks and balances that are required in our political system. How stable, certain and tolerant it is stands up against just about all, if not all, political systems in the world. It is a truly democratic system with the best mix of the British Westminster system, a bit of Australian thrown in and, of course, the powers of the Senate err more towards the American system.

We have nothing to hide in regard to human rights. All this government is saying is that there is a time and a place to voice those human rights and to single the issue out. The issue should not be mixed or confused, as would be the case if it were tied in with trade. The danger in doing that is that you devalue the issue, you devalue your voice for human rights and you cause obvious contradictions.

BREAK.PARA: As a nation, Australia has a proud record on human rights. We do not believe we should contradict ourselves by mixing it with trade. There is a time and a place. We have proven, in our voting patterns with the United Nations, that we do not resile from the strongest ideals.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

I preface my remarks by simply indicating that Senator Allison of the Australian Democrats came down to the chamber to speak on one of these documents. If she was intending to do that, it might be an appropriate time for her to return to the chamber. I do not know which document she wanted to speak about, so I cannot move to take note of it on her behalf and seek leave to continue my remarks.

Document No. 103 is a report on the National Crime Authority for the year 1995-96. As senators would know, this authority was established by the states, the territories and the Commonwealth to fight organised crime. The authority has been given powers that exceed those which the state and federal police forces have. Having been given those additional powers—extra authorities, over and above the normal authorities—the authority has to exercise those increased powers very carefully.

I recently retired from the parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. Nothing I say in this very brief contribution is in any way anything confidential that I gleaned from my time on that committee. My understanding is that the parliamentary committee is having a general inquiry into the National Crime Authority for a number of reasons. One of those is the concern in some people's minds, including my own, that the National Crime Authority may have entered into the political arena several years ago when it embarked upon an investigation of a prominent Victorian.

Without making any comment on the innocence, guilt or otherwise of that gentleman—I am certainly not in a position to raise that—I inform the Senate of a matter that has always concerned me: whether investigations of that nature fitted into the brief of the National Crime Authority on organised crime. My understanding and that of ordinary Australians and I think most parliamentarians is—perhaps this is not the technical legal interpretation—that that authority was established to look at organised crime, that is crime involving what is referred to in the media and in fictitious TV programs as the Mafia and Triads—the real organised crime.

One wonders whether the NCA has in some of its investigations followed that part of its charter. I am sure that the parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority will investigate that and other matters in its determinations in the near future. I think it is important that the parliament has the ultimate confidence in that authority. I am sure the authority does tremendous work in a very difficult area, but it is important that the parliament watches over, so to speak, these powers, these authorities. I am sure the joint committee, under the chairmanship of Mr Bradford, will very thoroughly look at all aspects of the work of the National Crime Authority so that the authority can continue its good work now and into the future in looking after the Australian national interest. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 November, on motion by Senator Woodley:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the reasons I briefly want to comment on the annual report of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation is that recently we had a briefing at Parliament House with the new managing director of that organisation, Mr Adrian Kloeden, who also happens to be the Managing Director of the International Wool Secretariat. Being a wool grower myself and representing a lot of wool growers, I must say things have not been that bright in the wool industry of late but I was heartened by some of the comments he made. I was particularly impressed by his attitude as the managing director of that organisation. After all is said and done, the wool growers of Australia have been pouring millions of dollars into that organisation over the years. That has produced many great outcomes, but in recent times some questions have been raised, quite rightly, about whether they are getting value for money.

SPEECH.PARA: The amount of money being paid in by government has reduced. In 1995-96, wool growers contributed $87 million in wool tax, $11 million was contributed by the government and another $11 million was contributed by others. Contributions made to the International Wool Secretariat, an international organisation, totalled about $98 million. When we look at the funding of the International Wool Secretariat, we find that Australia provides—to me, not surprisingly—92 per cent of that money.

I remember visiting the International Wool Secretariat a few years ago in Paris. I was warned then by the people working there that perhaps the funding was not being put to the best of use, and in fact promotion had almost fallen away, to the detriment of the industry. I think if you look back over the last few years, you see that there is no doubt that the lack of money being put into promotion has had quite a dramatic effect on the usage of wool. There have been plenty of other effects, of course. I was pleased to hear the opinions of the new managing director, who is a private enterprise orientated person. He is taking a whole new outlook on the situation. He says:
Great opportunities lie ahead, and with a freshly invigorated business‐based philosophy, AWRAP will continue to go out and meet the challenges head‐on.

They have. One of the innovative new ways that they have tried to improve our sales of wool overseas is to gain access into Mexico, sell our wool tops into Mexico, have the wool processed there and then be able to get the cloth duty free into America. Up until now Australia itself has had a non-tariff barrier of quite significant amount preventing us from exporting to that key market.

The annual report does point out that, whilst there has been a dwindling income for wool, there are other ways growers can maximise their returns, and that is by being more efficient. A lot of the activities carried out by this wool research corporation are into new technology. It is very good to see that they have put quite a bit of money into soils and pasture management programs. My colleague Senator Heffernan would know all about that, being a wool grower himself. I note also that there has been quite a deal of money and some very good results in long‐life combs and cutters. If anybody has ever been mixed up with the shearing industry, they would know that that is in itself a significant advance.

When we were in the IPU visiting the Baltic states a couple of years ago, we visited the Drobe Wool Enterprise in Lithuania. At that time Australia had started investing money into that enterprise. I am pleased to see that, as a result of Australia's interest and encouragement, this particular mill has lifted its usage from 50,000 kilograms in 1992 to 700,000 kilograms last year. Those sorts of enterprises that have been encouraged by the International Wool Secretariat and the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organi sation, even though they have a reduced budget, are the types of things that will put wool back on track and put money back into wool growers' pockets.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate notes, with concern, the failure of the Government to adequately administer or defend key aspects of the Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs portfolio and, specifically, the Federal Government's:

(a) unwillingness to address concerns of the higher education community about the problem of declining demand for university courses, particularly in regional Australia, resulting from increased Higher Education Contribution Scheme fees;
(b) complete abrogation of its responsibilities to ensure an adequate supply of science and engineering graduates;
(c) reduction of training and labour market programs;
(d) lack of a sustainable policy to address long-term unemployment; and
(e) inadequate defence of public education and abandonment of a long-standing commitment to the provision of quality, universally accessible and equitable public education.

Earlier this week the Senate discussed the issue of the position within this government of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone), highlighting the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) had sought to undermine her authority and position within the government by allowing her junior minister, the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Dr Kemp, responsibilities for the new work for the dole scheme. That was a scheme that this government had dreamt up over the weekend as an attempt to divert attention away from the various scandals and difficulties that it was facing—an attempt, of course, driven by the pollsters within the Liberal Party secretariat, aiming at distracting attention away from the gross inadequacies of this government. This is a pattern that has emerged in recent times within the government, and particularly within this portfolio.

I indicated earlier in the week that the opposition extended its sympathy to the minister because of the concerns that must undoubtedly be being felt within her office at the constant, determined and persistent efforts being made by her colleagues, her ministerial colleagues, to undermine her within the government. Now we see that the Prime Minister is supporting her detractors within the ministry and weakening her position, her authority and her capacity to effectively administer this portfolio.

Upon reflection, I thought that perhaps this was in itself not the full story; that our sympathy should go to the minister on a broader range of issues, because after all this seems now to be a bit of a pattern within her career. It is really sad, when you think about it, that she came into this parliament in 1984 as a person presenting herself as representing the views of the wets within the Liberal Party, the so-called progressives within the Liberal Party. She has had to face and struggle against her opponents within the Liberal Party—the dries, represented by Senator Minchin and others. Of course, this is a struggle that has continued since 1984.

She sought, I think, in many respects—and we saw this with her interest particularly in law reform—to present progressive views and liberal views in some areas. But what does she find when she gets into government? She of course is obliged to introduce policies which will see those educational programs cut dramatically; she will in fact have to do the bidding for the most conservative elements within the Liberal Party; she has become effectively the agent for the dries within the Liberal Party. I am sure that is a frustration that she feels quite strongly.

Despite the fact that she was seeking so strenuously to be the Attorney-General in the Liberal government, she ended up with what she regarded as the booby prize. It is the third largest portfolio within the government. You would think it is a matter of great significance, that it is a portfolio that has enormous political, social and economic significance for this country. You would think that she would actually regard it as a job that required some real attention, had some real worth. Unfortunately, that is not the approach that she took.

In fact, in this last budget, we saw her administer policies which amounted to the reduction of some $4.3 billion in the budget outlays for her department over the forward estimates period. Here we have it: a person who comes into politics as the great progressive ending up implementing the policies of her arch factional rivals within the Liberal Party. You can understand her frustration in that regard.

In the higher education area in particular we saw that she has introduced policies under this budget which have seen the reduction in expenditure of some $1.821 billion dollars. That is provided on page 22 of volume No. 1 of the additional information received by the Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee. In the vocational education and training area she, as a senior minister, is administering policies which see the gutting of the Australian National Training Authority. She will see the quite dramatic undermining of the whole training reform agenda. She will see the reduction of some $137 million for vocational education and training over the forward estimates period.

But of course it is in the labour market programs that we see the really big cuts being made, where the really savage, draconian, ruthless and heartless actions are being taken by this government to reduce assistance, by some $1.958 billion, for persons who are unemployed. That is nearly $2 billion worth of reductions in assistance to people who are unemployed. We heard last weekend this government's miserable, petty scheme to provide assistance to persons who are unemployed. It is a miserable, pathetic scheme which, of course, is aimed at harbouring the most prejudiced views about people that are unfortunate enough not to be able to find work within our community. A right that is being denied is a nature of our economic system and the failure of our economy to provide adequate work for all.

What does this government do? It blames the victim. It seeks to establish in the minds of the public that the reason we have unem ployment is that the unemployed are there and that, somehow or other, the unemployed themselves are to blame. Instead of having a program of assistance which is based on a balanced approach between employment and training and education and training, as we saw under the previous government's Working Nation, this regime has sought to blame the victim.

It has sought to attack viciously those persons who are unemployed and to try to de‐legitimise people in a way that means that the public turns on those who are unemployed. Instead of providing assistance, they say that it is not appropriate to provide assistance. But when the government gets into trouble—political scandal after political scandal surrounds this government—they have to dredge up a new device to distract attention away from the difficulties.

This minister has to also administer cuts to education assistance, income support, youth policy support and Aboriginal education. In total, student, youth and Aboriginal education support has been reduced by nearly half a billion dollars. That is $4.59 billion in the forward estimates period which will be reduced from this portfolio as a result of the budget. The total budget savings introduced in this budget amount to $4.3 billion. It is little wonder that the minister finds it frustrating in a new job.

She made it perfectly clear from the moment she came into this position that she did not really want it. She made comment upon comment which suggested to me that she is having great difficulty adjusting to her new role. For instance, I recall, there was a famous speech that she gave at the national conference of the Australian Association for the Education of Gifted and Talented in Adelaide back in April last year in which she said that education has had it too good for too long.

She announced that, since becoming a minister, her most important decision had been that the letterhead should be black to save confusion when changing trays on the photocopier. She knew the difficulties that she would face in this new job. She announced that she was going to buy a Paddington Bear yellow mac `because of the garbage that would be hurled at me when I visit universities.'
The opposition does feel for her with her approach to these great issues of the nation, her approach to these high policy matters—
Senator Conroy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, of course there is the issue of her fashion sense as well. But the real question is her attitude to this portfolio. What we have seen in this last budget is that this government has reduced the total outlays going to this portfolio from 11 per cent to nine per cent of total government outlays in the forward estimates period. This is a government that is determined to undermine this portfolio as a priority within this government.

SPEECH.PARA: Actions of course speak much louder than words, but the words themselves are very interesting. I remember Senator Vanstone describing students as the ugly face of self‐interest, defining students as little brutes squealing like stuck pigs when faced with the problems that she of course was administering.

TALK.START.PARA: —She didn't say that?

—She did indeed say that. She suggested on one occasion in September 1996, when confronted with the very strong reaction from within the higher education sector, that universities should stop whingeing and start dobbing. She said that academics should dob in wasteful universities by leaking information—to her, of course, and to her department—that they should stop whingeing and start dobbing. She said, `I am sick of hearing comments from universities that, "We'll have to cut courses and staff."' She said, `I am yet to hear one of them say, "We will improve our management or make administrative changes."' She said that they should contact the media to alert the community to waste.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a government very concerned about waste, isn't it? We have seen a whole frontbench over there which is very wasteful indeed. The minister suggested that people should place a piece of paper in a brown paper bag to raise problems. We all understand what is meant by that, don't we? Some times a bit of public embarrassment is the way to do it, she said. Vice‐chancellors pretty well get anything they want from the university councils, she said. She said there were huge problems that had to be confronted and suggested that the way to do it was to stop whingeing and start dobbing.

The minister was, frankly, having great difficulties communicating this government's policies, and I can understand her frustrations in doing that, because she had a very straightforward approach: if people did not agree with her position, she announced she would simply `rip your arms off'. She would, of course, find it a great difficulty that university chiefs were feeling `helpless and totally dependent on government in seeking to cope with changes facing their own institutions'. She suggested that `those who are entrusted to light the path are afraid of the dark'.

Again we have a classic case of a government which is determined to blame the victims for their present circumstances. And this is a government which has inflicted great pain and suffering upon our higher education institutions. The government has approached quite profound issues in a most simplistic manner. It has sought to suggest that the minister's massive changes in policy were, as she said in September `just a nick; you won't even have to put a bandaid on it'. She suggested that `apparently if you lose one per cent the end of the world has come'. There is nothing like that. We saw some 17,000 university places taken out of the system as a result of this government's changes.

Is it any wonder that there was such a reaction to the government's budget? Is it not therefore also any wonder that in this climate there should be such turmoil engulfing the higher education community, that there should be the national disgrace of the inaction at the rising levels of unemployment and the rising levels of inequality that were a direct result of this government's failure in terms of the administration of this portfolio and the policy directions this government is taking, particularly in education and training. You have got budgetary measures which are aimed at the removal of some $4.3 billion from DEETYA's funding over the forward estimates period.

It is a result that comes directly from the vandalism that this government has inflicted. We see rising unemployment, declining levels of demand for university courses and a deterioration in the public education system. So at all levels, in all divisions of her portfolio, this minister is facing enormous problems. A very deep‐seated crisis is emerging and she has failed to administer it properly. As I say, the opposition has some sympathy for her because we understand how difficult it must be for her to be able to confront these enormous problems when she is being so constantly undermined from within her own ranks. It must be extraordinary not to be able to rely upon the support of her Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Minchin wants a job.

—This is another difficulty, Senator Conroy. The ambition faction within the Liberal Party makes it extremely difficult for her to concentrate on the task that she is faced with. It is no wonder that the national newspapers cover a significant disaster in national education and training policies week by week. Week by week we are faced with the stories of shame that arise from this government in terms of this minister's failure to address very serious concerns being expressed by scholars, by academics, by business people, by trade unionists—by ordinary Australians. Every aspect of her portfolio is under severe public criticism. Just take a few of the comments that have been made. Former University of Canberra chancellor and distinguished author Donald Horne made the point that Vanstone is a disaster. Mr Horne described the minister as a `real disaster', stating that `she had no understanding of the fact that there are public benefits in universities'. Perhaps even more damning was his belief that `the present minister has lowered the debate to a depth that might be unparalleled in the liberal democratic world'.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not totally blame the minister for her actions. Her inability to constructively deal with the growing wave of criticism of her policies is systematic of the way this govern ment forsakes all the conventions of ministerial responsibility—

TALK.START.PARA: —Symptomatic.

—You know, Senator Herron, exactly what I am talking about—all the conventions of ministerial responsibility. It is symptomatic of the government's dogmatic 1950s attitude, the belief that we can turn back this country to the way the world might have been in some idealised vision of the elitism of the 1950s. The great patriarchs of our society will be able to come forward and suggest that we should have a university system for the rich and the powerful, we should have a system of school education for the rich and the powerful, we should have governments that are aimed at providing business welfare at large; but no support, or very limited support, for social security recipients, for the unemployed, for any people who do not measure up to your ideas of success. This is a government that assumes that the rich and the powerful are entitled to support through the university system and through the school system but that that support should not extend to all Australians; that facilities and opportunities should not be made available to all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen the desperate defences made by this government in denying what is obvious to all: the university system is already beginning to fall apart as a result of this government's budgetary policies. In response to a seven per cent decline in demand and plummeting entry scores in terms of the TER cut‐offs, we have heard the government first make their puerile claims that it was too early to evaluate the effects of the HECS increases. They then said it was the fault of the schools and then it was the fault of the universities. And, guess what, it will ultimately be the fault of the students themselves, because we have a mentality here that you blame the victim. Of course, the real victim here ultimately will be the minister herself. As I say, we have some sympathy for her in the struggles that she is facing in these matters.

It is very easy to blame everybody else except the minister and this government at large. This view stands in very sharp contrast to that of the experts right across the educa tion and training sectors of this economy. It stands in contrast with the views of experts such as the head of the New South Wales Vice‐Chancellors Conference, Professor Cliff Blake, who recently described the number of vacant places as unprecedented. Dr Rice, the President of the Australian Council of Deans of Science, said, `The effects of increases in the higher education contribution scheme could not be underestimated.' Professor Tim Brown, who chairs Melbourne University's selection committee, said, `It would be surprising if higher fees had no impact on student choice.'

Even the National Party itself—the great scholars of this parliament—said that it was very concerned to see that the minister was unable to meet the responsibilities of her portfolio. It was very concerned in particular about the increases to HECS. The Nationals understand that there is considerable damage being done to our regional universities as a result of the changes to higher education and the introduction of such draconian higher education fees.

The facts are very clear. When the government released its higher education budget statement on 9 August, some 11 days before the 1996-97 budget, the higher education community reeled. In its first budget, the government totally abandoned a whole series of pre‐election promises and so-called guarantees. It slashed some $2 billion from the sector.

The government cut some $623 million from operating grants to universities and some $214 million from the discretionary funds, which are funds used by the university to enhance the quality of its teaching and its research. So much for the promise the government made about promoting quality and excellence in research and teaching. It made so much of that in the election campaign. The universities were also made to bear the cost of a $300 million academic salary increase.

In short, the government has slashed some 17,000 Commonwealth funded places from the higher education sector, from the university sector. It is not just the universities that are being deceived. The 1996-97 budget added a massive $1.1 billion in additional costs to students. It replaced the single level HECS charge with a three-tiered structure, increasing the annual debt levels by between 35 per cent and 125 per cent. It lowered the repayment threshold by almost $8,000 and in 1998 we will see the introduction of the full fee paying places.

The government has abandoned the concept of merit and has gone back to the old scheme where wealth and privilege can buy both a place at university and all the rewards that that confers. You want to be clear about what you are doing. Do not try to deceive the Australian people in the manner in which you are trying to return to a scheme based on privilege and wealth and are trying to take away from Australian universities their mass character and their character which the Labor government was able to introduce by allowing more and more Australians to participate in the university sector.

Although the government has set a 25 per cent cap on fee paying places, many believe that the major purpose of the West review, which is currently under way, is to expand the whole privatisation of the university sector. That point is certainly being rammed home by the AVCC acting president, Professor Geoff Wilson, who stated that the government, through the West inquiry `was trying very hard to achieve a significant shift from public to private funding' and `more deregulation with respect to fees would be a fairly likely scenario to result from the inquiry'.

The government's agenda is for a small, elitist university sector. It is quite apparent that the effect of the 90 per cent rise in HECS for science and engineering students will produce that sort of result in those sectors. We see significant drops in demand for those particular courses throughout the country. Cut-off scores have plummeted in Melbourne. The combined science and engineering degrees at Monash University have dropped more than 10 points, a statistic repeated or exceeded throughout the country.

The reduction is so severe in Victoria that the tertiary education minister has established a committee to examine the drift of higher achieving students away from science and technology, and has called on universities to subsidise science and engineering students. In New South Wales they have gone even further with the University of New South Wales actually offering to pay the difference between last year's HECS fees and the new rate.

The minister has the nerve to continue to rant that her increased HECS fees are not the source of the problem. Sydney University Vice-chancellor, Professor Gavin Brown, summarised the true situation when he told students last year that the change to a three-tiered HECS system was `a gratuitous act of violence which showed a lack of understanding on the part of politicians about the impact of their decisions'.

The impact has been felt not just by the university students but also by the staff. With major sackings occurring nationally as a result of the budget cuts and the constant attacks on the sector by this government, staff morale has plummeted. The effects that such low academic morale and disillusionment will have on the learning environment are yet to be seen, but one can see a situation in which there has to be an eroding of the quality of teaching standards and an undermining of the drive for excellence that one would expect all our universities to be striving for.

In the schools area we see a similar shift away from equity to privilege. We see a similar shift away in government priorities. In terms of general grants to the states and course specific purpose payments, we see a net reduction of some $387 million in Commonwealth funding for schools, public schools in particular.

The abandonment of the new schools policy will directly aid the privileged in our society. It will provide additional resources for the private sector at the expense of the public sector. It will deliberately see an undermining of this country's commitment to public education. As a result of the government's changes, we will see a net gain of some $150 million over four years to private schools in direct grants alone, while government schools will suffer a $177 million reduction over the same period.

This transference of funds under the government's so‐called enrolment benchmark adjustments has seen all states in this country condemn that measure. It has seen a new device added to the scheme of undermining pubic education by the use—and I think the cynical use—of the concept of choice in this regard without having regard to the fact that choices are being extended to some at the expense of the many.

Of course, you will see this classic case being repeated over and over again, a situation recently highlighted by the Bulla Primary School in Victoria. That school had 42 students in it when the Kennett government closed it. The Victorian government forced it to close, like the 300 schools in Victoria which have been forcefully closed as a result of that government. Forty‐two school students at the Bulla school left because it was forced to close.

What has happened? The same site has been used to reopen a new school, but it is a private school. And guess how many students are there: 21. So much for the rhetoric of choice. The huge undermining of public education that is occurring in Victoria is being repeated across this country. It has been directly facilitated by the policies of this government.

You can see a situation where, in funding for vocational studies, private school students will get the benefit of government support of some $1,700 per student. But funding for students undertaking vocational studies in government schools is some $300 per student. We even see discrimination in the Catholic sector, where the amount of money is from $433.

It is not just discrimination about private versus public—which is abundantly clear—but discrimination about particular private schools, particularly the Catholic systemic model, against the more wealthy private schools. A recent report by Monash University has shown that Victorian schools are now forcing parents to raise some $200 million in addition to the amount of money being provided for their so-called non‐salary cost of delivering educational programs through their various fundraising activities.

This is a government which in all sectors of this portfolio is committed to the privatisation of what ought be a public responsibility and which requires the full support of this government but which is not enjoying that full support. We have a minister who is constantly being undermined from within this government, a minister who is obliged to introduce the most draconian measures and the most hostile of environments.

She came into this parliament as the great libertarian. We hear her day after day saying to us, `Listen here, sport, if you do not like what you are getting, we will rip your arms off.' This is the great libertarian, the great moderate of the Liberal Party, who is under constant attacks from the more extremist elements, such as those represented by Dr Kemp.

So we do have some sympathy for this minister. We know she does not really believe in anything she is doing. She does not actually believe in the quality of education, to begin with. She does not actually support the value of this portfolio and its work within this government. I understand how difficult it must be. But to have to face up to the constant criticism from within her own government! She came here to represent the progressive views of the Liberal Party in South Australia and finds herself constantly undermined by her colleagues. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth, Sen Judith

TALK.START.PARA: —It was no surprise to those of us on this side of the chamber to hear Senator Carr end his speech in the same way that he began it—talking about factions. Senator Carr, you must be so preoccupied with the problems of the ALP in Victoria that I am really delighted that you would find time to devote to a debate like this.

SPEECH.PARA: We came into this chamber expecting a discussion on the items which you have put forward under this general notice of motion, like higher education, labour market and training programs, the long-term unemployed and public education. But, no, we heard half of your speech being devoted to a dissection of factional tactics which are so beloved by you, and that is what you would sooner talk about.

Senator Conroy further trivialised this debate when Senator Carr was talking about the portfolio of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone). I do not know whether the remark was taken down in Hansard, but Senator Conroy described it as a mickey mouse portfolio. So that would give us Senator Conroy's impression of these very important matters. Far from it being a mickey mouse portfolio, these are very important matters.

I refer to them one by one. The government is, of course, most concerned that interest in participating in higher education is maintained throughout the Australian community. As Senator Carr correctly remarked, the department is monitoring the number of applications and enrolments each year. For him to say that it is early days yet is true. It is early days—it is the first academic year after these changes have been brought in. So how would it be possible to be doing anything else at this stage but monitoring the results of our changes to see how they are going to operate?

The government has already indicated its intention to make adjustments if there is clear evidence that increased HECS charges are significantly affecting enrolments in particular courses. Analysis of the applications data so far shows that the number of year 12 applicants for 1997 admissions has not been influenced by the latest HECS charges. There are other factors that operate which influence the number of students who enrol for each course. Demand for places overall by non‐school leavers has declined for 1997 but there has been a late rush in at least one state by mature age applicants.

When students consider whether or not they are going to do a university course, there are other factors that decide what they will eventually do. A university course is indeed a worthwhile goal for many secondary school leavers, but many students decide that perhaps they will not do a university course and that they will seek full-time employment. Who is to say that they are wrong? Many of them may have come to the conclusion to follow that course.

In particular, the number of science and engineering graduates as a proportion of all graduates, and science graduates in particular, has been increasing annually since 1992. Similarly, the number of engineering surveying graduates has been increasing as a proportion of all graduates since 1992, and it is in fact at its highest level since 1987.

The employment outcomes for recent science graduates do not indicate that there is an undersupply and data derived from the graduate destination survey, published by the Graduate Careers Council of Australia, showed that, of recent science graduates—and I am talking here about a bachelor degree—available for full‐time work in 1995, between 27 and 38 per cent, depending on the field, were still seeking full‐time employment five months after completing their course compared to 22.1 per cent for all disciplines. Between 45 to 75 per cent of those who were employed were working in science based occupations. Engineering graduates, on the other hand, enjoy better labour market prospects than science graduates, but there is no evidence of undersupply. In fact, the starting salaries of engineering graduates have declined in each of the last five years.

With particular reference to these two applications in those two disciplines for 1997, the analysis of first preferences by the department indicates that there is no systematic impact of differential HECS on these disciplines. In fact, first preferences increased in agriculture, law and veterinary science and all of these were in the middle or top HECS band, showing that the differential level of HECS is not a limiting factor in the choices that students make. However, the continuing decline in the number of applications for science courses is of concern to the government because the last thing we would want to happen is that in a few years time we do not have enough science graduates, particularly when I put this in the context of a consistent decline in applications for science courses since 1993.

The decline, as again Senator Carr correctly remarked, appears to be a reflection of the declining interest in science subjects to year 12 at high school where, for example, the proportion of year 12 students undertaking a physics/ science subject has fallen from half in 1986 to 44 per cent in 1992 and 31 per cent in 1995. Again, the government is most concerned about this trend and we welcome the inquiry set up by Mr Honeywood, the Victorian minister for higher education, which will address this issue.

Let us turn now to the remark by Senator Carr about the reduction of training and labour market programs. There could be no greater contrast because between the coalition government and the former Labor government which had such a disastrous record with its labour market programs. Indeed, I well remember asking many questions in estimates on the employment, education and training program which indicated that the outcomes result—that is, people who actually gained a job after going through a labour market program as administered by the former government—was very, very low.

The present government's goal is for everyone who wants a job to be able to find one. The major elements of the government's job creation strategy are being implemented or are under development. I will go on to mention some of these in a moment.

On a broader level, the budget is being placed on a more stable footing so that we know as we approach each budget what exactly is in the Treasury. I compare this situation to the result that we faced when we came into government in March 1996 and discovered the existence of the $8 billion black hole. Under our Charter of Budget Honesty, which will be introduced in the parliament in this session, the budget will see the underlying balance return to surplus by 1998‐99 and we will know at any given time in the budget cycle exactly where we stand as far as money in the Treasury is concerned.

The reduced budget deficit operating in 1996-97, brought about as a result of the May budget last year, has already helped to bring about reductions in interest rates, and it will increase national savings. These developments are critical for economic growth which underlies the creation of new jobs.

Again, relating to another portfolio, to stimulate employment, the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Act 1996 came into effect at the start of this year.
