It will take time before the full effects are felt but I would point out that the January 1997 figures for the lodging of unfair dismissal claims stood at 347. At this time in January 1996 the number of unfair dismissal claims lodged were 1,150. This represents a 69.8 percentage reduction in the number of unfair dismissal claims lodged.

Again, during the course of the employment, education and training committee's inquiry into the causes of long-term unemployment, one of the major disincentives for employers to employ was the existence of the unfair dismissal provisions. The fact that they are put on a much fairer footing will mean that employers will once again have an incentive to employ people because they will employ people knowing that if the employee proves unsatisfactory or the employee is not satisfied they will then be able to put them off and it will not be such a long and onerous process. Again, from another portfolio, that will work in with employment prospects. The government does recognise that there are many disadvantaged job seekers who will not benefit from jobs growth alone and it is reforming employment services to better assist the unemployed to benefit from real jobs growth.

If we look at some of the projects that were carried out under the Working Nation scenario before March 1996, we saw large amounts of taxpayers' dollars being spent on simply processing long-term unemployed clients through labour market programs so that they could then be reclassified as short-term unemployed. The whole thing employed a washing machine action by which the long-term unemployed were simply churned around.

Much of the formal training funded under Working Nation was demonstrated to have little or no impact on the client's chances of getting a real job and, as I remarked earlier, the successful outcomes from the labour market programs were very few. I think the highest percentage of those who actually achieved a real job within three or six months of leaving a labour market program was something approaching less than 40 per cent.

Many of the so-called job creation placements, such as jobskills, new work opportunities and the LEAP program for the long-term unemployed, were extremely expensive and they did not significantly enhance the client's chances of getting a long-term job. Later in my remarks I hope to illustrate the advantages of the work for the dole scheme which has a much greater rate of success.

The delivery and effectiveness of Working Nation was severely impaired because of the large number of programs—I think up to 26, which we have now cut back to five—their complexity and lack of flexibility. This government's reforms aim to assist those unemployed people who need assistance most, and assistance will be tailored to their individual needs. Arrangements will be simpler, less costly and more sharply focused on real job outcomes.

Let me now turn to training. This is one of the most important aspects of this government's programs. There is a planned increase—I wish Senator Carr were here to hear this—in Commonwealth expenditure on training in 1996‐96, not a reduction. Expenditure on accredited training was $240.2 million in 1995‐96, while the revised estimate for 1996‐97 is $314.1 million, an increase of $73.9 million associated with an expected increase in apprenticeships and traineeships. Again, education and training grants to the states maintain the number of student places available in 1996‐97. Funding to the states and territories, apart from designated Commonwealth funding for vocational education and training through the National Training Authority, has been increased by $10.6 million in 1997 over 1996. The allocation of funds to public—that is, TAFE—and private providers within states and territories is a matter for state and territory governments, consistent with the national strategy for vocational education and training agreed to by all governments.

Before I turn away from the provision of employment and training, I would like to mention that Senator Carr indicated that this government sees the unemployed as victims. He knows that that is not true. I would like to bring to his attention the remarks recently made by Martin Ferguson, now the member for Batman, lately the President of the ACTU. As recently as 10 February 1997, Mr Fergu son, when opposing our work for the dole scheme, told ABC Radio:
They—
referring to unemployed people—
go home and go back to bed or watch TV for the rest of the week.

If that is not painting unemployed people as victims, what is? If you over there did not take any notice of the rising level of unemployment for the 13 years that you were in government, you stand condemned for it. That is a good one, Mr Ferguson. Apparently unemployment over your 13 years of government had nothing to do with you. Neither did the record high interest rates, neither did the failed Labor job training programs that I have just gone through. Working Nation, as we discovered in estimates, certainly while I was in opposition, simply tried to hide the unemployment numbers. They were shuffled from program to program. But I guess we should not be too surprised by this.

Not only did the member for Batman say that. Your leader, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) recently said that Labor's billion dollar training programs, which you instituted, were successful not because they led to jobs but because the unemployed `weren't around the streets bothering everybody else'. You know quite well that that was said by Mr Beazley on Radio 6PR on 29 January 1997. You have got the shadow employment minister and your leader talking about the unemployed in those terms. If we had been so unwise as to ever do that, you know that there would have been question after question about our ability to govern this country. Yet you have Mr Beazley, who was a minister in your government, talking about the unemployed in those terms. If that is not painting them as victims, what is?

I would like to turn to the school sector, which was also dealt with by Senator Carr. Contrary to his assertions, this government has taken decisive action to strengthen schooling in the government area. He referred to our States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act. This was an historic act because, for the first time, it gave parents choice. Senator Carr denigrated the word `choice', but let me tell you that, for many parents who are thinking about where to send their children to school, choice is a very important element.

I would like to take particularly the Bulla Primary School in Victoria which Senator Carr mentioned. Bulla Primary School, at the time of its existence, was given the opportunity to close or to merge with another school. The parents chose—the word `choice' again—to close that school. Another school was then enabled to set up on the site. It is a private school with 21 students at the moment, as Senator Carr correctly pointed out. Parents at long last have a choice about where they will send their children.

Senator Carr and, indeed, many others on the Labor Party side, do not seem to understand that, although we have an excellent government school system in all states, many parents, for reasons of religious belief or other principles that they hold, like to have a choice about where they send their children to school. That is a choice that is being made by many parents today. Enrolments in the non‐government school sector have gone up in recent years because that is the choice that parents are making. They choose to send their children to those schools because of religious beliefs or other principles.

While we are on about choice, I would also like to point out to Senator Carr that I find it hard or easy, depending on which way you like to look at it, to understand that he does not understand that some parents like to work for their schools and help provide additional funds. That is a choice that parents make. Not all parents want to be involved in school fundraising, but some do because they feel that that involves them in their children's education. They like to do whatever is possible to assist the school to gain extra funds with which to better educate their children. He should not be on about denigrating the choice that parents make to send their children to different schools or the choice that they make to help the school in fundraising activities.

We are promoting choice and diversity, not only between the government and the non‐government sector but also within the government sector. We are encouraging government schools to communicate with parents about the quality education that those government schools offer and this lies at the basis of the recent remarks by Dr Kemp about the way in which schools should communicate with the parents about how their children are doing at school. Instead of a one‐line report, which is certainly what may have been offered in the past, you would get from the government school a detailed examination of how your child is progressing. If parents are happy with that, presumably they will chose to keep their children at the schools. In that way, students in government schools will be there because their parents have chosen those schools as the best schools for their children. These sorts of reforms can only increase confidence in the government sector.

Since we started on the promotion and the passing of the states grants schools assistance bill, Senator Carr has been running around the countryside, running down and eroding public confidence in the government school sector, and he stands condemned for that. Given that the government sector is expected to continue to educate over two million students a year, this hardly is the bare bones of a system that is left, when everyone has emigrated to the non‐government system. There will never be a movement like that. The Labor Party, who are the self‐proclaimed defenders of government schools, would much better serve those schools by ceasing to talk down their strengths and by supporting the government's initiatives in this matter.

Senator Carr also made a point about research funding, and again, I would like to comment on that. I am talking here about higher education institutions. This government has substantially increased research funding and it has put in place mechanisms to enable universities to generate additional income. This is in addition to the specific initiatives to further encourage the participation of equity groups—again, this is a term that Senator Carr loves using—in higher education, such as the provision of up to 4,000 merit equity scholarships. I do hope that you understand what this means. It means that students who are extremely bright, who do very well in their secondary school career and who may not have the means to go on to a tertiary education will then be able to access one of these 4,000 merit equity scholarships, and go on to achieve a university degree.

TALK.START.PARA: —Back to picket fences.

—I actually had the advantage of a merit equity scholarship when I did my university degree, and I do not think times have changed very much since then, let me tell you. As for your allegations that `it's only the rich and thick' who will occupy university places in the future, you are wrong. In addition, you know very well that the fee‐paying places are capped at a certain percentage of university intake and there will never be a very high proportion of fee‐paying students. The places at university will be occupied by students who have won those places on merit or who have got there by the usual processes.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, for Senator Carr to be talking about devoting half of the half‐hour that he had to factional issues and devoting the rest of the half‐hour to what Senator Conroy derisively called a mickey mouse portfolio—and you'll live to regret that, Senator Conroy—is something that I find very difficult to believe.

Lastly, I would like to turn to youth unemployment. I mention here, particularly, two initiatives that the government has put forward since the new year, which will help to deal with the unfortunately very large numbers of youth unemployed that we have had in this country as a legacy of Labor's mismanagement.

Firstly, I turn to the work for the dole scheme. Senator Carr, in his terms of reference, talked about regional and rural areas and this is something that is particularly close to me as I come from a rural area. It is in regional and rural areas that we have seen some of the worst features of Labor government mismanagement over 13 years and very high levels of unemployment.

The pilot programs that will be introduced for the work for the dole scheme will have between 20 and 30 pilot schemes in those very regional and rural areas with very high levels of unemployment, and it is expected that several thousand young people will work on projects under these pilots. It has been emphasised by the opposition in these last few days that this is a draconian scheme.

From the start, as a way of implementing this scheme, we are going to call for submissions from local communities that wish to undertake projects which involve partnerships between local government; service bodies such as Apex, Rotary and Lyons; local business; local welfare groups such as the Salvation Army; and young people. People will not be made to do this. It is for people who want to work on these sorts of projects and for organisations who want to be involved in them. It will focus on community based projects that provide direct benefits for local communities and worthwhile work experience for young people.

It is particularly the work experience that I would like to talk about for one moment because it is this that provides training. Some of these projects will include a training element and, at the end of it, the young people who participate in this scheme may very well have had the training that enables them to go out and recommend themselves to an employer. It is the first foot on the rung of the ladder.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much training in that? How many hours training?

—Not only that, the pilot scheme that will be worked out to enable them to experience real work in a real work situation will help install a work ethic in young people and it will enable them to receive that first‐hand work experience.

SPEECH.PARA: Many of the long‐term unemployed young people that we spoke to during the inquiry into the causes of long‐term unemployment with the Senate committee talked about the fact that they would leave school, they would not be able to get a job and as two, three, four, five years went on, their sense of worthlessness and inadequacy simply increased. By getting a place in either the work for the dole scheme or in one of our other major projects, the green corps, many of these young people will be able to get the sort of work experience that will enable them to then get a job later on.

The target group for the work for the dole scheme, as I said, is particularly young unemployed people, particularly the longer term unemployed. But there will be some scope to include older age groups in the pilot stage. Rather than slave labour, again as the opposition has pointed out, the participants will be paid at the relevant award rate for their age, and their hours worked per week will be the equivalent of their dole payment. We will be releasing some more details of that in the weeks to come.

The last thing I would like to deal with is, again, another dramatic initiative—the green corps. This provides great work experience for people who are interested in environmental and heritage conservation. Again, it is particularly aimed at young people between the ages of 17 and 20. The participants in the program will receive a weekly payment of $206.65 based, I hasten to assure the opposition, on the federal national training award level C and on-the-job training, since you are so interested in that, in a wide range of skills. They will work full time for 26 weeks with an option to extend to 52 weeks. The funding for this program is $41.6 million over three years. In the first year of the program, it is expected that 440 young people will have commenced a 26-week placement on a green corps project with 240 places completed. In 1997-98, it is expected that 1,360 places will have commenced with 1,260 places completed. In 1998-99, 2,000 places are expected to be available.

Certainly, one of the green corps pilot projects in Victoria is based around the town of Macedon. Certainly, there is great scope in that electorate of Burke for the sorts of job opportunities and training in the environmental area that this particular program will present. In contrast to the Working Nation programs, these projects must provide real environmental and heritage conservation outcomes, and they should exhibit a very clear community focus. Training, I assure you, Senator Conroy, will be given in skills relevant to the above projects.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many hours?

—The details are still being worked out. Don't be too impatient. All will be revealed in due course. For those of you on the other side of the chamber who are so anxious to hear all these details of our projects, we will simply deluge you in details.

SPEECH.PARA: I do hope I have demonstrated that none of the remarks made by Senator Carr apply. The government is determined to forge forward in all of these areas and present an excellent program in labour market programs, higher education and public education to present to the Australian people over the coming years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I think all Senator Troeth has done is indulge in a point scoring exercise with Senator Carr. I have yet to hear any commitment, any outline or any detail of policies for sustainable employment opportunities for young unemployed Australians from this government in this debate or, in fact, since we began sitting this year.

SPEECH.PARA: If Senator Troeth was concerned that Senator Carr did not address the specific points in today's general business motion, I will assure her and her colleagues that I will apply my attention to each point, (a) through to (e), starting with the first one; that is, the government's `unwillingness to address concerns of the higher education community about the problem of declining demand for university courses, particularly in regional Australia, resulting from increased Higher Education Contribution Scheme charges'.

Certainly this government stands condemned for two reasons. The first is its absolute lack of commitment to providing and adequately funding universal public education at whatever level in this country—primary, secondary or tertiary. The second reason is that this government went to the election in March with very clear policy objectives in the area of education, specifically higher education. They were not going to cut Austudy, and what did they do? The independent age is up from 22 to 25 years and more stringent eligibility criteria were applied. They were not going to cut operating grants and what did they do? They instituted $600 million worth of operating grants cuts over the next three years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame.

—Shame, indeed. What else did they promise? No fees and charges increases. Look at HECS. We have gone from an annual payment of $2,300 per annum right up to, in some cases, $5,500 per year for some courses. I am not surprised at a report that in fact only arrived in my office today called Swindler's List . It is by the Geelong Association of Students. They point out some fascinating facts about Austudy and HECS repayment schedules. They ask:

BREAK.PARA: Did you know that if you take out an Austudy supplement you could get an additional $70 per week but you could be paying $70 per week to the government for the rest of your life.

So when Senator Abetz, as an example, stands up in this place, as he did yesterday, and talks about intergenerational equity and how we should not burden the young Australians of today or tomorrow with debt, be it debt in the form of a budget deficit, he overlooked the fact that this government has imposed a greater amount of debt on its students and on its young people than any other government beforehand. Not only have they increased HECS charges and fees, but of course from next year we will also see the operation of up‐front and full-cost fees for some courses.

How dare Senator Troeth stand up here and talk about choice in education in this country! Choice went out of the window when education was linked to your ability to pay. When it is your bank balance and not your brains that counts, there is no choice. Even the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) conceded in the debate last year that in fact there would be people who could not take advantage of an up-front, full-cost fee option. How could they? People cannot automatically take out $30,000 at the beginning of a year and then enrol in a course accordingly.

Senator Troeth mentioned that education has not changed that much since she was studying. I am so glad that she had the advantage of a merit based scholarship. Many of her colleagues—in fact, many people in this chamber—had the advantage of publicly funded education, be it under Whitlam or beforehand.

Our education sector has undergone the most radical reforms in its history—and only in the last few months. So for Senator Troeth to suggest otherwise shows that she is not up to date with this portfolio. Last year the threshold at which graduates begin to repay their HECS debt was reduced from average weekly earnings to 27 per cent below average weekly earnings. This means that graduates' debts kick in by the time they reach a salary of around $22,000 per annum.

We have already had research in this place from NATSEM that demonstrates, for example, that women are three times less likely to repay their HECS debts by the age of 30 than men. We have seen that it is the traditionally disadvantaged groups in our community that cannot enter into and participate in higher education or any other education institutions if faced with the prospect of up‐front and full cost fees. In fact, HECS, up‐front, full cost, non-award or postgraduate fees all act as a psychological and financial disincentive to enter the higher education system.

I am glad that Senator Troeth knows a few details about the scholarship system that is to be applied over the next few years, because the rest of us are still waiting for clarification as to how that scheme will operate. Will it be based on merit? Will it be based on a person's socioeconomic status? As to the 4,000 scholarships over four years for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, as I have already said, whoop‐de‐do. According to research from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander higher education network, the chance of getting a scholarship to a university such as Sydney University is one in 4,000. So I have to seriously question the government's commitment to access and equity.

In terms of reduced enrolments, the figures speak for themselves. I mentioned in this place the other day that the decline in the total number of university applications was three per cent in Queensland; five per cent in Western Australia; six per cent in Victoria; six per cent in New South Wales; seven per cent in South Australia; and eight per cent in Tasmania. We have glaring evidence that enrolment applications have sunk. How dare Senator Troeth talk about a last-minute increase in mature age applications. There could be nothing but an increase in mature age applications.

Let us look at the applications made by mature age students to higher education institutions around the country. As at the close of applications, they had fallen by 12 per cent in South Australia, 13 per cent in Victoria, 15 per cent in Tasmania, 17 per cent in Western Australia and 19 per cent in New South Wales. Let us hope there was a last‐minute increase in mature age applications because mature age students have certainly been hit hardest by many of these so-called reforms which are basically a radical restructuring of our education system.

The second part of the motion before the chamber deals with the complete abrogation of the government's responsibility to ensure an adequate supply of science and engineering graduates. I now turn to the areas in which enrolment applications have declined. There is clear evidence of a trend of a decline in engineering and science courses across the nation. I am not quite sure where Senator Troeth is getting her figures from. In my home state we need only look at the types of courses and the types of subjects being affected. They include nursing, education, business studies and Aboriginal studies, with science and engineering courses being the hardest hit.

I believe this continuing decline can be attributed to increased fees and charges. Despite pledges from both the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran) and the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs to review the new HECS system if there was a decline in enrolments or if it was seen to have an adverse impact on those particular courses, we have seen little action. Mr McGauran conceded last year that HECS had the potential to act as a disincentive to students pursuing science based courses and careers. They were his exact words. But we are yet to see any action from either minister in this particular area.

I know what we have seen from both ministers: a purported concern about the drop in science enrolments and young people pursuing science based careers. It seems that Mr McGauran blamed the schools while Senator Vanstone blamed the universities. They are probably chasing tails and blaming each other at the moment. Still, there is a lack of action while they indulge in their political point scoring.

The market drive to reduce funding and to seek accountability must be balanced with the pursuit of excellence and the quest for knowledge—something we in this country seem to have forgotten. Important discoveries in the areas of science and engineering may not be immediately useful or marketable. In fact, new technologies and ideas occur in a historical context. Incremental developments make the foundation upon which major advances can occur.

Further, the art of creativity and the nurturing of creative people upon which science and technology of course rely do not always march to the regular beat of a financial drum and short-term economic timetables. The research path in itself, by its very nature, is unpredictable. Therefore, there must be a balance which recognises the value of science and technology, teaching and research, and the long-term benefits that follow from healthy and vibrant research.

Make no mistake: the significant challenges of the future are within our lifetimes and require our urgent attention. The Democrats understand the possible consequences of global warming, pollution in our cities, population increases, emergent diseases, environment degradation, et cetera. These are all issues which we should be addressing through research, teaching and education, and by social change based on the results of new science and technology.

However, by understanding these challenges, we will be better able to identify the relevant considerations that we have as a nation and to implement workable solutions. This is founded on the idea that persuasive solutions should be based on evidence tested by experience. Education has a significant role to play in addressing a general understanding of modern science and technology and in preparing the community for the complex legal and ethical solutions generated by the introduction of technology—again, other issues which we will have to grapple with not only as a parliament but also as a nation.

At present, education fails to adequately prepare the general community for a world which is dominated by the consequences and the products of science and technology. This, in part, can be changed by a serious commitment from the government to support and fund innovative science programs in schools and to create a vital research community. We have seen from this government only a token gesture in this regard. I think an additional $12 million over the next three years is going into a program designed to encourage young people to pursue science at school. But $12 million over three years is not going to address or arrest the dramatic decline we have seen in science enrolments.

The falling interest in schools' base science subjects and falling university applications show not only that this measure is necessary and it is a good and small start, but that it is certainly not going to be enough. A strong and vibrant research community that has adequate funding and a long-term perspective will attract young people because they will see that there is an opportunity to pursue excellence and their imagination. We should also ensure that there is sufficient training through schooling and university to provide the passion, intellect and imagination for this research excellence.

As science and technology spokesperson for the Democrats, as well as higher education and employment spokesperson, I am inundated all the time with letters, e-mail and faxes from students who are currently studying science or thinking about science based careers but are unsure about their future. For example, last week I received an e-mail from Chris Wilkinson, a PhD student in astrophysics, nearing the end of his studies. Chris set out a number of examples facing young scientists. He said:

I personally, and many of my colleagues, are now at the point that we cannot encourage school leavers to go into science without seriously warning them about the conditions they face. The message needs to get out that science is definitely not vocational, that they should expect to have to branch out when they finish, and that generally does not lead to research. In that case serious thought should be made to choosing something more vocational, such as computing. Research is extremely hard to get into, and the conditions they face there are appalling and I think exploitative. They will be underpaid, unvalued and overworked and after a few years will quite likely have to get out of it and do something else, at which point you have to consider the worth of it all.

Even the Premier of Victoria, Jeff Kennett, has announced some assistance for science and engineering, realising the potential loss of skills in Victorian institutions—both science based institutions as well as universities and schools—in the near future. He understands that Victoria will suffer as a result of such losses.

I am also pleased to note that Senator Troeth mentioned the initiative of the Victorian Minister for Education, Mr Honeywood. I believe he set up a committee designed to investigate—and, hopefully, stop and make recommendations about—the drawing away of young people from science and science based careers. It is something that has been echoed by a former minister in the South Australian government, Mr Bob Such, who argues that his federal colleagues have inflicted a double whammy on his state and on students and aspiring students, not only through HECS debts but, of course, through institutional funding cuts. He was particularly concerned about science.
I am pleased to note that even Senator Vanstone has recently acknowledged in the Senate:
Science and engineering are vitally important faculties at universities . . .

So perhaps Senator Vanstone and Mr McGauran could stop blaming each other and come up with some recommendations as to how we can protect the interests of science and science graduates. Creating an environment in which science and technology flourishes is in all our interests and will draw young people to those careers as well as create solutions for the future. By failing to act now, the government is, indeed, as per the words of the motion in front of us today, abrogating its responsibilities.

Let us turn to part (c)—reduction of training and labour market programs. Again, Senator Troeth trumpeted the coalition's two initiatives—two big initiatives, apparently. I am surprised that she referred to the work for the dole scheme as an initiative because it has to be one of the oldest solutions for a very modern and growing problem, that of unemployment. I was particularly disappointed this week to hear this government talk about a work for the dole scheme and to dredge up this anachronistic idea to the problem that we are dealing with.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do all the young people like it?

—Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, I will take that interjection. Why do all the young people like it? Since when has this government consulted young people about anything to do with government policy? Since when? I can tell you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that there is only one political party that I know of that conducts not research into young people but actually asks young people for their views and opinions on the issues affecting them, from education, employment and training right through to sex, drugs and rock and roll. I have never seen a member of this government do anything except portray young people in this place with stereotypic and negative ideas.

BREAK.PARA: We only have to examine the treatment of young people in the last week. Let us look at this parliament and let us look at the example that Senator Troeth put forward. Let us look at the way the media has portrayed young people in the work for the dole debate. Have you seen a newspaper story on this accompanied with any image apart from young people with surfboards or skateboards?

The seasonally adjusted figures out today show that 27.3 per cent of 15- to 19-year-olds are looking for work. That means that 88,500 15- to 19-year-olds are looking for work and cannot get it. The inference that this government and other members draw on occasions is that young people are sitting at home. They are not looking for work—they are watching TV and they are having a ball. Life's a beach for young Australians! Well, it is not. Not when we are looking at incredibly staggeringly high levels of youth employment.

What does this government do? It comes up with two paltry initiatives. It scraps 107,000 places from labour market programs and other education, training and employment placement areas and comes up with a green corps. A total of 240 places will be provided in 1996-97 through the green corps for young Australians. Even then you have to get in on merit and you can only be aged 17 to 20. It will be funded at $41 million over three years. How token can we get in this nation?

As a Democrat I would support environmental initiatives, environmental industries or anything in that area. We are desperate for those kinds of solutions. We are desperate for sustainable and long‐term job opportunities for people in this country. Not only is this a token gesture but, again, the government has broken a promise. They said that the green corps would be funded at $68 million over three years, it would be open to 17- to 25-year-olds, it would not be accessed on merit and that young people who were interested in environmental initiatives could apply.

What about the work for the dole scheme? I do not know why this government persists with the assumption that young people need to be compelled to work. The irony is that young people are looking for work. They want work. Many of them have amazing education and training qualifications. Even if those who do have degrees and are seeking entry into the work force get in, graduate starting salaries are at an all time low. So why compel people? People do not need compulsion. The fact is that the jobs are not out there. I have heard nothing from this government as to how they are going to start creating jobs for young people or for anyone in this community. Let us not forget that while young people are a specific group, there are other groups—unemployed people in this nation—who have been treated badly by this government and former governments.

Senator Alston might like to get up after me and explain his initiatives for sustainable environmental industries, high technology fields, valued added manufacturing. Maybe he would like to talk about how we are going to create the jobs of the future—and I mean meaningful jobs. I am not talking about short- term, ad hoc, stopgap measures designed to keep young people occupied while they receive their benefits.

Another thing people seem to forget about dole recipients and those people in receipt of social security benefits is that there already are elements of compulsion involved, there already are mutual responsibilities that have to be met. People are now filling in dole diaries and they have to be answerable to employer contact units and other measures that are designed indeed to—if only Senator Troeth were here—blame the victim. It implies that young people are not trying hard enough when in fact they are trying, yet the jobs are not there for them.

The government talks about the benefits of low inflation, business confidence and balanced budgets as the way to restore substantial jobs growth. Unfortunately, the Treasury forecast for unemployment at 8.25 per cent by June this year is way off the mark. Even private sector forecasters suggest that unemployment could be as high as nine per cent by even midyear. That is based on current laws and current initiatives and other regulatory measures by this government.

The recent Westpac and Melbourne Institute index shows a drop in consumer confidence, and the DEETYA indicator shows an employment decline. The recent revelations about the need for further budget cuts suggest that a balanced budget may be some way off. Even if the Treasurer, Mr Costello, is so interested in and committed to a deficit reduction strategy, as we all are—all Democrats support a reduced budget deficit but not at the expense of the economy and not so that we create environmental and intellectual deficits in the future—why not create jobs? I understand that an increase in the jobs rate of one per cent would knock $1.5 billion off our deficit. So we do seem to be approaching it from another perspective.

So what has happened to labour market programs in this country? Senator Vanstone has suggested—indeed, Senator Troeth pursued this line as well—that the labour market programs LEAP and REEP, the landcare and regional environmental programs that existed under the former government, admittedly, were not working and that projects like LEAP, REEP or others did not necessarily have positive outcomes.

I am not entirely uncritical of some of the labour market programs that existed, but Working Nation and the concept behind it were short lived before this government cut Working Nation. Why not take the best bits and get rid of the worst bits as opposed to making the massive cuts—$1.4 billion worth of cuts—to labour market programs that were made. LEAP and REEP may be defined as being so-called unsuccessful because they had around only a 45 per cent success rate, but the 14,000 LEAP placements in 1995 meant that around 6,000 young people still went on to further education, training or employment. So even if we define that as an unsuccessful program, at least 6,000 people still benefited from that program. LEAP and REEP were expected to help 75,000 young people and unemployed people over the next three years, and we have replaced that with the green corps, which is expected to help 3,500 people over the same period—that is, assuming we meet the government's targets, but so far the green corps has failed in its objectives.

For 15- to 20-year-olds the labour market programs LEAP, REEP, NWOs, jobtrain, accredited training for youth, the special intervention program, skillshare and job club have all been abolished with a total loss of youth labour market placements of over 120,000. Over 120,000 places have been lost. When we weigh that up against the green corps and the work for the dole so-called initiatives, we start to see exactly what we are doing to unemployed people, including long-term unemployed people and young unemployed people, in this country. These programs were directed towards providing young Australians with training and access to employment. And yes, they did have varying degrees of success, but we should have built on their success—not slash them because the government simply thought that, because it was a new government, it should put its ideological stamp on government programs.

So far the government's responses to youth unemployment have been indeed problematic and disappointing. I resent the implication that the Democrats, including me, are knocking this for the sake of knocking it. We are coming up with strategies, just as we have in alternative budget proposals since 1977, for job creation, for sustainable industries. We have been coming up with strategies—yes, for budget deficit reduction but we also balance that against the needs and the wellbeing of the community, especially young Australians.

I will turn to part (d) of the motion which relates to the lack of sustainable policies. I think I have already addressed this in part, but the centrepiece of this government's budget must be—and I hope it will be—some positive plans for addressing unemployment. They can consider a range of issues, including export assistance programs, research and development—again, something that was massively slashed in the last budget—small business incentives, regional development initiatives, tax reform, infrastructure programs and, of course, environmental repair programs.

I would like to see the government embark on a community discussion about how we can solve this problem. We recognise that there has been a massive structural and technological change in our work force. The traditional jobs for young Australians do not exist anymore. Traditional entry level jobs have disappeared. For that reason it is time to start reassessing how we define work, the nature of work, in our community. Maybe that does mean talking about issues that the minister ruled out in question time the day before yesterday—job sharing, working hours, leisure, the contribution of those who are unpaid in the home, assessing different ways of how we work, income distribution. There is a range of other issues. Instead of ruling them out, at least talk about them and involve the community in these discussions before instantly dismissing them.

Unemployment should be the major focus for this government. Unfortunately, it is not. There are economic reasons but there are also social, personal, psychological and health costs of unemployment in this nation. If we really care about our community, we must address unemployment as a priority.

The last part of Senator Carr's motion before us today relates to the government's failure to defend public education. This is where I have a go at both sides. Unfortunately, although Senator Carr moved this motion, and it is one with which we agree, the process of pursuing user‐pays education both at a secondary level and at a higher education level, specifically the introduction of HECS and the deregulation of post-graduate fees, occurred under the last government.

The Australian Democrats have always supported and defended a universally accessible and publicly funded higher education system. It has been a part of our policy since we began in 1977 and we have voted against every attempt to impose and increase fees for education in this country—the HEAC in 1986, HECS in 1988, postgraduate fees all through the 1980s and 1990s. We opposed Austudy loans, we opposed reductions in the threshold at which graduates begin to repay their HECS debts and of course last year we maintained that opposition in relation to the radical and truly regressive reforms to higher education introduced by the new government. So it saddens me to acknowledge that the mover of this motion is a member of a party that began this process, one that was severely and radically entrenched by the government before us today.

If we really care about education in this country, we should start to treat it as an investment and not as a cost. It is part of the solution to the economic ills of the day; it is certainly not a contributing factor. I will, as long as I am in this place, continue to oppose attacks on a publicly funded education system at whatever level. I think it is getting increasingly harder, and I have to say that it was pretty heartbreaking last year to see the ultimate edge of the wedge, if you like: the introduction of up‐front and full cost fees.

There is no doubt—all the evidence and research backs us up on this one—that those fees are a disincentive, especially for traditionally disadvantaged groups. After Whitlam opened up access to higher education after the abolition of tertiary fees in 1974, we saw an increase in participation rates of those traditionally disadvantaged groups—Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, students with disabilities, women, people from lower socioeconomic backgrounds. A vital component in that was student financial assistance, whether it was TEAS back then or Austudy and Abstudy as it is now.

But in the last few weeks I cannot imagine that there are many people in this place or in the other chamber who have not been inundated with calls from families, individuals, students and aspiring students as a result of the actual means test in the Austudy provisions. The confusion that the actual means test has resulted in has meant that some families have taken their students out of education at both the secondary and the higher education level. That evidence is available and it is heartbreakingly true.

So the combination of student financial assistance and the abolition of fees does ensure that people in our society have access to education—the one guarantee in this new modern work force for employment opportunities, and we have almost shut the door completely on an accessible and publicly funded education system. So the students who were responsible for the Geelong association paper entitled `The Swindler's List'—quite good, I thought—acknowledge that you can get in only on your ability to pay. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this motion, I highlight that I will be focusing on the points related to employment. Given the criticism that was made of Senator Carr by Senator Troeth earlier, perhaps I should also highlight that the opposition decided that, so we could comprehensively cover all the points, we would focus on different areas. So I wish to put that point on the record against the criticism made by Senator Troeth that Senator Carr did not adequately cover all points.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to indicate an apology on behalf of Senator Crowley. Because several of the speakers have taken advantage of the last opportunity they will ever have under the standing orders to speak for a full half an hour, she has had to leave the chamber and will not be able to cover the points on higher education that she was intending to cover.

BREAK.PARA: But, for my part, as I have indicated, I will focus on those points related to employment, which I think we have all acknowledged is an issue that has been identified as one of the most important issues on the political agenda of the day. In relation to this motion, I want to highlight the failure of the token Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, to adequately defend or administer those key aspects of this most critical portfolio.

I refer to Senator Vanstone as the `token minister' because of the treatment of her and other women within this parliament, within the cabinet, within the Liberal Party. The retiring sex discrimination commissioner, Sue Walpole, said that, while she was retiring for personal reasons, she was concerned about the government's poor record on women's policy.

Let us look at a couple of recent examples of that. We do not have to go beyond today's question time to find a beautiful example of how this government really is in the picket fence era of the 1960s. In question time Senator John Herron referred to Gabi Hollows as a potential adornment—adornment—to his portfolio. For heavens sake! Yesterday, in a TCF industry forum in the Great Hall in Parliament House, I and several other women attending that forum were offended by the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, Mr John Moore. He quite rightly acknowledged his wife's presence at the forum and her expertise in fashion, but also added how the rest of us should think about taking our wives along, too. That is a little bit difficult, I am afraid. Once again they are back in the 1960s, for heavens sake.

Senator Vanstone's problems may not just relate to her gender; they may also relate, as has been mentioned earlier by Senator Troeth, to some factional problems she has within the Liberal Party. I must say that `faction' was the word she used, not me. Many have already mentioned the preferment problem she faces with respect to the Kemp brothers and the allocation of the responsibility for the `new great initiative of work-for-the-dole' given to Dr Kemp rather than to her.

Before I go on to some points on employment related issues in this motion, I would like to digress just for a moment to the points made by Senator Stott Despoja. I note that Senator Alston is here in the chamber at the moment. In the past, he has referred to my perhaps having delusions of grandeur. I would rather be a little bit more humble at the moment and refer to some of my beginnings, some of my history, and say quite seriously that I do not believe that I would be here today if, as a mature age student, I did not have access to Austudy. Following her points, I am pretty sure that I would have thought three, four, five times over the issues if I had faced increases that are currently before us within the community in the HECS charges. I am pretty sure I would not be here today under those circumstances, even with delaying the stage of having a family until a fair bit later than most people do within the community. I think that that further education problem would have probably been too much for me to stumble over as a young woman hoping and aspiring for an education and development.

I sympathise with Senator Vanstone because of all these problems that she faces. I understand the difficulties. I see the 1960s aura that pervades this place and the verbiage of many of her fellow ministers. But, unfortunately, despite her having all of these problems, we do have to recall that she still is responsible for a very significant and important portfolio. The results of her failure are thousands of extra Australians unable to find work, particularly the long-term unemployed and the young. In a moment I will detail the report card on this token minister in the areas of training and labour market programs and sustainable policies to protect the long-term unemployed—areas that she is alleged to have ministerial responsibility for.

There is a clearly identified community insecurity regarding employment issues: insecurity about work, insecurity about the future of work and insecurity about retaining work under the new Workplace Relations Act. Underlying this uncertainty are, to be fair, the sweeping structural changes that have been occurring in the international economy. We have had to undergo dramatic change in response to these changes. This has resulted in significant structural employment change in the country. Many workers now need to learn new skills and require assistance to put them back on the path to employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —You've got to read this stuff. I wonder who wrote it.
—I will respond to the interjection by Senator Alston. I was of the mind that such petty interjections had actually gone with Senator Woods, but it appears that is not the case.
—Reading skills are very important.
—Let me respond one more time, Minister. I am pleased at least to be up here speaking on a subject of policy importance to the country as a whole.
—Reading cabinet submissions—that's his problem.

—He may not read the cabinet submissions, but he cannot even be in the chamber when we are dealing with legislation that he is responsible for. If the minister has difficulty with my referring to notes, then perhaps he should examine his own problems rather than mine.

BREAK.PARA: Let me refer to the problems that this country has faced under the structural employment changes that have occurred. Many workers now need to learn new skills and they require assistance to put them back on to the path of employment. Australia has abundant natural and human resources. We are located in a dynamic region which is experiencing tremendous growth. With the correct policies and priorities, we have the capacity to achieve higher growth, higher employment, better quality employment and improved living standards. Labor, when in government, recognised this and crafted policies to provide training and support programs for those in need and for those suffering from the problems associated with structural reform.

This concept seems to have eluded Minister Vanstone and the coalition government who have participated in the obliteration of many needed programs. The token minister has waffled and bungled her way through $1.8 billion of funding cutbacks of many innova tive and effective training and employment programs. Many of these programs enabled the long‐term unemployed to find work.

These programs were not failures, as Senator Stott Despoja has already highlighted, but the government has been attempting to portray them as such, expecting high success rates from programs targeted at particular problem groups such as long-term unemployed. Frankly, one long‐term unemployed person—out of five—put into a sustainable job is better than none, as often occurs in places such as Britain.

I will detail the specific labor programs that the Howard government and Minister Vanstone have presided over. The Howard government and Minister Vanstone have presided over. There is the jobskills program and the landcare and environment action program. Now, of course, we have the Green Corps—a scheme that has $3.3 million in funding in the year 1996-97 compared with the $90 million landcare and environment action program, LEAP, funded under Labor. There will be 3,500 people entering the Green Corps program compared with 13,000 people who went through LEAP in one year. That is a very big difference.

Senator Stott Despoja raised another very important point in relation to the Green Corps, and that was merit. How on earth do we determine merit for a Green Corps program? Are we going to analyse people's views on what is green? Will that get them entry? Is it their academic record? Is it their job seeking record?

TALK.START.PARA: —Green eyes!

—Green eyes might be useful. Liberal Party membership might be useful. Being a Liberal Party staffer and prepared to say the right thing on television at the right time might be useful. Who knows? We certainly have not heard, and God only knows when we ever will.

BREAK.PARA: But I digress. Let me continue to the other programs that have been abolished: the new work opportunities program, the jobtrain program, the special intervention program, the accredited training for youth program—the minister will excuse me while I read this list—the skillshare program, the formal training elements and the direct assistance elements of the training for Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders program, or TAP, the job clubs program that Senator Stott Despoja has already mentioned, and the mobility assistance scheme. The way the government is going to encourage mobility is to more strongly exert the threat to remove any benefit.

The net effect of the minister's efforts in abolishing all of these programs is nearly 27,000 extra long‐term unemployed. Long‐term unemployment levels have shown no improvement under this minister. Contrast this with the Labor government which, in trend terms, provided 32 consecutive months of decline in the number of long‐term unemployed. In fact, it is predicted that long‐term unemployment will increase under the Howard government's policies, according to forecasts by the minister's own department.

So now, when the minister effectively sabotages the chances of those people finding work, where do they go for additional assistance? Do they use Dynamo to remove the stain after today's question time? No, they go to the CES. But this will be cut, too. The minister has the Employment Placement Enterprise to rely upon. This will regulate the private sector providers of programs currently provided by the CES but—surprise again—it is likely that the EPE will not even have the resources or the capacity to adequately regulate these programs. But the minister need not worry if these service providers charge high fees at a much higher rate in real terms than the CES when it provided the services, because the one‐stop shop, the new one‐stop shop, will refer only the unemployed who have been so for more than 12 months. So there will be less to provide a service to, even if those services are going to cost more.

TALK.START.PARA: —`Fewer,' Senator Watson would tell you. `Fewer' applies to people.
—I wonder how the 1,860,000 people who presently use the CES will view the services offered by the one‐stop shop.
—Didn't you hear Senator Watson talking about `fewer' or `less'?

—What will they do when they cannot refer them to these providers? What will they do? It appears now that the interventions are focusing on grammar. I am disappointed that the government does not find more substance on which to comment. Obviously, employment assistance is going to be reduced by the new measures applied to the CES and this is particularly going to affect young people. One of the much vaunted concerns of this government is youth unemployment. In 1983, Labor faced Mr Howard's youth unemployment level of 158,000. By February 1996, it had cut it to 87,000. Labor's Working Nation program was working. It was reducing the numbers of our young unemployed.

BREAK.PARA: Yet the Howard government has added a token $160 million to the amount allocated to youth training and apprenticeship schemes; this can only be considered in the context of the impact of the $1.8 billion worth of labour market programs that have been abolished. The outcome has been no decrease in the total level of youth unemployment since the minister took office. I wonder, therefore, what the minister would say to her Prime Minister (Mr Howard), who, just prior to the election, said at the National Press Club:

I would be a very disappointed man if I had not made serious inroads into the level of youth unemployment in this country because I would like to see our performance in this area as being the mark of what we have been able to do as a Government.
I hope it is. I hope we face the next election with that as the key test. Senator Vanstone will be able to report that she has, indeed, made serious inroads—inroads in the wrong direction.

Let me refer to the other figures that were released today. Two sets of government data, released this morning, gave contrary indications of what was happening on youth unemployment. We had the minister refer in question time to the ABS data, but data released by the Department of Social Security shows an amazingly sharp jump of 9.1 per cent— that is, 3,050 young people—in the number of young people receiving dole payments. The Department of Social Security's figures suggest that any improvement the government hoped to get from its work for the dole scheme has been wiped out in one month. At the moment, the government's policy on youth unemployment is a case of running up and down on the spot. It is not going anywhere. And it criticised the Labor government for a lack of real jobs. To date, we have not heard of any real jobs in this work for the dole program. No real jobs have been highlighted at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has created real unemployment, though.

—Thank you, John. I will repeat though that unemployment is increasing—a fact that this minister in this government seems incapable of dealing with in any way except by putting her head in the sand, although additionally the minister has sat by, perhaps contemplating the chocolate strawberry frogs we heard about yesterday. She has sat by while the public sector, traditionally a place where the young obtained work and career prospects, has suffered severe cutbacks—up to 30,000 people cut out of the work force. The minister is defending the South Australian vehicle industry—this minister from South Australia. But speaking of unemployment overall, the unemployment rate rose by 0.2 per cent in December and is now 8.6 per cent. There are now 10,800 fewer full‐time jobs than when the budget was delivered.
—You did use `fewer'.

—I am pleased that you approve, Senator. The ANZ job advertisement series fell by 12.9 per cent, in seasonally adjusted terms, in the first nine months since the minister took office. The minister's own department has stated that any sustained increase in the rate of employment growth is still some way off.

BREAK.PARA: Putting up dodgy work for the dole schemes in an attempt to conceal Senator Vanstone's problems and perhaps Senator Woods's failures is not the answer. The scheme betrays the unemployed. Senator Troeth seemed to be indicating that compulsion was not really going to be a factor in these schemes. She also criticised Mr Ferguson for describing some of the characteristics of long-term unemployed people who she herself accepted suffer from a lack of worth.

Mr Ferguson was criticised for describing these problems of young people who would go home and spend the rest of the week watching television. I personally know what that is like, having suffered from an incident of severe depression when I was at school. It is not much fun going home, getting into bed and watching television. As Senator Stott Despoja pointed out, young people do not find this much fun.

It was not a criticism of young people that Mr Ferguson was making; it was a description of what happens to them when they suffer the lack of worth associated with long-term unemployment. It is no compliment to Senator Troeth that she cannot see this connection. In fact, it is no compliment to the government as a whole that during question time they attempted to score points on the matter.

The work for the dole scheme sets those who work against those who do not. That is what it is really about. Senator Vanstone has failed to help the unemployed and is now seeking to stigmatise them. The minister once claimed that the government did not deserve to be re‐elected if it did not reduce unemployment. She is, obviously, not on the Liberal Party campaign re‐election committee.

Statement by Senator Margaret Reid

Logging and Woodchipping
