I recognise that I should have declared my interest in the relation to that vote at that time, however I do so now having been informed today in a letter from Senator Brown of my failure to do so.

In making this statement I am clearly of the view that my interest in Boral shares was clearly on the public record at the time of last Thursday's vote, and in fact was on the public record for some time prior to that.
AMANDA VANSTONE

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Brown has drawn my attention to a failure on my part to declare an interest. There could be some debate as to whether there was an advantage or a benefit arising from a matter that he created and a matter that had been debated some time before. He used the forms of the Senate I believe to create an issue for his benefit and maybe to the detriment of a number of my colleagues.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation arose when a number of us were attending a committee meeting of the Senate. I would suggest that, to overcome this difficulty, the clerks should advise the presiding officer before votes are taken the matter on which the division is relevant so that, when senators enter this chamber for a division, everybody is well aware of the matter before the Senate at the time. At the time I did seek to ascertain what the vote was about and it was difficult to obtain. That, nevertheless, does not excuse the matter.

We all are required to lodge declarations of interest. My declarations are well known, being the subject of some debate both inside and outside. When we look at the register of interests, the lowest one in the register seems to be about $100. I really dispute whether the benefit that may in any circumstances occur—favourable as they could be—would be anywhere near $100 because of my small shareholding relating to a major company of which woodchipping is a subsidiary or minor part.

Nevertheless, I declare an interest in Boral for the purpose of meeting the very technical requirements which were imposed. I do remind the Senate that these matters have been discussed, voted upon previously and at all times I have registered my interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—As I have done on two previous occasions when issues concerning woodchips have been debated in the Senate, I declare that I hold shares in Boral Ltd, which has an interest in woodchips. I make this brief statement because, when a disallowance motion moved by Senator Brown was voted on in the Senate on 6 February, I did not declare this shareholding at that time, al though I had done so, as I say, on two previous occasions.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason that I did not was that, like Senator Watson, I had rushed into the division from I think a committee meeting on the other side of the building. Quite frankly, I was not clearly aware of the subject matter on which I was voting when the division occurred. I think that is something that we all find we are subject to on very frequent occasions.

When I subsequently learned that it had been a division on a woodchip issue, I thought that my two declarations on similar occasions late last year might suffice for a declaration on this occasion. However, it is now quite clear to me that this is not sufficient within the terms of procedural standing order 17(5). So I now set the record straight by repeating for the third time that I hold some shares in Boral Ltd.

Like Senator Watson, I am very proud to hold shares in several major Australian companies. Australia is crying out for productive investment. Shares are a critically important vehicle for such investment, and I am proud to be playing at least a small part—I have to say it is a pretty small part.

There are a couple of points I want to raise about procedural standing order 17 because I think it has certain practical problems. The first is that a senator who holds shares in a company may well not have a detailed knowledge of the activities in which the company is engaged, particularly if it is a large company, say, BHP—or for that matter a company such as Boral. It could be that a senator holds shares in a company which does have an interest in an area about which there is parliamentary debate and/or voting but to which fact he or she may be quite oblivious.

A second problem with procedural standing order 17 is how do you define the words `any relevant interest'? Does it mean that, if I am debating or voting on a bill dealing with company tax, fringe benefits tax or other taxes or charges on companies, I will have to get up and name every company in which I hold shares? Does it mean that if I have a bank account or savings in a superannuation fund or a mortgage on my house—as I certainly do—I have to declare all these interests if I am involved in a debate or a vote on a bill that could have an impact on interest rates? Or if I own my home do I have to declare this when debating or voting on legislative measures that impact on inflation and therefore the value of my house?

Do farmers have to declare their interests each and every time they debate or vote on a measure dealing with the rural sector? Do members of trade unions, in particular former officials of individual trade unions or trade union organisations—there are surely more than enough senators in that category on the other side of the chamber—have to declare this each and every time we debate industrial relations, industry superannuation funds or the other vast array of issues that affect trade unions and their membership? Should Senator Brown declare his directorship of the Australian Bush Heritage Fund every time he speaks about conservation?

There is no doubt whatsoever that before the Register of Senators' Interests was established in 1994, many such declarations of interest should have been made when relevant matters were being debated or voted in the Senate. Since 1994 we have had a Register of Senators' Interests, which is a public document, available for the world at large.

I wonder whether this register should not be regarded as a sufficient declaration of interest for the purposes of debate and vote in the Senate, unless of course relevant assets are not disclosed in the register because they are owned by a trust, the assets and liabilities of which have not been listed in the register.

I use the word `wonder' deliberately because I do not have a firm view of what is the best course of action. But I do think there are real questions in respect of procedural standing order 17 that should be examined. For that reason I wish to use this occasion to request the President to give consideration to referring procedural standing order 17 to the Committee of Senators' Interests for examination and report in light of the three years experience we now have of the operation of the Register of Senators' Interests and of the operation of that procedural standing order. I would also ask that the President advise the Senate at the earliest opportunity as to her views on this request.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short, I shall convey your remarks to the President.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 February 1996, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —Senators will recall that one of the more public, high profile inquiries conducted by the Senate last year was the one the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee of the Senate conducted into the development import finance facility scheme—DIFF. This scheme was axed summarily upon the government coming to office and caused great consternation, concern and damage to Australia's foreign policy relations and particularly to our relations with four of the countries in our region which were in receipt of DIFF schemes—Indonesia, Vietnam, the Philippines and China.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate committee has since found unequivocal evidence that our standing has been severely damaged in those economies. It was damaged at government level because of the way in which the scheme had been axed, but it was also damaged at a commercial level. Australian companies had spent a big dollar in developing projects that would qualify under DIFF, and often they did it with the support and cooperation of joint ventures in the target country—Indonesia, China, the Philippines or Vietnam. So industrial or commercial entities in those countries had invested in the project, too. Often those projects had a gestation life of anything up to three or so years.

Many of them—and all of this was adduced in evidence—were projects that committed to real benefits to the country, that committed priority benefits to the country often in a way in which the individual or ordinary people in that country would directly benefit. Solar lighting in Indonesia and training of people with disabilities in Indonesia were two good examples of that. Therefore, the damage was done as well across a much wider area. Now what we have is the government's response to the recommendations of that inquiry.

Might I say that the response by the government is totally inadequate. In fact, the response by the government is downright wrong or absolutely dishonest in the case of some of those responses. Let me go, for example, to the first recommendation that the government's response deals with. In many respects this is one of the key recommendations. It states:

Majority Committee Recommendation: that all companies holding DIFF Letters of Advice at the time of termination of DIFF be processed in the normal way and that additional funds be made available in the 1996/7 and subsequent years to finance successful applications.

The government have rejected that proposal and they have rejected it on the most specious of grounds. They argue that they had a clear pre-election commitment to terminate the DIFF scheme. You can argue there is some justification in that. They got elected. They said before the election that they would terminate the scheme and they certainly complied with that immediately after the election, but the majority recommendation of the committee that I have referred to which these government remarks reflect on does not mean to say that if the government does not want to terminate the scheme it cannot.

What it means to say and what it importantly recommends is that the government should do it. If it is going to proceed to do it, it should do it in a way which respects the needs of the client countries who are recipients of the benefits of the scheme and which does not damage Australia's international reputation and our foreign relation standing, particularly in this region with many of our most populous neighbours, and does not inflict financial hardship, sometimes bankruptcy, or rupture the relations between government to government in those countries.

We had considerable evidence that if all of the schemes that had received, as the majority report says, a letter of advice—that is to say that they were partially qualified for the final hurdle of selection to obtain approval to proceed with the DIFF program—were allowed to go through and be tested at each point so that the criteria of final decision making would have been the same, about 30 per cent of them would have been knocked out anyway because they would not qualify. It is far better to do it that way then just cut them off at the pass without any appeal at all.

The others would have been schemes that would have benefited Australia, would have created jobs for Australians, would have created market opportunities for Australian companies in countries where they needed that market foothold that the scheme would promote and would lead to—the evidence here was overwhelming—follow‐on work of a commercially remunerative nature which would have enabled Australian companies to expand their operations in the longer term in these high growth economies of Indonesia and China.

The coastal provinces of China are growing in economic terms at around 10 per cent. Indonesia last year grew at about eight per cent. This is a major growth market. If this recommendation had been observed, it would have enabled Australian companies to position themselves to take advantage of it. As it is now, those schemes that have been cancelled will go ahead. They just will not go ahead with Australian companies; they will go ahead with Italian companies, or French companies, or German companies, or American companies, or Japanese companies. So the work that Australians have done to create these market opportunities will be taken by foreigners.

The prestige that we have built up in developing these projects will finally go to some other nation, not Australia. The reputation we have given ourselves here is as unreliable partners in commercial development. To say that the government had said something vague about cutting the scheme before the election and that everyone knew that after the election it would do so and that therefore that is a mandate for cutting the scheme is I think specious. But what I think is even more specious is to say that by adopt ing the recommendation that I have referred to in the majority report they would be going against their own policy. They would not. They need not. They would simply have grandfathered those companies that had the opportunity to develop schemes.

Let me put this in an important foreign relations context. In October 1995, the then Australian trade minister, Mr Bob McMullan, was in Beijing with the Chinese Minister for Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation, Madam Wu Yi. They announced at a joint ministerial meeting a list of companies that had letters of advice. The fact that they announced it does not mean to say that those companies with letters of advice qualified. We know that. But to take a technical point that they did not qualify and therefore they can be rubbed out, which is the point the new government has taken, insults Madam Wu Yi, the trade minister for China, and causes China to lose face with those Chinese companies that were joint developing partners with the Australian companies on that list that she had published.

It was understood, as those ministers announced that list publicly, that each of those companies would have a chance to present their credentials. The fact that the new government stopped them, stopped them unilaterally without appeal so they have no chance at all, is, I think, despicable. But to pretend that we have not inflicted severe damage on our credibility and offended the Chinese, who are a major source of trade for Australia and an enduring growth economy in this region, is, I think, laughable.

I have spent more time than I ought to in the 10 minutes I am allowed on the first recommendation. There are many others that I can comment on. The government has responded to most of the other recommendations of the Senate inquiry by saying, `Well, the Simons review is going to answer that.' The Simons review is taking a lot longer than it was intending to take.

The government should give a long, strong, clear, reliable signal now to our major trading partners that it does intend to have a DIFF scheme and that DIFF scheme will operate from the next budget but that the details of it will be worked out following the Simons review, not say, `Let's wait for the Simons review. Let's then decide whether we will have a DIFF scheme, whether we will have soft loans and whether we will participate in this form of aid.' That leaves the ball up in the air. Companies are undecided, not knowing what the future prospects for them will be and Australian companies will lose market opportunity to European, North American and Japanese companies in the high growth market of Asia. That is what the government should say, and I make that as a general comment on all those references to the Simons review.
The final recommendation goes to the minority committee recommendation:

that the terms of reference of the Simons committee review of Australia's aid program be enlarged to the extent necessary to examine certain details of mixed credit arrangements such as the overall impact of the multiplier effect, flow on trade and export opportunities etc.

I think that was a worthwhile recommendation. The fact that the government has now declined to do that is a pity. It simply asked for there to be some econometric modelling done saying, `The Australian taxpayer in the aid program puts X number of dollars into foreign aid. What does that create in terms of trade for Australia and return to the Australian economy in exports, and what does that mean in terms of jobs created in Australia?' (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the response that the government has given on the DIFF inquiry. In particular, I think it is significant to look back at the original hearing on 7 August when Senator Boswell asked a question of Mr Tripp of Ralpar, one of the companies that had taken the time to put in a submission and appear. Senator Boswell said:

SPEECH.PARA: You have told them that the Senate inquiry is like the cavalry coming over the hill to help you.
Mr Tripp responded:
I did not put it quite like that, but fundamentally, yes.

So the inquiry took place. Many of the small business people who turned up to that inquiry saw the inquiry as being like the cavalry being sent to save them, their businesses and the many outlays they had made in getting to either the formal offer or the letter of advice stage. They saw the inquiry as very significantly affecting their future. Most of the companies—not all, but most—that showed up on the day in Canberra did not come for tea and biscuits or a day in Canberra; they came because they had outlaid substantial amounts of money. They had a hope, albeit belated, in respect of what the government had said at that time. They hoped that the government might in some way change its attitude to the DIFF scheme and do as my colleague Senator Cook has just said: grandfather the scheme and at least allow those who had got to the letter of advice or formal offer stage to be totally processed.

At the time of the hearing, some 57 formal offers or letters of advice had reached particular stages in the DIFF process. Of course, these never were able to proceed. The government has driven the final nail in the coffin for these people with the answers that were tabled in the Senate last week. Some companies had outlaid as little as $50,000 in getting to the letter of advice stage. Some had outlaid from $50,000 up to $100,000. Some had even outlaid up to a million dollars to get themselves through the first or the second stage. This is money that has just been washed straight down the drain, never to be recovered by these businesses. It is something that they can ill afford to have happen to them.

The other thing is that there was an effect on jobs. Most of the businesses that appeared before that inquiry were, as I said, small businesses, businesses employing somewhere in the vicinity of five to 10 employees. In one case, a project had up to 65 subcontractors involved and employed small numbers of people. What the impact on those people has been I do not know. One of the important recommendations that the government has since rejected was that the government look at putting forward another mixed credit scheme. It is quite clear that, if Australia is to be competitive in the region, we will need a mixed credit scheme which can support small business operations and allow them to get a foothold, as the DIFF scheme allowed many small businesses in Australia to get a foothold in the South‐East Asian region. The responses by the government are totally inadequate.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to inform the Senate that a long serving officer of the Department of the Senate will retire tomorrow. Mr Bill Adam joined the department on 14 February 1977—St Valentine's Day—which means that he will have served the Senate for 20 years to the day.

INTERJECT.PARA: Bill's career took him to some interesting places before he came to the Senate. He was employed as a field medical assistant based at Lufa about 80 kilometres from Goroka in Papua New Guinea. He was responsible for the general health of people living in an area of some 10,000 square miles in the New Guinea highlands. Because roads had penetrated little of the highlands in those days, most patrols were conducted on foot and Bill spent many weeks of his time away from his family.

After some years in business in the Philippines, in 1977 Bill moved to Canberra with his wife, Ines, and their family. Like many others in the old building, he began his career in the department as a Senate attendant. In 1980, he was promoted to personnel officer, and two years later to his present position where he was responsible for the maintenance of senators' office facilities. One of his first jobs was to arrange the supply of state‐of‐the‐art IBM golf ball typewriters. They were issued to senators over a period of two years strictly in order of seniority. Bill's next duty was to arrange for the supply of curtains and fridges in our offices in the old Parliament House.

From those humble beginnings not so many years ago, Bill is now responsible, among other things, for the supply and maintenance of the department's 380 personal computers, 100 facsimile machines and 30 photocopiers. I understand that he is well known among local equipment suppliers as a person who expects to get the best deal available in Canberra. I believe we have all benefited from Bill's ability to drive a hard bargain, and we have all benefited from the dedication that he applied to his work.
I know I will miss Bill and being able to go to him. On behalf of all senators, I wish him all the best for his well‐earned retirement. Thank you for coming into the chamber this evening, Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition agrees with your remarks. We wish him well in his retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the government, I wish to reinforce your statement. Bill has certainly looked after all of us. I wish him well in his retirement. I am sure he will not retire; it would be impossible for him to do that; he will just engage in other activities. On behalf of the government, I join with you in wishing him all the best for his life outside these chambers.
—Thank you. Good luck, Bill.

—The matter that I wish to raise this evening is a matter that has just occurred in the hearings of the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee looking into euthanasia. That committee had two witnesses before it who had some research funded by the taxpayers of Australia through the NHMRC. They have declined to provide us with the data of their findings on the basis that they have an agreement with the Medical Journal of Australia . Whilst I fully accept that the copyright of the article clearly vests within the Medical Journal of Australia , I believe that the data, which is being funded by the people of Australia, should have been made public. I say that because I believe the information and the tactic employed may well be designed to try to gain some extra publicity for the pro‐euthanasia cause.

BREAK.PARA: I understand that a survey was conducted in which Dr Kuhse, Professor Baume and others were involved. They sent out 3,000 surveys to general practitioners. They had a 64 per cent return rate. The signatures, I understand, of Professor Baume and Dr Kuhse were on the letters forwarding the survey. All of us in this place know that, when you send out surveys with a signature of the protagonist at the bottom, you will get your supporters responding. When I do electorate wide surveys signed off, let us say, as Eric Abetz, Liberal Senator for Tasmania, it stands to reason that I will get more Liberal supporters responding to that type of survey.
Indeed, Professor Baume acknowledged that in an article in the Medical Journal of Australia, volume 161, published on 18 July 1994, when he said:
The non‐respondents were less likely to agree that it is sometimes right for a doctor to take (active) steps to bring about a patient's death as shown in Table 2.

In table 2, you find that from those who voluntarily responded to the survey 59 per cent were allegedly in favour of euthanasia but it was only 18.2 per cent from the non‐respondents—a vast difference. When about one‐third of the people that you are inquiring into do not respond, it would be fair to say that the vast majority of those would be opposed to the particular cause of Professor Baume, who is the patron of the Voluntary Euthanasia Society of New South Wales, and Dr Kuhse, who is well known for her views.

The suggestion is being made that these researchers compared the results with the findings of what they describe as a comparable study of `medical end of life' decisions in the Netherlands. That is wrong. I have a copy of both the Dutch findings and the survey that has just been circularised around Australia and there are some very important differences. The Dutch survey was based on actual deaths from the coroners' reports. Their survey was based on a paper survey or interview going to doctors. So one was a survey of doctors; the other was a survey of coroners' reports.

The Dutch did a three‐point study, and it is very important that that be understood. They took a three‐part design which was a sample drawn from a population of physicians, a sample drawn from all deaths and they also interviewed the physicians for some 2½ hours. There are no personal interviews in relation to the study that is supposedly going to be released on Monday. So the methodology is completely different. When it comes to the refusal rate, the Dutch report said:

However, in order to present an estimate for the whole of the Netherlands, it is essential to know on how great a fraction of the total number of deaths the statements of the physicians in the sample are based. This latter information cannot always be obtained.
The report continued further:
A minimum of several thousands of deaths need to be studied to obtain a sufficiently large number to get the important statistical data.

The Dutch study claims that there is a bias in the non‐respondents. In the Dutch study, you had 15 out of 410 doctors—but, course, a whole lot more deaths being considered in those 410 doctors—but there was a non‐response rate of 2.7 per cent. In the Australian study about to be released with all the fanfare, there is a 36 per cent refusal rate—in other words, a 36 per cent rate of bias. Therefore, their bias rate will be 12 times that of the Dutch study. I hope they do not try to continue with the prospective media release, which I have, to assert that this is somehow a comparable study—because, clearly, it is not.

The questionnaires differ also in a very material way. The Dutch only asked about the acts that doctors may have undertaken to hasten death, and they asked that in the questions, whereas the Australian survey asked, `Was death caused by one or more of the following actions or omissions?' They slip in the word `omissions'.

I think everybody in this chamber knows that the euthanasia debate is not about omissions but about deliberate active actions. So to slip in the words `or omissions' will undoubtedly give you a greater number saying that they have been involved in euthanasia. The question goes on:
Was death caused by one or more of the following actions or omissions which you or a colleague decided to take with the explicit intention of not prolonging life or hastening the end of life?

So they lump in taking a course of action designed not to prolong life with an act of hastening the end of life, as though it is an active act to hasten the end of life. To try to say that an action is the same as an omission, to try to say that not prolonging a life is the same as hastening the end of life, is, I have to say, intellectually dishonest. I do not make that claim lightly.

We were denied all of this information at the Senate hearing because the witnesses wanted to go into camera. It gives me no joy to have to put this on the public record, but the simple fact is that the Senate committee and those witnesses who are about to appear before the committee tonight and tomorrow morning will be denied the right to respond on the public record to this supposed study.

I call on these people to make available the raw data for independent examination. The editor of the Medical Journal of Australia, Dr Martin Van Der Weyden, tells us that the survey results would be used to support both anti and pro euthanasia arguments. In other words, it is like statistics—anybody will be able to use the survey results to try to bolster their argument. I have a funny feeling that those involved in this study may have been trying to excite some community interest in this matter. The editor also said:
Society's energy should be more focused on palliative care . . . where modest investments have yielded excellent results . . .

The media release goes on to state that Professor Michael Ashby believes that you ought to draw a distinction between a doctor causing of hastening death by stopping active treatment or by palliative interventions and administration of a lethal injection. So he makes the distinction. I seek to table this media release from the Medical Journal of Australia entitled `Survey results provide more ammunition for euthanasia debate'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to voice the legitimate protest of residents in an area where there is a proposal to site a mobile telecom munications tower in a residential area. In the Dobell electorate on the central coast of New South Wales, Vodafone plans to erect a 30-metre communications tower. To date, Vodafone and their constructors, Hassell Pty Ltd, have failed to investigate alternative sites. Correspondence from the construction company, Hassell—

—Madam President, I take a point of order to ask a question. I know there is a speakers list, and I know that Senator Reynolds was next on the speakers list and is not here, but it has normally been the case that where a government senator leads off in the adjournment debate then he or she is followed by an opposition or non-government party senator.

—That is not the case with the adjournment debate. The speakers list for the adjournment debate often is not followed precisely. It is followed with those who are present. If I am told there has been an exchange of positions, that would be followed. In other debates that is the practice, but not the adjournment debate.
—Can I ask, then, why the list is negotiated on the basis of government and then opposition?
—That is how it comes, but the practice has been that it is followed on the basis of those who are present. You will be called next.

—As I was saying in relation to this matter in Berkeley Vale with the location of the Vodafone tower, Vodafone are ignoring their own commitment in this area to co-locate where possible. The proposed site at Bon‐Mace Close, Berkeley Vale is totally unsuitable. This tower, in the area of Tumbi Umbi in Berkeley Vale, will be the equivalent of 12 storeys in an area of single storey houses.

SPEECH.PARA: Over 1,000 residents have lodged objections on environmental and health grounds with the Wyong council. Two thousand preschool and primary school students attend schools within a one kilometre radius of the proposed tower. A private hospital is within the shadows of this communications tower.

BREAK.PARA: It is a sad irony for these residents in the electorate of Dobell that they are facing this fight with Vodafone. The present member for Dobell, Michael Lee, is the former minister for communications in the last Labor government. This fight between Vodafone and the concerned community citizens stems directly from the legislation that Michael Lee, the member for Dobell, was responsible for. The ALP act exempts Vodafone and other carriers from state and local government environment, land use, general development and planning laws.

Former Minister Lee published a code to this effect in June 1994. That national code of the last Labor government was an appalling example of window dressing. Under it, carriers were supposed to take into account environmental matters and the views of the local council. There was also the question of having the proposal to build telecommunications towers subject to arbitration by the federal environment department. What is the outcome of Labor's national code in relation to these towers? The carriers politely tell the local government and the community that they are going to proceed with construction, regardless of what they think.

Electors of Dobell in Berkeley Vale and Tumbi Umbi are furious that their local MP has left them with this time bomb to unsettle their daily lives. My colleague the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston, has replaced this window‐dressing with action. The telecommunications national code that commenced on 1 January this year has more teeth than the code that was in effect under the last Labor government.

Under this new code, carriers must refer to the council's telecommunications facility planning guidelines which indicate councils' preferred sites for towers. Carriers will be required to co‐locate mobile facilities on radio telecommunications towers, unless it is not technically feasible. That technical feasibility is determined by Austel. High impact facilities are to be notified to the council and, if requested, the carrier must consult with the community at public meetings.

Unfortunately, these changes appear to be too late for the residents in Dobell. The proposal for the Berkeley Vale tower was lodged with Wyong council on 17 December 1996. This means it is exempt from the tough provisions of the new coalition national code and comes under the old code of local member Michael Lee.

While Michael Lee remains silent on this matter, I have initiated action to seek alternative sites in the Wyong shire. I have had discussions with Liberal Mayor, Councillor Doug Eaton, to jointly approach Vodafone. We are going to meet with local residents. We have spoken to the managing director of Vodafone, Mr John Rohan. We are going to use moral persuasion to get the carrier to reconsider this decision.

As this carrier is currently acting under Labor's law in Berkeley Vale, there is no other way around it legally. All we can do is ask Vodafone to change the decision. I remain hopeful that we can clear up this mess left by Michael Lee not only in his own electorate but also in many other areas in Australia.

Our initial contacts with Vodafone in a cooperative approach have been most promising. They have promised to revisit the question of the location of the tower. They are sending up their radio and property specialists to report within a week, and we find this to be a welcome development. People should be under no doubt that the problem of communication towers and their inappropriate locations right around Australia were caused by the code set up under the last Labor government. We are changing that and, with the procedures that will come into effect after 1 July 1996, we will get this back on a proper footing so that proper environmental concerns, proper local government concerns and proper community concerns are taken into account.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to continue my remarks about the Austudy actual means test—this great bungle that the government has introduced for tertiary students around this country. I have brought into the chamber tonight the Austudy application form, which is 13 pages long if the means test does not apply to you and 17 pages long if it does. You receive an explanatory booklet with a cartoon from Leunig. That is very apt because it has somebody developing into a plant. You probably would by the time it took you to work it all out. In fact, whoever drew the cartoon should have drawn someone turning into a stone. I can imagine how difficult the form would be for students to work out. Even accountants are having problems with it.

SPEECH.PARA: The means test application form indicates that you will need to read the notes on pages nine to 12 of the Austudy application guide. If you need more information, those pages direct you to the 1997 Austudy information book, which is 69 pages long. The means test is explained in another booklet which is 36 pages long. No wonder people are confused. They do not understand exactly what applies or what they are required to put in terms of expenditure. The means test explained booklet states:
The actual means test questions require the family or independent student (as applicable) to give a summary of their expected expenditure and savings for 1997 in the following seven categories . . .

Then there are seven dot points: principal family home expenditure, other real estate expenditure, transport expenditure, general living expenditure, other family expenditure, financial expenditure and other investments‐education expenditure.

In some cases people have put down Austudy loans as expenditure when they are not required to do so. It is very difficult to find in the booklet where you are told not to do that. As a result, where people have done it—and that has been what has ruled them out of eligibility—they have to apply for a review. Just because they have made one simple mistake, they cannot simply put in a new application. That would be the simplest thing to do. They have to apply for a review which, in some cases, can take up to six months. These people are either not able to continue their studies or not able to start them.

In terms of what you are required to put as expenditure, if you put in a figure lower than the average national benchmark expenditure figures based on the ABS household expenditure survey, the department changes it.

BREAK.PARA: It seems a bit silly to ask people to fill out this application form to identify all of these various aspects of expenditure and then at the end of the day, if the department thinks it is too low and it does not match up with the average national benchmark expenditure figures, they change them anyway. Why do they not just apply the national benchmark figures and save people a lot of time and stuffing around?

This morning on radio in Tasmania, when asked a question by the interviewer about the distress being caused by the actual means test, both in the way it is structured and the way it is administered, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) said:

We tried to modify the test to make it easier than last year's and more accurate. Last year what basically happened was the Department would take the value of your house and they would impute income from that. They'd say effectively: look, if you've got a house of that value you must have 2.5% of that around in income—and so it went. We changed that to say: no, look, let's shift as far as we can towards what people tell us their expenditure will be. But we did have a number of remaining items we wanted to keep some sort of check on—because, as you understand, while most citizens are good and honest people and would fill in a form honestly, now there are a number out there who would perhaps take advantage of self-assessment and not put the correct thing in. So we decided that we would in a sense use that same imputation arrangement against a number of these things, and it's reasonably clear to me that some of those assessments are well out of kilter . . .
They certainly are out of kilter, Senator Vanstone. They are right out of kilter. The means test—well, I would not say it is a cock‐up—has resulted in students who have received—

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it is parliamentary.

—I cannot think of a much better description, Senator Herron. Students who received Austudy last year, without any change to their income or any other changes, are finding themselves either having all of their entitlement removed and not being entitled to any Austudy or having it substantially reduced. Surely the government must take a greater course of action than it has by lumping a few more people to work on the hotline to take the calls. Surely you must take some course of action whereby you can alleviate these problems, because in terms of the review process—that is a 10-page document that you have to fill in, and it is supposed to take somewhere between six to eight weeks—students who have sought to enter university have to pay certain fees by 28 February. That includes the student amenities fee of $204. Also, if they have not made a decision by 31 March with regard to where they are at, they will be liable for HECS.

BREAK.PARA: On top of that, I am curious to hear from the government about students who are part‐way through their courses or degrees who have done one or two years already. What happens to them when they are now ruled out by this stupid means test—it really is just a whole mess—with regard to the HECS debt that they have already accumulated? If they are not able to continue in university, does it mean that the HECS that they have accumulated thus far will be waived? What does it mean? Surely these people have some right to get information from the government and not have to wait in some phone queue to ultimately speak to people who do not have these answers. The answers to those questions are answers that only the government can supply. Departmental people cannot provide those answers.

Surely the minister and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) have an obligation to do something. If you talk about the importance of education and an application of fairness of education to all Australians, as you have on many occasions, surely you have a responsibility to come out and indicate to people what the situation really is. It is a ridiculous set of circumstances if you do not do something about it.

There is a whole range of other matters that really ought to be addressed by the government. I think that the minister, for whatever reason—I am not sure whether she understands it herself or not; it would appear that she does not—is simply not coming forward with answers. If the government does not do something about it, I think that will be reflected when these people come to vote at the next federal election. I am sure that they are not going to tolerate that sort of nonsense from any government or any party seeking to be a government in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to speak about the benefits of the family tax cuts and the economic as well as the social implications following the family tax initiative and the associated family income tax cuts which operated from 1 January this year.

SPEECH.PARA: There was some interesting research undertaken by the Cato Institute in the United States on the effect of reducing taxation on the economy. This research was undertaken by Stephen Moore and Dean Stansel and was reported in the Australian Financial Review of Wednesday, 15 January. I believe that these studies can be used to endorse the government's recent measures to reduce tax for Australian families. I firmly believe that these tax cuts will be of benefit not only to the immediate families but to the economy as a whole.

These two economists researched the 10 US states which had cut their taxes the most between 1990 and 1995. They then went on to compare them with the 10 US states which had actually increased their taxes the most. They found that in the ones benefiting from the tax cuts there was greater growth in employment and greater expansion of the economy; their budgets exhibited a healthier balance and their populations actually increased. Where taxes were raised, employment growth was static but where taxes were cut or reduced, there was an overall increase of 10.8 per cent in the number of jobs.

Unemployment statistics backed up this finding. Unemployment was higher in those states increasing their taxes and lower in those states decreasing their taxes. When taxes are increased the cost of producing goods and service increases. This results in higher prices and increases in the cost of family living. Family income was found to have grown by a larger percentage in states which reduced their tax. In fact, over that period a family of four was found to be significantly better off in the 10 states which had the greatest reductions in tax. Because of this, in the first half of this decade there was an influx of people into the low taxing states to take advantage of the economic benefits generated by the tax cuts.

I am proud, as you are, Madam President, to be part of a government that on 1 January this year brought in significant reductions in tax for families with dependent children. I remind others listening to this broadcast that for families with combined incomes of less than $70,000 and with one child the tax‐free threshold has been increased by $1,000, which on average will reduce their tax by $200 per year. For each additional child the income threshold for eligibility is increased by $3,000, a generous amount. Eligible families with, say, five children can expect a tax cut of $1,000 this year.

In addition, further tax cuts are now available to eligible families who have only one source of income. Where there is a single parent or one parent chooses to stay at home to look after their under‐fives, the tax‐free threshold has been increased by $2,500. Families can expect a tax cut of $500 from this measure alone.

Therefore, the study by the Cato Institute which I have mentioned supports the initiatives taken by the government as a means of improving economic growth. According to that American study, interpolated into the Australian scene, we should be able to look forward to higher family incomes, greater employment, more economic growth and a better balanced budget. So Australians should benefit not just from the initial reductions in tax but from the long-term flow-on effects in

BREAK.PARA: the economy as a whole. I congratulate the government on its initiative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 14 January 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did Mr David Marsh of `Allendale' near Boorowa, New South Wales, sign an application for a grant under the National Landcare Program (NLP) in the name of the Boorowa Community Landcare Group for a demonstration site on his own property involving $19,780 of NLP funds and a group contribution of $29,000.

(2) Did the application detail the actual nature of the work to be undertaken including the area of the site and the nature and purpose of fences or any other improvements to be undertaken; if so, what were those details.
(3) Was the application formally endorsed by the Boorowa Community Landcare Group and was the application formally recorded in the group's annual report.

(4) Did the Department write to the New South Wales Department of Conservation in January 1994 asking that costing irregularities be investigated; if so was a response received by the Department; if so: (i) when; and (ii) what was the nature of the response; if not: what follow up action was taken by the Department and when did it occur.

(5) Have there been any instances where either Commonwealth or State authorities have initiated action to recover Landcare grants where it has been discovered that those grants had not been administered in accordance with the application; if so, please provide details of these instances.

(6) Did an officer from the Department visit the site on Mr Marsh's property in 1993, if so: (a) on what date did the visit take place; and (b) did that officer verify that the funds provided through the national Landcare Program had been expended in accordance with the terms of the application.
(7)(a) How was that verification process undertaken; and (b) can a copy of the officer's report on his visit to the site be provided.
(8) Was the $29,000 identified in Mr Marsh's application as the community contribution actually expended on the project.

(9)(a) Did the Department seek legal advice as to whether or not it should seek to recover the funds allocated to Mr Marsh after the irregularities in his application were discovered; if so, what was the nature of that advice; and (b) if no such advice was sought, why not.
(10) What was the advice provided to the Commonwealth Ombudsman that led her to state in a media release dated 26 November 1996 that `the funds were used for their intended purpose'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On March 19 1992 Mr David Marsh of `Allendale' near Boorowa, New South Wales, did sign an application for a grant under the National Landcare Program (NLP) in his capacity as Chairman of the Boorowa Community Landcare Group (BCLG) for establishment of a demonstration site on the main Boorowa-Cowra Road involving $19,780 of NLP funds and a group contribution of $29,000.
(2) The project application provided a description of the work to be undertaken, and a copy of the application which received NLP funding will be provided direct to the Senator.

(3) Departmental investigations showed that the project application was endorsed by the majority of Boorowa Community Landcare Group members. A copy of a Chairman's Report 1991-92 held in Departmental records does not specifically refer to the NLP project.

(4) The Department did write to the New South Wales Department of Conservation and Land Management on 5 January 1994 seeking information on costing details. A response from the Department of Conservation and Land Management
was received on 8 February 1994, and enclosed a copy of the Statement of Receipts and Expenditure for the project ending 5 November 1993, and a copy of the detailed Financial Statement.

(5) It is not unusual for NLP projects to be varied from the original approved project specification (i.e. the application) during the life of a project. Droughts, fires, floods, illness of project managers, etc., can all be reasons for variation of original project specifications. Underspends of grant funds can also occur as a result of effective project management (including use of innovative techniques).

Systems are in place to ensure that, where project variations occur, documentation is in place to support any continued funding of the project. In addition, Audited Statements are used by NLP program administrators to ensure that unexpended funds are recovered as appropriate.

(6) An officer of the Department did visit the site of Mr Marsh's property on 29 November 1993. The officer verified that the funds provided from the NLP had been expended in accordance with the terms of the application.

(7)(a) By examination of the application form, by physical inspection of the works undertaken at the project demonstration site and by the noting of information that the demonstration site has been used for demonstration purposes. (b) Certified relevant extracts from the officer's report will be provided direct to the Senator.
(8) The community contribution as per the BCLG application was assessed and all available evidence indicated that such an amount had been expended on the project.

(9) The Department did not seek independent legal advice with regard to the provision of the grant funds made specifically available to the Boorowa Community Landcare Group for establishment of a demonstration site on the main Boorowa—Cowra Road. Such advice was not sought because claims of irregularities in the project application could not be proven.

(10) All Departmental records concerning the above grant were made the subject of an offer of access by the Ombudsman. It is a matter for the Ombudsman to provide the reasons as to why she stated in a media release that `the funds were used for their intended purpose'.
